column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: The course will help students explore and better understand how politics and their environments both internally to the enterprise and externally affect strategy formulation. This module will also allow the student to be able to explore and analyze of the inter-related nature of the environment in which business organizations exist and the implications for the way they work. An introduction to models of industry analysis. An introduction to the main theoretical planning models. The implications and influence of cultural and ethical issues for strategic planning. The effective strategies for organizational competition and growth.

The course will include but not be limited to exploring Micro-politics, concepts on national, regional and local identifies. The impact of local networks and political capital, Multinationals versus local in contextualization and influencing laws and regulations. The impact of international politics and local enterprises: trade wars, climate change, regional alliances, trade zones, international agreements, WTO. The politics and strategy inter-development of globalization vs localization with a global perspective.

We will examine a variety of questions at the intersection of strategy and international political economy. For example, how can companies gain a competitive advantage by successfully shaping their broader business environment, how do managers play political influence games with stakeholders from multiple countries and how can firms form alliances with different interest groups? We will cover a variety of topics such as analyzing a firm’s business environment, stakeholder engagement, the global economy, political influence games, sustainable development and strategy, analyzing different market and non-market environments, and firms’ interactions with political actors.

Whether you are a future staregic conmsultant, a firm manager,a policy maker, a diplomat, a lawyer or an employee of an international organization, understanding the interactions of firms with their broader business environment is an essential skill that will beinvaluable for your professional career. In today’s dynamic business environment, firms are increasingly engaging with a variety of stakeholders in order to be successful. In this new case-based block course, we will learn how firms can pursue an integrated approach to strategic management that combines elements from non-market strategy (e.g. how to successfully engage with non-market actors such as regulators or the media) with concepts from traditional market strategy (e.g. how to deal with market forces such as competitors).
This course is an elective at the end of the academic year and will expand/ add to previous strategy courses.
Attendance is highly recommended to both the lectures and workshops. Although course attendance is not compulsory, it is strongly recommended for ALL sessions.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
• Discuss the connection between business enterprises and governments in a selected firm and/or country
• Identify the key stakeholders and their roles in the political influence on enterprises and entrepreneurs
• Describe the importance of understanding how political events may impact strategy
• Demonstrate a clear understanding of political influence, political systems and their impact on firms

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/114548,2023,Corporate Venturing,Engels,Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,['prof.dr. VJA van de Vrande'],,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Small firms and start-ups play an increasingly important role in our economy. R&D spending by small firms has increased and many disruptive innovations have been conceived by new entrants to an industry, thereby posing a major threat to existing firms. In order to sustain their competitive advantage, it is important for large firms such as Eneco, Unilever, and KLM to tap into the knowledge of these start-ups and to invest in corporate venturing. Corporate venturing can be achieved in different ways, including: taking a minority position in outside businesses (corporate venture capital), building a new business as a stand-alone unit (spin-out), or building a new business inside the existing firm with a structure allowing for managerial autonomy and independence (corporate incubator or accelerator). This course will discuss strategies, organizational structures and implementation challenges of new ventures within an established corporation as well as options to leverage external partners outside the boundaries of the corporation within the process of new business development.

Each student is expected to be present during on campus lectures and to actively participate, complete assigned readings, read posted literature, listen to thought-leader presentations and podcasts and submit written assignments when due.

We understand that missing a class is sometimes inevitable. Therefore, you are allowed to miss one session (out of eight). Do keep in mind however, that absence might affect your grade: you may miss out on valuable information regarding an assignment, or miss the assignment altogether (and receive a score of 0/10).

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
• Discuss the different forms of corporate venturing and how each of them advances corporate innovation
• Identify key trends and organizational practices of corporate venturing
• Describe the importance of corporate venturing and the various ways in which it can be organized and recognized within companies
• Demonstrate a multidisciplinary view on corporate venturing and open innovation

column1: Deze uitgebreide cursus in Corporate Finance onderzoekt kritieke aspecten van financiële besluitvorming die de waarde en duurzaamheid van een bedrijf sturen. Door een gerichte verkenning van kapitaalstructuur, hefboomwerking, dividendbeleid, opties en kortetermijn financiële strategieën zullen studenten een diepgaand begrip ontwikkelen van hoe financiële keuzes van invloed zijn op de prestaties en strategische koers van een bedrijf.

Corporate finance is ondersteunend voor andere vakgebieden zoals strategie of marketing. Vaak worden in deze vakgebieden de zakelijke beslissingen geformuleerd (bijvoorbeeld in welke markten of producten moeten we investeren), terwijl we in Corporate Finance deze keuzes evalueren en analyseren hoe we ze het beste kunnen financieren

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Evalueer de financieringsbeslissingen van bedrijven met behulp van verschillende theorieën met betrekking tot de kapitaalstructuur.
Analyseer het effect van schulden op het risico- en rendementsprofiel van een bedrijf
Contrasteer verschillende kapitaalstructuren qua effecten op de kapitaalkosten en financieel risico
Bereken de waarde van een bedrijf dat gefinancierd wordt met eigen vermogen en schulden op basis van een analyse van relevante kasstromen
Analyseer de impact van het dividendbeleid op de waarde van bedrijven
Beschrijf de fundamentele concepten van opties, inclusief het verschil tussen call- en putopties
Pas verschillende methoden voor optiewaardering toe, zoals het Black-Scholes-model, risiconeutrale prijsstelling en replicerend portfolio
Analyseer de onderliggende mechanismen van werkkapitaal management.
Bereken en interpreteer de belangrijkste financiële ratios die worden gebruikt in werkkapitaal management
Kunnen verbanden leggen tussen concepten van traditionele bedrijfsfinanciering en duurzame financiering</body>

column1: The department of Viroscience of Erasmus MC organizes A Course in Virology. The course provides a comprehensive introduction to the field of fundamental and translational virus research.
The topics covered in the course are:
The course in virology is organized for PhD students, post-docs and medical microbiologists. During the course, national and international experts in the field of virology will present seminars.
Be sure to register at least one week prior to start of the course.
You will receive all details about the location, relevant literature and the final program for the course one week prior to the start of the course.
Obtaining knowledge on fundamental and translational virus research
The full 5-days course program will follow a.s.a.p.
Attendance – Attendance is mandatory for this course

This course includes mandatory attendance when registered. It is necessary to meet the attendance requirement in order to pass: if you do not meet this requirement, you will not be awarded the course EC points and the cancellation policy applies.

Attendance is compulsory for the entire course, participants may be absent for a maximum of 20% of the course. Attendance is registered during the online and live sessions of the course via Academy Attendance. Participants should register their attendance on all course days of their courses.

The moderator will issue a code and the link of the Academy Attendance website during the course. Log in with your ERNA-ID (e.g., 123456AB@eur.nl) and ‘check in’ on your mobile device. The screen will instantly show whether registration has worked or not.
N.B. it is not possible to register attendance after class so make sure to ‘check in’.

Your evaluation is important to us, as it helps us improve the course in coming years. We have made the evaluation a mandatory part of the course in order to avoid selection bias in the outcomes, and to make sure every student is heard.

On the last day of the course, you will receive an e-mail with a link to the evaluation form. Note that your answers will be processed anonymously. You will have one week to submit the evaluation form.

Certificates-of-attendance will not be provided for PhD candidates and Research Master students. Other participants can e-mail graduateschool@erasmusmc.nl to request a certificate after completing this course.

As an Erasmus MC PhD candidate, please ensure that the OSIRIS student number (the first six digits of the ERNA account) is registered in the Hora Finita account. This can be found under 'Research phase', 'TSP' tab, under the heading 'Education'. Please add the course using the course code to your Hora Finita portfolio. Once these two steps are completed the EC’s will be automatically transferred and approved.

Erasmus MC Graduate School PhD education is free of charge*. However, free of charge does not mean free of responsibility. Once you have signed up for a course or event, we expect you to attend. For every late cancellation or no-show, we have had to disappoint others who would have liked to join.
Please find the cancellation and no-show policy on STiP.
*A payment of €1.00 is required for administrative purposes.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: The long prevailing assumptions of corporate market capitalism – e.g., profit as the fundamental purpose of business (Friedman, 1970), opportunism as the key feature of managers’ behavior (Jensen & Meckling, 1976), and competition as the key process for reaching prosperity (Porter, 1998) – have recently come under serious questions. According to the Deloitte Human Capital Trends 2018 report, 77% of business and HR leaders around the world rate “citizenship and social impact” as important or critical to their strategy and identity as a corporation. The same report also noted that 86% of millennials believe the success of a business should not just be measured by financial performance. In general, people now are more concerned about climate change, social justice, inequality, corruption, terrorism, mass migration etc. Interestingly, though very powerful actors of capitalist society, businesses have long been able to ditch these issues in conducting their business operations, leaving them entirely to the hands of politicians and public sector actors. But not anymore! For their own survival businesses need to address these challenges. But how do they do so? How do social entrepreneurs tackle grand social, political and environmental challenges? How do they create measurable social impact and business opportunity? This course is designed to seek answers to these questions and equip students with tools and strategies to create social impact around the world and be the force of positive change in the society. Throughout the course students will be given a tour to the Impact World and in the process, they will enrich their theoretical and practical knowledge on impact leadership and strategies.

At the end of the course students will have a very good understanding on: 1. How can businesses reach beyond profit in a capitalist system? 2. What type of leadership is necessary and what type of organizing is required for creating social impact? 3. How do the impact processes work, and how to measure and scale up social impact?

The Beyond Profits and Promise elective is shared between two lecturers from the Department of Strategic Management and Entrepreneurship. Both lecturers bring in their own personal angle on social impact and accordingly the students will be exposed to a diverse set of elements that constitute the ‘bigger picture’. Each week will feature a three-hour lecture that centers on a specific theme regarding strategies and organizing for social impact. To complement theoretical considerations, we allow students to gain practical insights into the realities of social impact creation through case studies and guest speakers.

For preparation, students should at least read the required literature as stated in the course overview. In terms of examination, groups of students are required to write a research report on an impact project of their choice. Moreover, students will write two individual essays on topics or questions assigned by the respective course instructor.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
• Gain a theoretical understanding of the components and interrelations of impact strategies
• Understand the ‘real-life’ challenges and limitations to creating impact
• Understand the underlying logic and meaning of impact measurement
• Apply theoretical insights formulating an impact project
• Conceptualize and analyze the underlying foundation of existing projects

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/114932,2023,Creative Economy and Creative Organizations,Engels,Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,['SR Gaenssle'],,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: The economy is changing. The ‘Creative Age’ and the role of creative assets

are increasingly seen as a source of competitive advantage and generators of economic growth. The course examines the forces that have led to an increased interest in creativity and the consequences of this turn; the way artists and creators shape cities and how creativity is seen as ‘the golden thread of urban policy’; the impact of technology; the processes that support the making of culture versus those that support its exploitation; and policy and practice at local, national and international level.</body>

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: <body>The aim of the course is to develop students' understanding of an economy based on ideas rather than physical goods and the role of organizations in this creative economy. After the course, students will be able to explain how the creative or knowledge economy is different from a goods and services based economy, and how the role of organizations changes accordingly. Students will be able to explain how creative organizations are different from other organizations, and how creativity can be fostered within organizations. After the course students will be able to apply these insights in their analysis of creative organizations in a knowledge-based economy.</body>
https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/114714,2023,Creative Industries in the Global Economy,Engels,Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,['JR Fear'],,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

<body>Cultural and creative industries are increasingly recognized as important generators of revenues and jobs, as well as powerful drivers of cultural globalization, especially as the world moves into the digital age. One 2015 global survey estimated that they created $2.2 trillion in revenue and around 30 million jobs. Yet they are not new phenomenon. The high profile of multinational media companies is often described as dominance and cultural homogenization, yet it disguises the diversity and multipolar nature of the creative industries. Countries and cities have increasingly identified creative industries as an important means of economic development; cultural branding and have increasingly used historical ""heritage"" as a competitive advantage. We will critically examine the concept of creative industries and the ""creative class,"" how digitalization has made monetization more difficult and altered industry dynamics, and the relationship between cultural industries and development. The course examines why clusters and entrepreneurs emerge at specific points in time (such as Hollywood or Bollywood) and discusses how their competitiveness can be sustained. A special focus will be on how individual firms or clusters in specific places have emerged over time and altered their strategies to redesign themselves for a global digital age.</body>

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
·         Students are able to examine critically the concept, history and reality of creative industries.
·         Students understand the particularly dynamics of various creative industries over time, in particular how digitalization is changing these industries.
·         Students can assess and explain how public policy has targeted creative industries as drivers of growth, employment, and development.
·         Students can apply key concepts such as the ""gig economy,"" ""precariat,"" and ""creative class,"" in the analysis of firm-level strategies.

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/114808,2023,Creative Production: How it's Made,Engels,Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,['dr. YGD Wijngaarden'],,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: We are all avid consumers of creativity. When we get up in the morning, we might listen to some uplifting music. When we come home in the afternoon, we might play some videogames to relax. And in the evening, we read a book or attend a techno party. But how are these creative products and events developed? And who are the people producing these products and events?

Studying the production side of the creative industries is essential to understanding cultural products and cultural consumption. The creative industries have a profound influence on what we hear, see and feel. They convey the meanings we attribute to things, and the way we perceive the world. Moreover, these industries offer hundreds of thousands of jobs in the Netherlands alone, and are a major contribution to the national economy.

In this research workshop, we will study all aspects related to the production of creativity. We will focus on spaces of production, social networks of producers, the importance of gatekeepers, the daily challenges of creative workers, the effects of technological developments. Students will conduct a small-scale research project in which (part) of the discussed theory is elaborated upon and empirically examined, and will formulate a research question on topics such as the production of games, film or music, the organization of events, diversity and inclusion, the effect of AI on the work of creatives, surviving as a freelancer, co-working and knowledge exchange in creative clusters. At the same time, students are trained to obtain and analyze qualitative data about the production of creative products and events by means of doing in-depth interviews and ethnographic research. Their efforts culminate in an academic research paper.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: ·         State-of the art theory on the subject of the workshop.
·         Common research designs and methods to examine the subject concerned
·         Design and execute a small scale empirical study.
·         Report on their findings in oral and written form.
·         Critically reflect on the limitations and the possible societal implications of their research.
https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/114648,2023,Creative and Sustainable Cities,Engels,Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,['E Naclerio'],,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: What makes a city creative and sustainable? And what role do the arts and culture play in this? In this research workshop, we will delve into these question by reviewing and critically assessing relevant theoretical contributions and policy debates, and by carrying out original empirical research on the topic.

Over the past decades, the concept of creative city has encapsulated the anticipation of the economic and social benefits of the arts and the creative industries and their embeddedness in cities, resulting in a number of urban cultural policy interventions. More recently, cities are called upon to be creative in tackling societal challenges, from rising inequalities to the climate crisis. We will start the course by reviewing a number of central writings on creative and sustainable urban development; we will then zoom into the cultural and artistic sectors, to see the opportunities and challenges they face towards sustainability transitions. In parallel to these content-focused discussions, we will learn about and train research methods of qualitative data collection and analysis.

Students then work in groups and individually to develop their own original research on an empirical case relating to creative and sustainable cities. Students will train the qualitative research skills gained in this course. Possible topics for research projects include: sustainable practices in the art institutions; greening and inclusive business models in the creative industries; arts, the creative industries and urban gentrification

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: This course’s aims are threefold: firstly, students become familiarized with and critically reflect upon the key concepts and theories on the nexus between creativity, sustainability, and cities. Secondly, students train their qualitative research skills, practicing the different stages of research design. Finally, students work individually and in group apply their theoretical and methodological knowledge and research skills to develop and conduct a small qualitative research on the topic of creative cities, presented in oral and written form
https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/115876,2023,Creativity and Discovery in Science,Engels,Erasmus School of Philosophy,,['dr. TKAM de Mey'],,Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: In the first half of the twentieth century, philosophy of science was completely mesmerized by justification. Think, for instance, of verificationism and falsificationism. In this context, the emphasis was on the critical part of scientific reasoning. By contrast, in the second half of the twentieth century, with Hanson, Kuhn, and so on, the focus shifted (again) to discovery. “Friends of discovery” like Nancy Nersessian and Thomas Nickles (still) investigate the creative problem solving part of scientific reasoning. In this course, we discuss the insights and results of the friends of discovery, and reflect on how philosophy in general and philosophy of science in particular can further scientific progress, for instance, by optimizing the heuristics of creative, scientific problem solving, or by boosting or even creating conceptual integration in interdisciplinary contexts.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: (1) The student can recognize, identify, describe and apply the main notions, distinctions, problems, philosophers and isms” in the philosophy of discovery. (40%)
(2) The student can analyse, evaluate and discuss the main arguments and views in the philosophy of discovery. (30%)
(3) The student can creatively define and re(de)fine a research problem. (30%)

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: There is an extensive literature on both creativity and innovation and their relation. The definition of creativity and innovation is overly discussed yet not conclusively. In addition, scholars and practitioners have an ongoing debate on creativity’s relation and influence within human (personal) and business development.

Creativity has its own meaning within education, psychology, business and management, marketing, communications, advertising, arts and entrepreneurship for instance. Depending on which context we take as a framework for creativity, the meaning, the practice and the outcome might differ. The same can be said about when defining what innovation might be. For the same reason, scholars argue for a ‘multidisciplinary definition of innovation’ (Baregheh et al., 2009).

To narrow down the comprehensive reach of creativity and innovation within the 21st century’s context, this seminar will focus on creative thinking (CT) & creative problem solving (CPS) theories, methods and applications in more specific. CT and CPS in a 21st century (business) context will benefit students by introducing, understanding and applying essential contemporary knowledge and skills. Besides CT & CPS being a central 21st century personal skill that is required within the work field, it is also a central practice of businesses in coming up with innovative ideas, improvements and thus solutions for product, service and communication/ human related (business) matters/ challenges.

CT & CPS, both can be related to the ‘creative person’, the creative process, the creative output (products & services) and the creative environment that either facilitates or blocks thus hinders these aspects/ processes. Several (scientific and work) fields can be directly related to these researches and practices. To name a few: Organizational-, business-, product development & communication, organizational and business sustainability, management and leadership-, creativity and innovation studies, communication sciences, (positive) psychology, entrepreneurship, marketing & sales, not to mention people’s career and lives’ in an ever-changing social, societal, economic, political, cultural context. In addition to communication, collaboration is also at the core of CT & CPS processes in a group setting.

Consequently, in this seminar, the focus will be a careful selection of creativity & innovation (CT & CPS) related theories, methods and the practice of those, applicable within several fields of work (and life in general). A solid theoretical backbone will serve for the practical implementation, geared towards a sustainable career development and business operation; product, people and process innovation.

Anahita Baregheh, Jennifer Rowley, Sally Sambrook, (2009) ""Towards a multidisciplinary definition of innovation"", Management Decision, Vol. 47 Issue: 8, pp.1323-1339, https://doi.org/10.1108/00251740910984578

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

• Essential theories and methods about creativity & innovation in relation to creative thinking (CT) and creative problem solving (CPS) within a globalized 21st century organizational, team and individual context

• Realizing the need for contextual awareness to apply creativity and realize innovation (that is ‘out of the box’), feasible and sustainable (for ex.: understanding the importance of the organizational, team and individual context and realizing the implications of historical, political, socio-economic, (multi / inter) cultural, industry or sector/ field related context)

• Identifying challenges and problems (within an organizational, team and individual setting) and how to differentiate between solvable difficulties to overcome, to transform, and difficulties / situations that need a complete new approach and a solution leaving the ‘old’ behind
• Knowledge of how to effectively produce and communicate (verbally and in writing) creative & innovative ideas, processes and outcomes (consultancy project)

• Understanding the need and benefits of a responsive, open, positive attitude and a curious mind-set, allowing out of the box (creative) ideas or (novel) solutions to emerge that fit the ethical framework of the situation / context
• Understanding the benefits of collaboration and own individual responsibility within a multicultural / intercultural context
• To be able to (re)define, elaborate, refine, analyse, and evaluate one’s own ideas to improve and maximize creative (individual and group) efforts within a multicultural setting

• How to gather (research) and implement methods through which creativity and innovation can be enhanced, fostered, realized and managed within the context of an organization, team, and on an individual level
• To theorize (research, analyse, write and verbalize) creativity and innovation in a 21st century’s international / multicultural / intercultural business

• To contextualize theoretical knowledge within an empirical framework. Bringing theory into practice: To create novel solutions to existing and or foreseeable (personal, team and multicultural organizational) challenges

• To make judgments on why, where, when and how creativity and/or innovation could take place: To implement the presented methods through which creativity and innovation can be enhanced, fostered, realized and managed within the context of an organization, team, and on an individual level
• To practice critical and analytic skills, while listening, observing, writing, verbalizing the context of multidimensional possibilities within which creativity and innovation can take place

• Understanding the necessity of a high level of interaction, and when necessary (creatively) enhance collaboration to develop, implement, and communicate new ideas to others effectively within an international framework
• To develop a deeper level of self-awareness; to be a critical and creative listener, thinker, ‘actor’;
• To be aware of the need for an open mind-set that fosters every challenge as an opportunity (both within personal and career/ business context)
• To initiate (besides collaborating) creative ideas to find solutions, approaches and gradually realizing own responsibility in relation to the self and within the context of a group of individuals

column1: This course is part of the Leiden-Delft-Erasmus Joint Minor “Authenticity and Art Crime. Methods, Materials, and the Market”. It will provide students with an overview of how criminal actors can disrupt the art market and how the market itself can become a multi-dimensional criminogenic space. A range of “art crimes” are discussed like forgery, theft, looting, and fraud and their impact on collecting and the art market. The topic is approached from the fields of cultural economics, cultural sociology, and critical heritage studies, providing a transdisciplinary perspective.
The weekly courses will be a mix of lectures and more practical seminars.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: -describe the art market, its seminal actors, structure, and operation
-describe the role of intermediaries and their challenges related to art quality and authorship
-analyse why authenticity has become so important in the art market
-examine how looting, theft, and forgeries impact the art market
-examine how society perceives cultural heritage plagued by art crime</body>

column1: In dit laatste vak van het eerste jaar wordt het Rotterdamse veiligheidsbeleid centraal gesteld. Daarbij komen vragen aan bod als hoe beleid wordt gemaakt, welke veronderstellingen eraan ten grondslag liggen, en wat is de rol van de politiek en van criminaliteitscijfers daarbij. Welke soort maatregelen worden door de Gemeente getroffen en welke effecten (bedoelde en onbedoelde) hebben deze? Het is de bedoeling dat de student voor het beantwoorden van deze vragen gebruik maakt van de kennis die hij of zij heeft opgedaan bij de eerdere vakken. Daarnaast moet de student zich grondig verdiepen in het beleid en wetenschappelijke literatuur. De student stelt zelf een onderzoeksvraag op en beantwoord deze met behulp van inhoudsanalyse. Het vak Criminaliteit en samenleving leert de student als het ware om de eigen leefomgeving door een criminologische bril te bekijken.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Na het succesvol afronden van dit blok kun je:
1.         Betekenissen van concepten als veiligheid in het Rotterdams veiligheidsbeleid identificeren en evalueren;

2.         Veronderstellingen, doelstellingen en (beleids)theorieën herkennen in het Rotterdamse veiligheidsbeleid en deze kritisch beoordelen op basis van wetenschappelijke juridische en empirische literatuur;
3.         Kwantitatieve en kwalitatieve databronnen in het Rotterdams veiligheidsbeleid herkennen en beoordelen;

4.         Een onderzoeksvraag opstellen gerelateerd aan het Rotterdamse veiligheidsbeleid die te beantwoorden is met bronnenonderzoek (inhoudsanalyse), dit onderzoek uitvoeren en hierover rapporteren;
5.         Een gestructureerde, samenhangende en kritische analyse schrijven over het Rotterdams veiligheidsbeleid.

column1: <body>In dit vak staan daders en hun criminele carrières centraal.  Na het volgen van dit vak is de student in staat om verschillende soorten criminele carrières te beschrijven en te verklaren aan de hand van verschillende criminologische theoretische perspectieven. Daarbij worden de criminele carrières ook bekeken vanuit het perspectief van de daders zelf, en zullen de verschillende relaties tussen werk en criminaliteit worden bestudeerd. In de hoorcolleges wordt dieper ingegaan op de stof, en zullen meerdere gastdocenten verhalen over de loopbanen van criminelen. Ook zal er een college worden gegeven door iemand die vertelt over zijn eigen criminele carrière. Tijdens het practicum zullen de studenten de carrières van echte criminelen bestuderen, en verschillende concepten uit de literatuur daarop leren toepassen</body>

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Na het volgen van dit blok kun je:

column2: • Het ontstaan, de ontwikkeling en de beëindiging van verschillende criminele carrières beschrijven en verklaren.
• Centrale criminologische concepten die samenhangen met het ontstaan, de ontwikkeling en de beëindiging van criminele carrières benoemen en toepassen op verschillende criminele carrières.
• Het ontstaan, de ontwikkeling en de beëindiging van verschillende criminele carrières vergelijken op hun belangrijkste kenmerken, vragen en verklaringen.
• De mogelijkheden en beperkingen uitleggen en duiden van verschillende theoretische en methodologische perspectieven op criminele carrières.

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/114184,2023,Criminologisch onderzoek voor de Praktijk I,Nederlands,Erasmus School of Law,,['dr.mr. F Geelhoed', 'JM de Dood, MSc', 'prof.dr. CG van Wingerde']",,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Wetenschappelijk onderzoek kan ingezet worden om het veiligheidsbeleid vorm te geven, op effectiviteit te toetsen en om interventies op het gebied van preventie, opsporing, of vervolging gericht in te zetten (risico-analyse). Dit vak geeft inzicht in de onderzoeksvormen die daartoe van belang kunnen zijn en in de mogelijke methodologische problemen en ethische dilemma’s die zich daarbij kunnen voordoen. Daarnaast belicht het vak de wijze waarop keuzes tot stand komen in beleids- en politieke discussies en hoe daarbij wordt omgegaan met de kennis uit wetenschappelijk onderzoek. In de eerste plaats zal worden ingegaan op de verschillende stromingen in het evaluatieonderzoek en de typen onderzoek die binnen de beleidscyclus kunnen worden gedaan. Evaluatieonderzoek is veelal onderzoek in opdracht van beleidsmakers. Daarom wordt er in dit vak in de tweede plaats ingegaan op de – soms complexe – verhouding tussen beleidsmakers en onderzoekers bij opdrachtonderzoek (‘wetenschap op bestelling’), op de benutting van onderzoeksresultaten in het beleid en op de problemen en dilemma’s waarmee onderzoekers in de praktijk te maken kunnen krijgen die de integriteit en onafhankelijkheid van het onderzoek bedreigen. In het tweede deel van dit vak laten we zien hoe kwalitatieve analyse gebruikt kan worden om de aannames die aan beleid ten grondslag liggen bloot te leggen. Voor effectief veiligheidsbeleid is het niet alleen van belang om te weten wat werkt en wat niet, maar ook om effectieve interventies vervolgens gericht (op de juiste personen en situaties) te kunnen inzetten. In het laatste deel van dit vak wordt daarom aandacht besteed aan het ontwerpen en toepassen van (risico)taxatiemodellen.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Veel criminologen komen terecht in functies waarin zij te maken krijgen met onderzoek dat van belang is voor het ontwikkelen van een effectief veiligheidsbeleid, bijvoorbeeld als gebruiker, uitvoerder of opdrachtgever van dergelijk onderzoek. Het doel van dit vak is tweeledig. In de eerste plaats beoogt dit vak inzicht en vaardigheden te bieden in het type onderzoek dat van belang is voor effectief veiligheidsbeleid en in de mogelijke methodologische problemen en ethische dilemma’s die zich daarbij kunnen voordoen. In de tweede plaats is het doel van dit vak om gevoel te ontwikkelen voor de context waarin dit onderzoek wordt uitgevoerd en al dan niet doorwerkt in beleid. Daarmee draagt dit vak bij aan het kritische gebruik van onderzoek door criminologen die in de beleidspraktijk terechtkomen.
Na het volgen van dit vak kan de student:

column2: • De opzet van een plan-, proces-, en effectevaluatie beoordelen op de sterke en zwakke punten van het onderzoeksdesign, de mogelijke methodologische en praktische uitdagingen (m.b.t. uitvoerbaarheid, validiteit en betrouwbaarheid) en mogelijke oplossingen benoemen;
• Zelfstandig een onderzoeksdesign ontwerpen voor een proces- of een effectevaluatie en reflecteren op de methodologische uitdagingen;

• Kritisch reflecteren op de belangen en rollen van beleidsmakers en onderzoekers bij opdrachtonderzoek en benoemen tegen welke ethische dilemma’s de onderzoeker kan aanlopen bij de vormgeving en uitvoering van onderzoek in een beleidsgerichte context;

• Zelfstandig kwalitatieve analysetechnieken selecteren, opzetten en deze op transparante wijze binnen ATLAS.ti uitvoeren op de wettekst, adviezen en politieke en beleidsstukken rond langdurig toezicht;
• Op basis van de overstijgende patroonanalyse uitleggen welke factoren en argumenten een rol hebben gespeeld bij de ontwikkeling van het wettelijk kader rond langdurig toezicht;
• Kritisch reflecteren op de aannames die aan beleid ten grondslag liggen en het al dan niet gebruiken van wetenschappelijke kennis in de politieke discussie en beleidsvorming.

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/114185,2023,Criminologisch onderzoek voor de Praktijk II,Nederlands,Erasmus School of Law,,['A Haspel, LLM', 'dr. A Bouabid', 'dr. TFC Fischer', 'JM de Dood, MSc']",,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Dit vak bestaat uit twee onderdelen. In de eerste plaats bouwen jullie voort op de vragen uit COP1 over de effectiviteit van justitieel beleid. Daarnaast zetten jullie in dit vak de volgende belangrijke stap voor jullie afstudeerscriptie: het schrijven van de onderzoeksopzet.

In COP1 hebben jullie geleerd hoe wetenschappelijk onderzoek kan worden ingezet om het veiligheidsbeleid, in dit geval rond de wet langdurig toezicht, vorm te geven en op effectiviteit te toetsen. In COP2 bouwen we voort op dit onderwerp en richten jullie je op een belangrijk implementatievraagstuk. Voor effectief veiligheidsbeleid is het namelijk niet alleen van belang om te weten wat werkt en wat niet, maar ook om effectieve interventies vervolgens gericht (op de juiste personen en situaties) te kunnen inzetten. Voor een goede implementatie van de wet langdurig toezicht is daarom de beschikbaarheid van goede risicodiagnose-instrumenten een belangrijke randvoorwaarde. In COP2 leren jullie hoe zo’n risicodiagnose-instrument tot stand komt en wat daarbij de valkuilen zijn. Vervolgens gaan jullie op basis van een gegeven dataset zelf een risico-taxatiemodel voor criminele recidive opstellen.
Het schrijven van de onderzoeksopzet voor je scriptie

Het onderzoeksidee voor het scriptietraject dat je in blok 1 hebt ingediend, werk je in blok 2 verder uit tot een onderzoeksopzet. Dit doe je parallel aan de andere activiteiten en verplichtingen van Criminologisch Onderzoek voor de Praktijk 2. Aan het begin van het blok word je meteen gekoppeld aan een begeleider en ga je samen de onderzoeksvragen verfijnen en belangrijke literatuur, theoretische concepten en onderzoeksmethoden bespreken. Het is vervolgens aan jou om je idee en de input en feedback van de begeleider te verwerken in een onderzoeksopzet voor je scriptieonderzoek. De onderzoeksopzet vormt uiteindelijk de basis voor de inleiding, het theoretisch kader en het methodenhoofdstuk van je masterscriptie. Als je kiest voor een stagescriptie, dan zul je je onderzoeksopzet goed moeten afstemmen met de stageorganisatie.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: In dit vak ga je ervaring opdoen met een specifieke toepassing van onderzoek voor beleid waarbij gebruik gemaakt wordt van kwantitatieve data. Daarnaast moet het vak leiden tot een goede start in je afstudeertraject middels het opstellen van een goed doordachte onderzoeksopzet.
Aan het einde van dit vak kun je:

column2: • Op basis van bekende criminologische theorieën en internationale artikelen met kwantitatieve bevindingen, hypothesen formuleren over een op te stellen predictiemodel;
• Zelfstandig een risicotaxatie-model ontwerpen en de kwaliteit daarvan beoordelen met SPSS (logistische regressie en ROC-analyses), rapporteren over de bevindingen.
• Kritisch reflecteren op de kwaliteit en toepassing van taxatie instrumenten.

• Zie voor de leerdoelen van de onderzoeksopzet voor jullie masterscriptie de syllabus van het vak Masterscriptie Criminologie. In COP2 zetten jullie de eerste stap voor het behalen van deze leerdoelen.

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/111323,2023,Criminology: a broadening minor. The twilight zone between legal and illegal.,Engels,Erasmus School of Law,,['A Haspel, LLM', 'dr. JW Hiah']",,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Crime might seem like an easy concept to grasp (e.g. murder, theft), but many phenomena are in the twilight zone between the legal and the illegal (e.g. ecological damage). Some harmless acts are criminalized, other acts are ‘awful but lawful’. This broadening minor introduces students to different perspectives on crime, criminalization and victimization. The course offers tools for a critical understanding of a diverse range of crimes, their causes, and their offenders and victims. In addition to understanding crime, the minor explores a variety of approaches to respond to crime, ranging from criminal law to social prevention. Students will be introduced to the core concepts, theories and methods of criminology, to the basics of crime control and prevention and to current issues in the field of crime and justice.

Contemporary developments in criminology, crime and justice run as a thread through this minor. We pay attention to how crime, subversion and approaches to it relate to inequality and sustainability. Given that many developments in contemporary crime are inherently global, we pay attention to the role of globalization, while not losing track of local particularities in crime (policy). Think for instance of topics such as organized drugs trade in the Port of Rotterdam, cybercrime, radicalization and deforestation.

Students will learn about different perspectives on crime, criminalization and victimization. The dominant perspective in this broadening minor is a sociological and critical approach to the study of crime, by paying attention to power dimensions that are inherent to criminalization and by paying attention to unintended social consequences of crime control policies.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Upon completion of this course, you are able to:

column2: • Explain and apply core concepts in criminology
• Describe research methods and data sources in criminology and assess their strengths and weaknesses
• Describe the key criminological theories and assess their strengths and weaknesses.
• Assess the implications of different perspectives on crime for crime prevention and control
• Apply the key criminological theories to specific criminological phenomena and current issues
• Describe and compare different approaches to and strategies of crime control and prevention
• Express and debate one's own understanding of behaviour in the twilight zone between the legal and illegal with one's peers
• Collaborate with one's peers about real-life cases of behaviour in the twilight zone between the legal and the illegal

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/115095,2023,Crisis Management: Leadership in Action,Engels,Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,['dr. A Barnoy'],,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: This course brings together two extensively researched topics that are often treated in isolation: crisis management and responsible leadership. With this goal, we focus on two interrelated issues—(a) the role of leaders in crisis situations, and (b) how leaders confront a crisis of confidence because of increasing scrutiny and pressures to act in responsible ways. The first part of the course looks at how leaders communicate during a crisis. Leader actions in a crisis have a decisive impact on crisis outcomes, whether negative or positive. Moreover, because of their controversial actions, ‘star CEOs’ (e.g., Elon Musk) can create crisis-like situations for themselves and their organizations. The second part examines the pressures that today’s leaders need to navigate, from increased demands for transparency to social purpose and stakeholder criticism. In light of these amplified challenges, we spotlight contemporary developments facing the C-suite including forms of activism (e.g., CEO and employee activism), distributed or remote leadership (especially in light of COVID), and social purpose leadership, and reflect on their risks and benefits.
We will draw on a combination of relevant literature, guest lectures, and business cases to unpack the afore-mentioned topics.</body>

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: <body>After this course, students will be able to:

column2: • Gain a nuanced perspective on the interlinkages of crisis management and responsible leadership
• Understand the complex landscape in which leadership communication strategies unfold
<li>Work individually and in teams to apply theoretical insights and developments in communication best practices to evaluate contemporary examples and cases

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/114640,2023,Critical Heritage Studies,Engels,Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,['dr. TJ Hoebink'],,"Inhoud

In this course students will be introduced to the interdisciplinary field of heritage studies and its critical approaches to cultural heritage, both tangible (e.g. artefacts and monuments) and intangible (e.g. traditions and languages). We will explore the relevant theoretical concepts and approaches to study cultural heritage and look at the complex relationships between cultural heritage and power dynamics, especially those involving identity (belonging), sustainable development, tourism and human rights.
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

The purpose of the course is to acquire academic insight into and adopt a critical attitude towards cultural heritage. At the end of the seminar, you will have knowledge of cultural heritage, and, in particular, the politics that are at stake in ‘the making’ of cultural heritage. Students are expected to develop an understanding of the political, economic and social dimension of cultural heritage. Moreover, you are able to reflect on cultural heritage on a theoretical and analytical level. In doing so, you’ll be able to critically reflect on academic literature, relate theory and research to specific case studies and, finally, write a well-informed essay on a relevant sub-theme.
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/110778,2023,Critical Social Policy for Transformative Development,Engels,International Institute of Social Studies (ISS),,['dr. GTJ McCarthy', 'dr. KA Siegmann', 'dr. RBC Huijsmans', 'prof.dr. AI Chib']",,

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: This course introduces students to critical theory and aims to equip students with the conceptual tools forged by some of the major scholars working in the critical traditions such as Horkheimer, Adorno and Marcuse (The Frankfurt School), Foucault and Deleuze & Guattari (The Paris School), the Black Panther Party, Angela Davis and the Combahee River Collective (the Black Liberation Movement), and radical thought in Italy (the Autonomist movement).

Students learn to apply critical theory as a “martial art”: a means of self-defence against discursive and non-discursive structures of violence without having the right for unfair attacks (i.e., submission to the rules of responsible speech). The course provides students with the necessary historical and theoretical background needed to understand later developments in the fields of critical theory and cultural analysis (as offered by the various majors in the Humanities) and the skills to become “Critical World Citizens” in the present.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column2: • have basic knowledge of the foundational schools and thinkers of critical theory;
• have a basic understanding of the main concepts and theories used in critical theory;
• have a basic understanding of the historical context of the main thinkers and theories used in critical theory;
• have a basic understanding of the various intersections of class, race, gender and nature that undergird the critical theories studied in this course.
• be able to apply critical theory to domains as varied as science, education, culture, media, and sports.

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/115885,2023,Critique: The Impact of Philosophy on Social Sciences and Humanities,Engels,Erasmus School of Philosophy,,['CR Koekoek, MSC MA', 'J van der Klaauw, MA']",,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: What is critical thinking? This question seems more relevant than ever in an era of ‘post-truth politics’ and ‘alternative facts’, where it can be difficult to separate conspiracy from critique. This module explores some of the most important post-war continental social-philosophical theories and their consequences for disciplinary thinking in the humanities and social sciences. Learning about these theories will allow you to better understand and gain new insight into contemporary societal problems. The guiding notion in this course is that of critique, as developed by the Frankfurt School. We investigate the relation between society and the knowledge produced and methods used by social sciences and humanities (but also by medical and environmental sciences). We focus on critical theory (Habermas, Frankfurt School), poststructuralism (Foucault), feminist critique, postcolonial critique, tentacular thinking (Haraway) and critical realism (Latour).

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: After following the course ‘Critique: The Impact of Philosophy on Social Sciences and Humanities’, students should be able to…

column2: • Interpret the practices of philosophical critique (with regard to the student’s primary scientific discipline)
• Apply the theories discussed in the lectures, tutorials and texts in relation to specific cases (from the student’s primary scientific discipline)
• Reflect critically on the various roles that scientific knowledge plays in society
• Evaluate the different kinds of critique discussed in the course, both historically and systematically
• Assess the societal relevance of philosophical critique (in relation to one’s primary scientific discipline)

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/111763,2023,Cross Cultural Psychology,Engels, Nederlands",Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences,,['dr. AMF Hiemstra'],,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: With ever-increasing globalization, we live and work more and more in multi-cultural contexts. Modern technologies have increased the speed and ease with which we can travel across the globe. Messages can be exchanged over large distances in no time. In a city such as Rotterdam, where people from over 100 countries live and work, knowledge and skills in cross-cultural contacts have become essential. Future psychologists need to be prepared for working in superdiverse contexts, for example when teaching, counselling, coaching, or testing and selecting candidates.

The course cross-cultural psychology deals with various important themes across psychological subdisciplines. You will first learn what cross-cultural psychology is. You will learn to look critically through a cross-cultural lens at the themes that have been offered to you in previous courses, such as personality psychology. Is the Big 5 universal? Are there specific personality constructs for different cultures? You will also learn about acculturation strategies and how people develop a (multi) cultural identity. The course will conclude with applied psychological topics related to performance and well-being at school and at work.</body>

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
• You will have basic knowledge of what the field of (cross) cultural psychology entails
• You will understand what culture is and how culture(s) affect human psychology.
• You will have a basic understanding of contemporary theories and cross-cultural research in the fields of personality, identity, intelligence, and psychological disorders,
• You will have a basic understanding of methodological issues related to measurement and diagnostics.
• You will have a basic understanding of how cross-cultural psychology can be applied to the domains of school and work performance.
• You will have attained a useful set of critical thinking skills that help you examine, analyse, and evaluate psychological knowledge through different cultural views.
• You will be able to design and give a well-structured presentation and interact with an audience.
• You will have gained an open and accepting attitude towards different ways of thinking.
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: <body>The lectures and literature will be offered in English to all students. The national track offers tutorial group meetings and the exam in the Dutch language.</body>

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: With ever-increasing globalization, we are getting in touch with different cultures more and more. In a city such as Rotterdam, where people from over 100 countries live and work, knowledge and skills in cross-cultural contacts have become essential. This minor deals with various important themes across psychological subdisciplines, including emotions, identity and psychopathology in different cultures, cultural differences in education and in attachment, working in intercultural teams, well-being of expatriates and immigrants, and problems in conducting cross-cultural research and assessment.

This minor is intended for all students who are interested in intercultural issues and in psychology. The minor aims to increase students’ awareness of cultural differences and contributes to the development of a broader academic attitude. Working during the course with students from diverse cultural backgrounds will deepen students’ knowledge through experiencing different cultural backgrounds and viewpoints themselves.

The minor will be open for international students. For this reason, all the material and activities will be in English. The language used in all tutorial groups will therefore be English. It will be possible to answer open ended questions on the exam in Dutch.

Students from all educational backgrounds are admissible for this minor. Students who do not have a background in psychology need to be aware they may need to put in extra effort in order to master the material and understand the underlying psychological principles. This course uses a problem-based learning (PBL) approach. Students who do not have a background in PBL will receive an online training to learn how to work with this didactical model. This short digital training needs to be completed before the minor starts.

In Module 1 (Part 1), we will study the main themes within cross-cultural psychology. Classic concepts in this domain will be discussed, as well as the factors that need to be considered when performing and interpreting cross-cultural research. Themes that are subsequently treated are: cultural differences and similarities in cognitions, emotions and autobiographical memory, how normal and abnormal behavior is perceived in different cultures, and cross-cultural issues related to society and work. Examples belonging to this last theme are experiences of expatriates, and preferred leadership styles across cultures.

In Module 2 (Part 2), students learn about psychological aspects related to living in a multicultural society. This module deals with more fundamental issues, such as stereotyping and prejudice, acculturation strategies and multicultural identity development. In addition, this module addresses issues that professionals may encounter when dealing with people from different cultural backgrounds in practice. Here one can think of topics such as: the role of ethnicity in diagnostics and treatment of psychopathology, immigrants’ study success, the influence of migration on mental health, discrimination at work and team performance.
- Teaching method(s): Problem Based learning: Tutorial groups, self-study and lectures.
- Teaching materials:  Recent journal articles and book chapters, provided on the internet.

Modules 1 and 2 will be closed with a separate exam each. The exam consists of true/false statements and (short-answer) open-end questions. In addition, during Module 2 you will work in couples to prepare a presentation. During the last tutorial meeting of Module 2, you will give this presentation to the students in your tutorial group.
The final grade will be a weighted average of both Exam Part 1 and Exam Part 2, plus the grade for the presentation (weights 2 + 2 + 1).

In order to pass the course, the minimum weighted average of both Exam Part 1 and Exam Part 2 must be a 5.5. Each exam separately (Part 1 and Part 2) needs to be graded with a 5.0 at minimum. That means students can to some extent compensate an insufficient grade for one part of the minor. In addition, the assessment of the final presentation needs to be a grade of 5.5 or higher.
Students will be offered the possibility to review their answers for each part of the exam shortly after the grades have been announced.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

• Students gain insight into the following overarching themes: cross-cultural differences in child development, cognitions, emotions, personality, intelligence, psychopathology and the meaning of working.
• Students gain insight into methodological issues that play a role when conducting cross-cultural research.
• Students gain insight into ethnic differences and similarities in the domains of (mental) health care, education and the labour market.
• Students gain insight into the processes playing a role in stereotyping and discrimination.
• Students gain insight into multicultural identity development and acculturation strategies.
• Students gain insight into effective behaviour in intercultural situations.
