https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/116771,2023,Cross-sector Partnerships for Sustainable Development,Engels,Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,"['SM Pfisterer, MSc']",,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Many practitioners and academics alike argue that complex societal challenges, including sustainable development, require collaborative processes between different sectors of society (state, market and civil society). Cross-sector partnerships are therefore an important part of the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) agenda and even have their own goal: the 17th SDG is to ‘strengthen the means of implementation and revitalize the global partnership for sustainable development’.

Despite all the positive rhetoric on cross-sector partnerships, practice shows that collaborating with multiple stakeholders from different societal sectors is challenging. Challenges include aligning different institutional logics of partners, dealing with collaborative dynamics, and navigating associated tensions of partnering. In addition, critical voices point to the limited success of partnerships in addressing the systemic causes underlying the severe sustainability challenges and the limited scientific evidence for their impact.

In this course, participants are stimulated to critically look at the drivers of cross-sector partnerships, reflect at different types of cross-sector partnerships and explore how to support, manage and strengthen the process of partnering. They will study specific partnership tensions and how they can be addressed. Moreover, they will investigate why it is so difficult to determine the value and impact of partnerships.

An important element of this course is the link between theoretical concepts and their practical relevance and case studies therefore play an important role. That is why each module consists of a more theoretically oriented lecture in which the topic will be introduced and explored and a lecture in which a guest speaker is invited to talk about his/her practical experiences in working with and in partnerships. Guest speakers include partnership managers from government, business, and civil society organizations.

Students are expected to attend all classes in-person and actively participate in the lectures.  TWO absences are allowed throughout the course. With THREE absences the student will lose 10% of the final grade. With FOUR or more absences the student will fail the course. In case of force majeure (e.g., illness) an exception can be made, but a documented proof (e.g., doctor’s note) is needed.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
• Understand the concept, drivers, different types and barriers/enabling conditions of cross-sector partnerships for sustainable development
• Develop (management) strategies to deal with dynamics and tensions of partnerships
• Make use of reflexive thinking and skills needed to facilitate, manage and strengthen partnerships
• Critically reflect on the value and impact of partnerships for sustainable development
• Apply theoretical knowledge about partnerships for sustainable development to real-world situations

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/114622,2023,Cultural & Media Studies,Engels,Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,['dr. SMR Driessen'],,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: How can we make sense of superhero movies, K-pop, or meme culture theoretically? What do these products of pop(ular) culture tell us about today’s society? How do they help us to discuss power, diversity, representation, or other big current debates? In this course, we explore the interplay between popular culture and media entertainment via the lenses of Culture and Media Studies.

We (re)visit classical concepts, but also investigate contemporary and emerging ideas from these fields of research. Doing so will help us better understand and offer an instrument to consider popular culture beyond its entertainment function. Often popular culture discusses, reflections on, and helps us to examine the world we live through representing or questioning societal changes that take place. In this course, we examine current topics from influencers to race, and gender to pop music fandom. Each week, we highlight different key theories from Culture and Media Studies and address a core question and case study to dive deeper into this approach.</body>

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
• Key concepts and theories in Culture and Media Studies;
• Gain an understanding of popular culture and its role in society and societal changes.
• Compare and critically evaluate existing and emerging ideas in Culture and Media Studies;
• Analyse and reflect on the course’s key concepts and theories;
• Present and discuss the course themes in written, visual, and oral forms of assessment.

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/114655,2023,Cultural Economics: Empirical Research,Engels,Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,"['dr. A Mignosa', 'SR Gaenssle']",,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

The seminars deals with the problems of doing empirical research: how scholars have tested theories, what methods and data sources have been used, how scholars overcame the problems encountered in empirical research, what are the main limitations of their empirical works, and so on. The seminar provides a forum for discussion of the week's topic and reading material. Students are expected to read and discuss the literature and to summarise it for discussion in class. A critical approach is encouraged. Students therefore learn to appreciate standards of research and how to conduct their own research later on.

Topics covered in the course, among others: cultural policies; cultural heritage; cultural demand; artists' labour markets; culture, economy and cities; (temporary) clusters and intermediaries.</body>

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

<body>The aim of the course is to offer advanced training in the application of cultural economics to specific areas of the cultural and creative industries. The seminar builds on the Cultural Economics: Theory course in Term 1. The aim is to enable students to select areas of special interest and to become familiar on how empirical research is done by scholars in the field of the cultural and creative industries and to learn to evaluate it.</body>

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/114654,2023,Cultural Economics: Theory,Engels,Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,"['dr. C Dalla Chiesa', 'dr. CW Handke']",,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: For better or for worse, economics is a most influential theory of human behavior and a popular tool for rationalizing decisions. Economic perspectives and arguments are important in debates on public policy of almost any kind. Decision-makers in businesses draw heavily on aspects of economic theory. Economic reasoning is also increasingly employed in the cultural sector. In this course, we discuss the theoretical underpinnings of cultural economics, to help students in harnessing economics for their own purposes.

We do so by discussing ‘classic’ theoretical issues and debates that illuminate the foundations of economics. We begin with two fundamental aspects of economics, price theory and welfare economics, as well as their limitations. We continue with four main themes in cultural economics: (1) public goods, (2) intrinsic motivation, (3) uncertainty and taste formation, as well as (4) superstars. We round off the course with a discussion of economic perspectives on entrepreneurship.</body>

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: <body>This course will help you to better understand the foundations of economics in general. You will develop an overview of the main themes in cultural economics. We encourage a critical, but constructive approach to the application of economics for decision-making in the cultural sector. Usually, the question is not whether economics is perfect but whether there is a superior alternative for a specific purpose, for instance to structure your thoughts, to interpret empirical evidence and to prepare your own empirical research or to convince others. All of this will serve you as a solid basis for subsequent courses, and help you define your specific areas of interest in further stages of the M.A. in Cultural Economics & Entrepreneurship.</body>

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/114661,2023,Cultural Entrepreneurship: Empirical Research,Engels,Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,"['dr. EMMP Loots', 'L Marques']",,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: The seminar builds on the ‘Cultural Entrepreneurship: Theory’ course in Term 1. By means of weekly subjects and a number of assignments (including a mini-research in group), students will become familiar with and evaluate how cultural entrepreneurship scholars research the field. The sessions simultaneously deal with a number of prominent entrepreneurship themes and the various research methods that are being applied to address those research themes. Some examples can include case studies of entrepreneurship and place, policy for entrepreneurship, quantitative testing of entrepreneurial traits and successes, entrepreneurial networks, big data challenges in relation to entrepreneurship, ethnography in entrepreneurship, etc. Guest speakers working within the field are invited, and one of the last sessions entails a study trip (if the C19-situation allows us to do so) during which we apply our insights.

The seminar provides a forum for discussion of the weekly topic and reading materials. Students are expected to read and prepare for discussing the literature in class. A critical approach is encouraged. Students get acquainted with the standards of research in entrepreneurship and will be able to practice those standards within individual and group assignments.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: <body>The aim of the course is to get acquainted with empirical research in the setting of Cultural Entrepreneurship. The course can be considered to be an advanced training in the application of entrepreneurship theory to specific areas of the cultural and creative industries, and should allow students to independently and in group develop research on the subject.</body>
https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/114656,2023,Cultural Entrepreneurship: Theory,Engels,Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,['dr. EMMP Loots'],,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: The notion of “entrepreneurship” is commonly associated with the discovery and pursuit of new business opportunities through the creation of firms. The ultimate aim of entrepreneurial activity is seldom profit or personal wealth-creation, but rather realizing new ideas and being free from restraints. Similarly, artistic and creative work is often about the introduction of novelty, and artists and creative professionals seek to create the conditions and to overcome the barriers to be able to develop works of art and creative goods or services.

Different approaches to and theories on entrepreneurship coincide, which we will explore during this course. The series of lectures in term 1 will introduce students to the diverse facets of the entrepreneurship literature, yet, not without making the necessary connections to the practice of entrepreneurship within the cultural and creative industries. We do so by specialist readings, exercises, group work and interventions by guests. The course introduces students to professional research in cultural entrepreneurship and teaches how to critically engage with this literature. Topics of the course include (but are not limited to):

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: The aim of this course is to offer an advanced training in cultural entrepreneurship by surveying the field of (cultural) entrepreneurship. It provides students with a solid background in the subject as a basis for subsequent courses and it enables them to select areas of special interest to pursue during the MA.
https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/114619,2023,Cultural Heritage Studies,Engels,Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,['prof.dr. SL Reijnders'],,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

The scientific study of cultural heritage has developed significantly in recent decades. Not only has the interest in this subject grown explosively, also what is exactly meant by 'cultural heritage' has been changing rapidly.

Until recently, attention was focused mainly on forms of material culture of seemingly undisputed value, such as museum artifacts, monuments, and archaeological sites. However, the concept of cultural heritage has broadened considerably. It now also includes intangible forms of culture, such as rituals, customs, and traditions, which are usually associated with non-Western cultures and traditional folk culture. At the same time, within the heritage sector there is a noticeable growing interest in the role of (new) media in the creation and (re)presentation of a shared past.

The course Cultural Heritage Studies offers students an introduction to the above developments. Students take note of recent publications in these fields, do their own research - both individually and in groups - and present their findings during class meetings. For students in Arts and Culture Studies, this course provides an introduction to the heritage branch in the program and elucidates the canonization of arts and culture. Students in History and Media & Communication Studies with an interest in the handling of the present with the past will find this course a welcome addition to their usual curriculum.
NB the maximum number of participants in this course is 25.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

<body>The aim of this course is to gain knowledge and an understanding of cultural heritage, in particular relating to contemporary developments within the field of heritage studies. This insight is obtained by a) critically examining, summarizing and presenting current, scientific literature; b) applying this literature to concrete examples.</body>
https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/115098,2023,Cultural Identities and New Media,Engels,Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,['dr. A Paz Alencar'],,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: In recent years, mainly with the advent of digital technology, new media platforms and transnational media networks have become central in the study of cultural identity and acculturation processes. New media is redefining the meaning of cultural identity and shaping the integration experiences of different ethnic migrant groups in both Western and non-Western societies. The purpose of this course is to unravel the intricate relationships between new media, in, and cultural identity and acculturation through the process of definition, interpretation, and critical analysis. In this course, students will develop their own research project to examine the relationships between new technologies and cultural identity from the perspective of migration, focusing on community networks and practices to explain the new dynamics of connection and bond formation among migrants, and the development of transnational socializing in online environments. Building on qualitative interview and content analysis methodologies, students will investigate the various ways in which (ethnic) migrant groups and institutions are appropriating such new technologies and the implications of these practices for their adaptation experiences in their entirety.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
• Key theoretical perspectives on the study of cultural identities.
• The main theoretical approaches to the analysis of the role of digital media in cultural identity processes.

column1: Students have the ability and/or propensity to:

column2: • Critically analyze new media as spaces for communication and network practices adopted by different migrant populations.
• Analyze digital initiatives focusing on migrants’ experiences in relation to identity negotiations and media use.
• Collect and analyze data based on interview research and qualitative content analysis.
• Report and present research findings in a clear, organized style.

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/114651,2023,Cultural Management,Engels,Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,['L Marques'],,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: This course will introduce topics of arts and culture management, such as strategy, marketing, fundraising or leadership. Besides theoretical approaches to these topics, practical examples and case studies from international practice will be used from a range of sources. During the course, students will delve into the specificities of managing organisations and entrepreneurial activity in the cultural and creative sectors. We will study a combination of fundamental concepts in management, while exploring their current theoretical, ethical, and practical implications in an ever-changing environment and technology.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Students will get acquainted and co-creatively explore specificities of managing organisations and entrepreneurial activity in the cultural and creative sectors.
Students will develop critical insights into relevant topics of managing arts and culture using different (digital) tools, as well as working individually and in small teams.
https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/114659,2023,Cultural Organisations,Engels,Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,['dr. C Dalla Chiesa'],,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Organisations are of great importance in the production and realization of cultural value. The first half of this course will analyse the fundamental questions underlying how organisations emerge. We explore economic and managerial explanations for the existence of organisations and the different organizational formats. We analyze the difference between formal and informal organisations in the cultural sector, and their relative importance for delivering cultural value. We explore the methodological side of studying organisations. How is this best done? And how important is the interpretive side of the analysis of organisations?

The second half of the course explores particular challenges that cultural organisations face, through the analysis by students of a cultural organisation of their choice. Why do creative firms choose to cluster, or integrate? How to motivate creative workers, and is this different from motivating workers in the commercial sector? What type of conflicts are likely to arise in cultural organisations? And how can we evaluate the cultural and social goals of cultural organisations? How to balance managerial and artistic goals? What are the novel cultural organizations created under digital transformations?</body>

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
• You can explain the most common economic theories for the existence of firms.
• You can explain the difference between formal organisations and informal organisations such as innovation commons.
• You can explain some of the important advantages and disadvantages of different methodological approaches to the study of (cultural) organisations.
• You can explain different organizational formats, their benefits and constraints.
• You are able to use the theoretical insights above to analyse particular organisations and industries within the cultural sector.
• You are able to use this analysis to highlight potential danger and opportunities for a cultural organisation.
• You are able to present your analysis in an academic manner, as well as in a format that would be useful in a cultural organisation.

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/114649,2023,Cultural Participation and Taste,Engels,Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,"['OC Kriebl-Bruno', 'prof.dr. CJM van Eijck']",,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: In this research workshop, we will critically assess theoretical and empirical debates on cultural participation and taste and carry out small quantitative and qualitative research projects on the topic. Over the years, Pierre Bourdieu’s classic theory on taste, cultural classification and inequality has been applied to new art forms, expanded upon, and criticized. More generally, a shift has taken place from analyzing what culture audiences consume to how audiences consume culture. Similarly, where Bourdieu’s theory focused on class, recent research has taken a much wider range of social identities (including race, gender, sexuality, disability) into account. In this research workshop we will be exploring Bourdieusian and non-Bourdieusian theories of taste, cultural participation, and identity. We will assess, among other topics, the role of digitization and online consumption, access to cultural facilities, micro-sociologies of culture venues and the relationship between social identities and cultural consumption. To address these topics, students will learn about quantitative and qualitative methods to analyse cultural participation and taste.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: This course’s aims are threefold: firstly, students become familiarized with and critically reflect upon the key concepts and theories on the nexus between taste, cultural participation, social identities, and inequality. Secondly, students train their quantitative research skills, through a data analysis assignment. Finally, students apply their theoretical and methodological knowledge and research skills to develop and conduct a small qualitative research project on the topic of cultural participation and taste.

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/114830,2023,Cultural Sociology,Engels,Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,"['LB Brans, MSc', 'prof.dr. PPL Berkers']",,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

In recent decades, cultural sociology has been one of the fastest growing – yet fuzzily bounded – areas of sociological study. Some have even argued that contemporary sociology is witnessing a ‘cultural turn’ – making culture (‘meaning-making’ in a broad sense) a central aspect of sociological inquiry in many different areas, such as politics, economy, the state, etc. However, as ‘culture’ is difficult, if not impossible, to define, discussions often lack conceptual clarity, leading to truisms like ‘culture matters’.

This course addresses major theories and contemporary debates in cultural sociology. Besides discussing classical sociological traditions (Marx, Durkheim, Weber) and conceptions of culture, we will discern six ideal typical approaches in cultural sociology: (1) culture as an instrument of power (neo-Marxism and conflict sociology), (2) culture as (cognitive) structure (neo-Durkheimian sociology and structuralism), (3) culture as meaningful action (neo-Weberian sociology and rationalization), (4) culture as a product of social interaction (symbolic interactionism and ethnomethodology), (5) cultural as signification (semiotics) and (6) culture as embodied practice (practice and performance theory).

While most contemporary research usually draws on several of these approaches, we aim to provide a degree of intellectual clarity by disaggregating these traditions. Including both classical theories as well as related contemporary empirical studies, this course will stimulate systematic and critical sociological thinking, and provide a necessary compass to navigate current debates in cultural sociology. </body>

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
• Current theoretical insights, academic debates and approaches in the sociological thinking about culture

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/114666,2023,Cultural Sociology of Tourism,Engels,Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,"['N van Es, MA']",,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

This course is founded in a cultural sociological approach to the phenomenon of tourism, focusing on key concepts and theories which are relevant in the study of tourism as embedded in wider socio-cultural context in which they occur and acquire significance. First, the course will address both seminal theories as well as cutting-edge research on the historical development of tourism, paying particular attention to the underlying interests, activities and concerns which are attached to this phenomenon in its respective context. Moving from tourism and travel in pre-modernity, via the massification of tourism during modernity towards the contemporary nichification of tourism in postmodernity, the course will illuminate central issues related to the practice of tourism in relation to the particular ‘Zeitgeist’ in which it occurs. Second, the course will dive into the practices, motivations and experiences of the tourists themselves, scrutinizing the meanings that they attribute to their travels to and interactions with foreign locations and localities. Third, the destinations of tourists and locals will be of focus, particularly related to transformations of place, host-tourist relationships and issues related to sustainability, both in terms of preserving local culture, economy and the environment. Fourth, rising middle-classes in rapidly developing countries are increasingly having an impact on global tourism flows, resulting in a huge influx of tourists from a plethora of socio-cultural backgrounds, bringing in new opportunities, challenges and considerations. Last, the ever-increasing ubiquity of popular and digital media are brought in dialogue with contemporary and future tourism practices.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: The main aim of this course is to teach students the basics and fundamental knowledge from the field of tourism from a cultural sociological perspective. Through working with a combination of seminal works in this field as well as more state of the art research, students learn to analyze tourism and related practices within the wider socio-cultural and political contexts in which they occur. In doing so, students will be able to reproduce and contextualize important insights, theories and concepts related to a cultural sociological analysis of tourism. In addition, students will be able to critically and systematically analyse complex socio-cultural processes underlying the evolution of tourism in an age characterized by ongoing processes of globalization, mediation and digitization.

column1: <body>This course aims at providing students with the basic understanding of the functioning of cultural and creative industries. The lectures introduce the sociological and cultural economics perspectives on the functioning of “high arts” (e.g. contemporary visual art and theatre) and “popular” industries (e.g. film and television) and provide conceptual frameworks to better understand recent developments in cultural industries across sectors and cross-nationally. It deals with applying the theoretical knowledge to real empirical cases by discussing the recent issues and developments in specific cultural organizations or creative fields more generally. The knowledge on the functioning of creative industries offers a useful frame of reference for the remainder of the bachelor program. </body>

column1: <body>This course will analyze the cultural dimensions of international business communication, for instance, how various media platforms are adopted and perceived in distinct cultural contexts. Further, it will investigate how the latest innovations in interactive digital media can be utilized to enhance communication with users, which is vital for the success of multinational companies. An in-depth understanding of the interplay between culture and new media can lead to effective practices to achieve communicative goals in cross-cultural contexts. As part of this course, students will have the opportunity to conduct own research on how innovative, trendy media technology such as AI, VR, AR, games, robots, and social media transforms various businesses across cultural boundaries.</body>

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: What can superhero movies like Black Panther teach us about today’s society? Or series like the Handmaid’s Tale or Black Mirror? What is the cultural value of memes? And who decides what content is (allowed to be) shared via popular platforms like Instagram or Facebook? As a form of entertainment for the masses, popular culture (movies, series, music, social media, games etc.) has always played a key role in society. In this course, we approach popular culture beyond its entertainment function by paying close attention to both its content and its followers, the fans.

Often popular culture illustrates, reflects on, and helps to better understand the world we live in through representing or questioning societal changes that take place. In this seminar, we explore the interplay between popular culture, media entertainment, and fandom. We do so by examining topics ranging from meme culture to race, and gender to transnational pop culture.

Discussing different theories and popular culture topics each week, we address core questions like: Why and what ways do people engage with popular culture? How has and will popular culture help us understand societal changes?
This course should not be taken if you have already followed CM2232.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

• The relation between popular culture and societal changes.
• ·Critically assess and compare existing theories on popular culture and societal changes.
• ·Analyze and reflect upon popular cultural forms using concepts and theories covered in this course.
• ·Coherently present the discussed themes verbally (and visually) as well as in written assignments.

column1: The course will cover ten separate, but connected, topics in marketing. Each session will be taught by a different faculty (for questions about the overall course structure or other general matters, contact Christophe Lembregts, the course coordinator). The selection of topics is made by the marketing faculty based on their beliefs about what topics are currently the most timely and relevant in academic marketing research. Some sessions will deal with a relatively well-defined and limited range of issues. Others will cover broader ground, providing a primer to entire sub-fields. Most sessions will be directly related to the research conducted by the respective faculty member, so students are taught by world experts in the domain of every session. The combination of sessions should provide a high-level entry point into academic marketing research.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: The main goal of the course is to familiarize students with key areas of marketing research as well as with different methodological approaches that are influential in marketing. Thus, the course will cover a wide variety of topics and perspectives, spanning consumer behavior, marketing strategy, and quantitative marketing topics. The broad set of topics and methods reflects the diversity of marketing research. You are not expected to pursue research in all of these areas in the future. Rather, we would like the course to help you understand the field and form a clearer idea of what area might be most suitable for you.

The course also serves two additional goals: introducing students to RSM marketing faculty and introducing faculty to students. Our hope is that this course will offer a useful platform on which students can build to develop a successful line of research during their time at ERIM, by exposing them early on to the research carried out at the RSM marketing department and by facilitating interactions between students and faculty and thereby increasing the likelihood of collaborations.</body>

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: The emergence of information and data technologies, together with the sophistication of tools in econometrics and machine learning, have led to a radical shift in the way marketing operations are run. The focus of companies has been shifted away from product-centric approaches and mass marketing campaigns to customer-centric campaigns tailored to the needs and wants of each individual customer. Such campaigns target a well-chosen subset of customers, at a well-chosen time, and with a well-chosen incentive. At their core, they require strong data analytics tools to be able to predict each customer’s behavior and derive optimal marketing interventions.

This elective will provide students with the necessary knowledge and skills to tackle these challenges. The course will focus as much on the managerial questions as well as on the use of methodologies to address these questions. The elective will be articulated around the core metric of Customer Lifetime Value (CLV). We will especially focus on customer-centric tactics firms can use to:

column2: Enhance customer acquisition (e.g., customer referral programs, seeding strategies)
Boost customer spending (e.g., loyalty schemes, customer engagement)

column1: To address these challenges, we will use state-of-the-art machine learning methods, including boosting, uplift models, decision trees, etc. Finally, we use rely heavily on the notion of A/B testing and randomized control trials to optimize personalized interventions of firms.

Attendance to the regular lectures is not compulsory but strongly encouraged. All the material discussed during the sessions is part of the knowledge students need to acquire to pass the course successfully.
Attendance to the case discussions is compulsory and participation during the discussion will be graded.
If you are facing a difficult situation, I would like to ask you to contact me and/or your study advisor as soon as possible to discuss the best way to address it.

• Possess a good expertise of companies’ best practices in the domain of customer analytics, and think critically about them
• Transform ill-defined problems into relevant research problems
• Understand, explain, and apply the latest research in the area of customer analytics
• Understand and explain key customer analytics tools companies have at their disposal to develop customer-centric strategies
• Manipulate and do data analyses using customer analytics tools using the R programming language (via tutorials) and predict key customer behavioral outcomes
• Provide and justify concrete managerial recommendations to non-technical audiences through the creation of (online) presentations and written reports

column1: The emergence of information and data technologies has led to a radical shift in how marketing operations are run. The focus of companies has been shifted away from product-centric approaches and mass marketing campaigns to customer-centric campaigns tailored to the needs and wants of each customer. Customer-centric marketing campaigns target a well-chosen subset of customers at a well-chosen time and with a well-chosen incentive. Moreover, they also require good monitoring of their impacts on firms’ profits. In other words, a customer-centric campaign requires companies to answer four key questions:

Customer-centric marketing can be applied to any marketing domain and, so, is an approach that multinationals can broadly adopt. In this course, we will focus on the three key marketing tasks related to the stages of a customer life cycle: customer acquisition, customer development, and customer retention.

The course will focus as much on the managerial questions and challenges and the use of methods to address these questions. This elective will be articulated around the customer lifecycle and rely on the core metric of Customer Lifetime Value (CLV).

Attendance is partially compulsory. Attendance to the regular lectures is desired but not compulsory. Attendance to the discussions of the business cases is compulsory and participation will be graded.

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/116783,2023,Customer Experience Management,Engels,Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,['dr. CJP Lembregts'],,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: How can companies gain and sustain competitive advantage in an increasingly competitive environment? In recent years, companies have realized that a crucial source of competitive advantage lies in the provision of a compelling customer experience. Customer experience is comprised of all cognitive, affective, sensory, and motivational elements that mark the customer’s interactions with companies or other market actors (adapted from De Keyser et al. 2020). Due to the rapid rise of digital and mobile devices, customers are increasingly valuing seamless experiences. In response, leading companies have decided to hire so-called “customer experience managers” to improve their customer experiences. This course discusses the general determinants of great customer experiences across all touch points (prior, during and after purchase) and introduces methods to improve customer experiences.
Attendance is strongly recommended, but not mandatory.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
• Understand and explain the importance of a positive customer experience management for business
• Recognize, understand and explain the determinants of positive customer experiences
• Analyze companies’ customer experiences and identify strengths and weaknesses
• Understand and apply methods and techniques to improve make positive improvements to customer experiences

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: The course “Data Engineering & Management” will teach students the fundamentals of data collection, management and visualization. Students will become proficient in collecting data from various sources (e.g. web scraping), merging data from different files, and visualizing the information content in dynamic reports. This course lays the foundation for the subsequent courses in the second block of the Analytic Decision Makers Track.

Today’s data analysts need to access data from a wide range of resources, merge data from various resources, clean, annotate, and analyze them using various methods, and present their findings in a convincing manner. The above Figure represents the steps and their connections in a typical data analytics framework. The course introduces predecessor and successor steps to data analysis, hence laying a foundation to subsequent courses.
The course is structured around a brief introduction to three fundamental steps in this framework:

·       Import: First, data needs to be collected. The course introduces how to collect and integrate data from various sources and import them into a framework where we can examine them. In addition, the course will provide a brief introduction to using APIs for collecting data from the Web.
·       Manipulate: Cleaning up and organizing data is an indispensable part of any data management framework. The course introduces principles of organizing, tidying up and manipulating data.
Often, data analytics require working with multiple sources of information. The course introduces forming associations between multiple data sources.

·       Communicate: Data visualization is a fundamental method for reaching to conclusions and communicating our findings. The course introduces advanced visualization techniques using programming languages.

column2: • Learn how to discover, collect, organize and store data
• Use tidy data principles to analyze, manage, transform, and merge data
• Learn how to visualize data and results of analysis
• Understand practical applications of data management frameworks

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/112039,2023,Data Management & Ethics,Engels,Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,"['C Wan, MA', 'dr. A Priante', 'prof.dr. DGJ Bongaerts']",,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Data is a key business resource. Web stores such as Amazon or Coolblue use customer data to dispatch purchased products and to make recommendations of new products; banking service providers such as ING or HSBC use data for processing cash and ATM transactions and for assessing a client’s credit worthiness; manufacturers such as BMW and Tesla use data to design and produce cars and to propel self-driving cars. Often, this data is spread within the organization through multiple information systems. In order for organizations to operate successfully, they need to be able to use, access and share data. Data management is the field is the practice of organizing, sharing and accessing data to support productivity, efficiency, and decision-making.

This course introduces data management topics such as database design, data preparation, manipulation, modeling, alongside with discussions on ethical and privacy issues related to data. Furthermore, students will learn how to apply SQL methods for managing data, querying and reporting.

In addition, the course provides an introduction to blockchain, which is a new and atypical way of organizing data. This type of data solution arose in the wake of the global financial crisis of 2007-2009 with the introduction of Bitcoin, the first cryptocurrency. Ever since, there has been an enormous growth in different types of blockchain based business solutions, some of them meaningful, some of them not. We discuss the basic design, logic and economic incentives underlying the blockchain technology, and discuss real-life applications, hypes and scandals.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

• Develop a critical understanding of and ability to apply data management topics, such as data management plan frameworks, database design and data structures, data preparation, data quality, and data modeling.
• Learn and apply SQL methods for managing data, querying and reporting.
• Understand, discuss and critically analyze ethical and privacy issues related to data.
• Understand, describe and discuss the technical design, economic incentives, and potential applications of blockchain.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: The advances in information technologies in the past decade have led to unprecedented digitalization. These technologies have also made it easier for digital businesses to collect, store, and use the personal data of consumers. The high value associated with personal data also creates incentives for adversaries to attack management information systems. Therefore, in the surveillance economy that we live in, invasion of privacy and cyberthreats are arguably some of the critical issues faced by digital businesses.

This course draws on the economics of privacy and is designed to introduce fundamental concepts related to data privacy and cybersecurity. Students will be exposed to privacy and security issues associated with new technologies in social media, cloud computing, smart cities, and artificial intelligence.
While attendance is not mandatory, students are strongly encouraged to attend the session to meet the learning goals.
Note: Without attending the guest sessions, students will not be able to submit guest reports.

• Explain the tradeoffs between privacy and technological convenience
• Explain the economics of privacy and security
• Identify various types of cyberattacks and evaluate mitigation strategies

column1: This course addresses the broader societal and organizational context in which data scientists operate. The course is structured according to three levels of analysis: Data science in society, Data science in organizations, and Data science as a personal responsibility. Each level is covered in related lectures that draw on academic papers and recent developments in practice. Data science in society addresses topics such as the impact of data science on market competition, potential discrimination, and data protection and privacy. Data science in organizations addresses topics such as the impact of data science on firm business models, new business development, and organizational practices. Data science as a personal responsibility addresses individual decisions and responsibilities regarding data management, ethics, and privacy protection. Besides an exam, students also complete team assignments related to one of the topics from the course.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
• Students will develop a better understanding of the role and impact of data science in society and in organizations.
• Students will develop a better understanding of their personal responsibilities regarding data science practices such as data management, ethics, and drawing conclusions from analyses.

• Students practice how to analyze real-world societal or organizational debates relevant to data science. They practice how to use academic research to develop an informed position in such debates and to provide management advice on a course of action for organizations.
• Students practice team report writing and communication skills.

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/115983,2023,Data analysis with Matlab/Advanced,Engels,Faculteit der Geneeskunde en Gezondheidswetenschappen (Erasmus MC),,['E. Buitenhuis - Linssen', 'L.M.R. Nijs - de Langen', 'P. Bremen']",,

In this course we focus on the most popular database model, namely the relational model. First relational databases are introduced, followed by formal languages for querying as relational algebra, tuple relational calculus, and domain relational calculus. Then, the entity-relationship diagram (ERD) is presented as a high-level abstraction of the modeled world. After that, the Structured Query Language (SQL), one of the most used query languages, is described. Last, the normalization theory employed for designing relational databases is given.

In order to better assimilate the topics covered during lectures, the students will work in teams on several assignments on the discussed topics. The students will also write a report describing the proposed solutions.

column2: • Knowledge and understanding of: the entity-relationship diagram (ERD), what is a relational database, how to query a relational database using the Structured Query Language (SQL), and how to design a relational database.
• Be able to design and query relational databases.
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/111247,2023,De Professionele School,Nederlands,Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences,,['dr. LAL de Meijer'],,Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Een professionele school wordt geleid door een uitstekende schoolleider die instructioneel en transformationeel leiderschap toont. Deze schoolleider richt zich op het leren van en lesgeven aan leerlingen, is duidelijk in zijn of haar doelen en betrekt docenten bij veranderingsprocessen. In een professionele school zijn de docenten excellent en blijven zich continu ontwikkelen. Maar het belangrijkste is dat professionele scholen erin slagen al hun leerlingen te stimuleren en te ondersteunen om zich te ontwikkelen en optimaal te presteren.

Het ondersteunen van professionele capaciteit kan worden gezien als een van de fundamenten van schoolverbetering. Professionele capaciteit omvat de kwaliteit van het personeel (leraren en schoolleiders), de kwaliteit van hun professionele ontwikkelingsactiviteiten en hun vermogen om met elkaar en andere professionals samen te werken en te werken aan gemeenschappelijke doelen van lesgeven en leren. Deze samenwerking kan plaatsvinden in zogenaamde professionele gemeenschappen die zich kenmerken door bijvoorbeeld een focus op het leren van leerlingen, gedeelde waarden en doelen, en een gemeenschappelijk verantwoordelijkheidsgevoel voor het succes van de school. De focus van deze module zal liggen op de kenmerken van professionele scholen. De module behandelt de volgende vier onderwerpen: kwaliteit van de leraar, leiderschap in de school, de school als lerende organisatie (inclusief de rol van onderzoek) en schoolontwikkeling in grootstedelijke context.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Following completion of this module, students are expected to be able to do each of the following:

column2: • Describe the main theories and models on professional capacity in schools, in general as well as in urban settings;
• Evaluate the effectiveness of these theories and models on professional capacity?;
• Describe the main forms of continuous professional development, in general as well as in urban settings, and their underlying theories;
• Evaluate the effectiveness of the main forms of continuous professional development.

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/110131,2023,De Sociologische Blik,Nederlands,Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences,,['dr. AS Leerkes'],,Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: De opleiding Sociologie is gericht op de intellectuele en beroepsmatige interesses van studenten die belangstelling hebben voor wat er gebeurt in de samenleving én in de eigen interacties met anderen. Sociologie biedt niet alleen een grote rijkdom aan theoretische inzichten en onderzoeksresultaten; wie de sociologie bestudeert verwerft specifieke manieren van kijken naar de wisselwerking tussen mens en maatschappij.  Sociologische kennis en vaardigheden zijn nuttig bij tal van beroepen en dragen bij aan persoonlijke groei.

In deze minor verbreed je je blikveld en bestudeer je de hoofdvragen van de sociologie (sociale cohesie, identiteit, sociale ongelijkheid en sociale verandering) aan de hand van actuele vraagstukken rondom onder meer cultuur, individualisering, criminaliteit, sociale ongelijkheid in het onderwijs en de arbeidsmarkt, gender, godsdienst en groepsidentiteiten. Daarbij leer je belangrijke sociologische perspectieven te hanteren (zoals het functionalisme, conflictsociologie, symbolisch-interactionisme en de rationele keuze benadering).

De minor heeft ook een verdiepend karakter: je kunt een invloedrijk sociologisch werk bestuderen dat betrekking heeft op, of raakt aan, je eigen vakgebied, waaronder psychologie, pedagogiek, rechten, bedrijfskunde, geneeskunde, bouwkunde, geschiedenis, media- en cultuurwetenschappen en filosofie.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: <body>Na succesvol afronden van de minor, kunnen studenten:

column2: • De grondleggers en basisbegrippen van de sociologie benoemen en uitleggen;

• Belangrijke theoretische perspectieven in de sociologie beschrijven en gebruiken bij het analyseren van vraagstukken rond modernisering, cohesie, ongelijkheid en identiteit (de vier hoofdvragen van de sociologie);
• De centrale beginselen in sociologische sleutelteksten begrijpen en uitleggen;
• Prominente sociologische theorieën rondom cohesie, identiteit, ongelijkheid en sociale verandering (waaronder modernisering) toepassen op hedendaagse maatschappelijke vraagstukken;
• Hedendaagse maatschappelijke verschijnselen gebruiken om sociologische theorieën en empirisch onderzoek te reproduceren, contextualiseren en bekritiseren.
• Uitleggen hoe sociologen aankijken tegen een of meerdere verschijnselen of theorieën die in de eigen wetenschappelijke discipline centraal staan, of aan die discipline raken.
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Studenten met een Bachelordiploma die deze minor met succes hebben afgerond verkrijgen daarmee toegang tot een Master-opleiding in de Sociologie (waaronder Grootstedelijke vraagstukken en beleid; Arbeid, Organisatie en Management; Governance of Migration & Diversity; Politics & Society; Engaging Public Issues; Social Inequalities), mits ze voldoende kennis van sociaalwetenschappelijke methoden kunnen aantonen.

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/114016,2023,De beursvennootschap in het financieel toezichtsrecht,Nederlands,Erasmus School of Law,,['mr.drs. ACW Pijls', 'SB Garcia Nelen, LL.M']",,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: In het vak komen drie kernthema’s aan bod. Deze kernthema’s zijn:
A. Het financieel toezichtrecht, de beursgang en het prospectus;
B. Marktmisbruik + publicatie- en meldingsverplichtingen van de beursvennootschap, haar aandeelhouders en haar bestuurders en commissarissen + het openbaar bod;
C. De aansprakelijkheid van de beursvennootschap en haar bestuurders wegens misleiding van het beleggende publiek.
Elk kernthema wordt in een aantal colleges uitgediept, waarbij zoveel mogelijk interactief college wordt gegeven en actuele ontwikkelingen worden besproken.</body>

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
• De student is in staat de belangrijkste voor- en nadelen van een beursnotering uiteen te zetten en kan hierover in concrete casus een juridisch gefundeerd advies uitbrengen.

• De student is in staat te beargumenteren waarom in het kader van een beursgang een prospectus moet worden gepubliceerd en kan tevens beredeneren aan welke inhoudelijke vereisten dit prospectus dient te voldoen.

• De student heeft inzicht in het gehele proces rondom een beursgang en in de rol van alle daarbij betrokken partijen en tevens is de student in staat de belangrijkste (deel)fases in dit proces, zoals het due diligence-onderzoek en het bookbuilding-proces, te beschrijven en hierover te adviseren.

• De student is bekend met en heeft inzicht in de belangrijkste publicatieverplichtingen van de beursvennootschap en is bekend met en heeft inzicht in de belangrijkste meldingsverplichtingen van de beursvennootschap, haar aandeelhouders en andere aan de vennootschap gelieerde (rechts)personen.
• De student heeft inzicht in het gehele proces rondom een openbaar bod en tevens is de student in staat de belangrijkste (deel)fases in dit proces te beschrijven en hierover te adviseren.

• De student is in staat te beoordelen en te beargumenteren wanneer sprake is van wederrechtelijke handel met voorwetenschap en kan tevens beredeneren wat de doelstelling is van het verbod tot handel met voorwetenschap.

• De student is in staat te beoordelen en te beargumenteren wanneer bepaalde informatie als ”voorwetenschap” dient te worden aangemerkt en kan tevens beoordelen en beargumenteren wanneer sprake is van marktmanipulatie.

• De student heeft inzicht in het leerstuk van prospectusaansprakelijkheid en is tevens in staat in concrete casus te beoordelen en te beargumenteren of een (mededeling in het) prospectus al dan niet misleidend is.
• De student heeft inzicht in de aansprakelijkheid van de beursvennootschap en haar bestuurders wegens het niet publiceren van voorwetenschap en/of het overtreden van het marktmanipulatieverbod.

• De student heeft inzicht in de aansprakelijkheid van de beursvennootschap en haar bestuurders wegens het publiceren van misleidende financiële verslaggeving en is daarnaast in staat in concrete casus te beoordelen en te beargumenteren of een gepubliceerde jaarrekening al dan niet misleidend is.
• In algemene zin heeft de student inzicht in de belangrijkste op de beursvennootschap van toepassing zijnde (Europese en nationale) effectenrechtelijke wet- en regelgeving.

• De student kan zelfstandig zowel Nederlands- als Engelstalige wetenschappelijke artikelen over onderwerpen die behoren tot het domein van de beursvennootschap bestuderen, analyseren, beoordelen en daarop kritisch reflecteren.

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/111183,2023,De complexe en diverse pedagogische praktijk,Nederlands,Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences,,['dr. AP Ringoot', 'dr. M Zee', 'M Looijen']",,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: De pedagogische praktijk is breed en omvat onder meer het onderwijs, de jeugdhulp, gehandicaptenzorg, de (preventieve) opvoedondersteuning en de geestelijke gezondheidszorg. Pedagogische vraagstukken die hier spelen zijn bijvoorbeeld: ‘Hoe zorg je ervoor dat ieder kind, ongeacht achtergrond en talent en vanuit zijn of haar individuele behoeften, passend onderwijs en zorg krijgt?’ En ‘hoe vergroot je de betrokkenheid van opvoeders bij het onderwijs van hun kind?’ Deze vraagstukken kenmerken zich vaak door (a) complexiteit en (b) diversiteit. Bij het zoeken naar mogelijke oplossingen voor deze vraagstukken dienen we daarom met verschillende factoren rekening te houden waaronder: hoe de verschillende systemen rondom een kind (school, gezin, wijk) met elkaar samenhangen; met ethische en juridische kaders; met persoonlijke opvattingen en overtuigingen van gezinnen; met onze eigen normen, waarden, (voor)oordelen en bias/vertekeningen en met het feit dat geen kind, opvoeder of gezin hetzelfde is. In dit vak ga je aan de slag met actuele pedagogische vraagstukken en leer je om een wetenschappelijk advies te formuleren waarbij je handelt volgens de beroepscode van pedagogen en onderwijswetenschappers, en je rekening houdt met juridische en ethische kaders. Daarnaast leer je kritisch te reflecteren op jezelf en je eigen rol als pedagogisch professional.
De beroepscode en juridische en ethische vaardigheden

(Ortho)pedagogen en onderwijswetenschappers werken volgens de beroepscode en binnen juridische en ethische kaders. Jullie zullen in het vak ‘De complexe en diverse pedagogische praktijk’ gaan werken aan    juridisch-pedagogische en beroepsethische vraagstukken waar (ortho)pedagogen en onderwijswetenschappers mee te maken kunnen krijgen, om later verantwoord jullie beroep uit te kunnen oefenen. Enerzijds bieden we in dit vak kennis over de juridische aspecten rondom ouderschap, zoals ouderlijk gezag, juridisch ouderschap, kinderbeschermingsmaatregelen, jeugdhulprecht en jeugdstrafrecht. Anderzijds gaan jullie als studenten oefenen met het gebruiken en interpreteren van juridische teksten om de juiste beslissing te nemen bij juridische en beroepsethische dilemma’s. Juridische teksten die aan bod komen zijn onder andere de Meldcode Kindermishandeling van de Nederlandse Vereniging van Pedagogen en Onderwijskundigen (NVO) en relevante delen uit het Burgerlijk Wetboek, het Wetboek van Strafrecht en de Jeugdwet. Om later verantwoord het beroep van pedagogisch wetenschapper en onderwijswetenschapper uit te kunnen oefenen bieden we ook ethische basiskennis, zoals ethische basisbegrippen, normatieve theorieën, beroeps- en onderzoeksethiek. Jullie gaan ook oefenen met het toepassen van deze basiskennis op verschillende actuele casussen.
Professionele vorming als toekomstig pedagogisch wetenschapper en onderwijswetenschapper

Gedurende de opleiding Pedagogische Wetenschappen in Rotterdam leiden wij pedagogisch wetenschappers en onderwijswetenschappers op voor de grootstedelijke context. Naast dat jullie kennis verwerven over diversiteit, verschillen, en (on)gelijkheid, ontwikkelen jullie competenties die je nodig hebt als pedagogisch wetenschapper en onderwijswetenschapper om kansengelijkheid te kunnen bevorderen. Het is daarom essentieel dat jullie inzicht hebben in en jullie bewust zijn van jullie eigen normen, waarden, vooroordelen, visie en competenties (i.e. het handelen). In het vak ‘de complexe en diverse pedagogische praktijk’ besteden we naast kennis daarom ook veel aandacht aan jullie ontwikkeling als professional, waaronder inzicht in jullie eigen normen, waarden, vooroordelen, visie en vaardigheden als samenwerken met diverse mensen, het op een opbouwende manier kunnen geven en ontvangen van feedback en reflecteren op je eigen kennis en vaardigheden. We doen dit tijdens werkcolleges en kleinschalige workshops.</body>

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Aan het einde van deze module zijn studenten in staat om:

column2: • kennis te reproduceren over wat voor een (ortho)pedagoog belangrijke juridische en beroepsethische kwesties zijn
• juridische bronnen te gebruiken en te interpreteren voor juridische en beroepsethische kwesties in de (ortho)pedagogische praktijk
• de beroepscode voor pedagogen en Nederlandse wetgeving toe te passen op (ortho)pedagogische casussen
• te reflecteren op voor een pedagoog belangrijke beroepsethische kwesties
• de handelingswijze bij beroepsethische kwesties te beargumenteren, gebruikmakend van een wetenschappelijke schrijfstijl
• te beschrijven hoe de structuur van het (ortho)pedagogische en onderwijs werkveld is vormgegeven
• de identiteit en werkwijzen van het (ortho)pedagogische en onderwijs werkveld te beschrijven en beschouwen vanuit een vergelijkend perspectief
• de complexiteit van grootstedelijke vraagstukken op het gebied van opvoeding, ontwikkeling en/of onderwijs te begrijpen en analyseren

• te reflecteren op de complexiteit van pedagogische vraagstukken door middel van het schrijven van een op wetenschappelijke literatuur gebaseerd advies, waarbij rekening gehouden wordt met diversiteit, verschillen, en (on)gelijkheid
• inzicht te krijgen in en te reflecteren op eigen stereotypen en vooroordelen
• op respectvolle wijze samen te werken en te communiceren met medestudenten met diverse achtergronden
• inzicht te krijgen in de eigen visie, normen en waarden als pedagogisch professional
• op een opbouwende professionele feedback te geven aan en te ontvangen van medestudenten en docenten

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/115902,2023,De historisering van het wereldbeeld in de negentiende eeuw I,Nederlands,Erasmus School of Philosophy,,['dr. B Leeuwenburgh', 'J van der Klaauw, MA']",,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: De filosofie van Immanuel Kant (1724-1804) wordt gezien als het hoogtepunt en het einde van de verlichtingsperiode. Via zijn drie kritische werken definieert Kant een dualisme van het subject (voor zich) en object (op zich) met de radicale conclusie dat het op zich – de ‘dingen zoals ze zijn’ – niet waarneembaar is. Wij nemen altijd dingen waar zoals ze aan ons verschijnen (voor zich). Het subject is dus bepalend voor het object. Daarnaast zien we ook dat Kant de geschiedenis voor het eerst als een leerproces opvat, met als doel de menselijke bevrijding via emancipatie, vandaar zijn beroemde slagzin durf te denken (sapere aude).

Op basis van de problematiek die Kant in zijn kritische filosofie aansneed ontwikkelt het Duitse idealisme zich eind 18e en begin 19e eeuw. In deze cursus behandelen we eerst kort de filosofie van Kant die het startschot is van wat wij ‘de historisering van het wereldbeeld’ noemen. Vervolgens zien we hoe drie belangrijke Duitse denkers allen worstelen met de problematiek van Kant. Johann Gottlieb Fichte (1762-1814) en Friedrich Wilhelm Joseph Schelling (1775-1854) komen elk met een eigen reactie, Fichte met een wetenschapsfilosofie en Schelling met een natuurfilosofie. Vervolgens is het Georg Wilhelm Friedrich Hegel (1770-1831) die de filosofie een volledig nieuwe wending geeft. Het leerproces van Kant is voor Hegel niet slechts een persoonlijk mechanisme, maar is gekoppeld aan de ontwikkeling van de wereld als geheel. Het is via het denken van de mens, wat Hegel zal noemen de geest (Geist), dat de wereld zijn eigen ontwikkeling waarneemt en emancipatie mogelijk maakt.

Hegel is een laatbloeier en wordt pas in de jaren ’20 van de 19e eeuw echt bepalend. Zijn volgelingen vallen uiteen in oud- of rechtshegelianen en jong- of linkshegelianen. Waar de rechtshegelianen Hegels woord als een nieuwe waarheid percipiëren, werken de linkshegelianen meer in de geest van Hegel. Onder die laatste groep vallen ook Ludwig Feuerbach (1804-1872) en zijn latere ‘leerling’ Karl Marx (1818-1883). Omdat zij vinden dat Hegels filosofie te religieus en te behoudend is, zullen zij met de door Hegel ontwikkelde begrippen en mechanismen een nieuwe filosofie ontwikkelen.

Ten slotte sluiten we af met twee stromingen die parallel in het begin van de negentiende eeuw opkomen, maar ook kunnen worden gezien als een reactie op Hegel, namelijk het ontologische verankerde pessismisme van Arthur Schopenhauer (1788-1860) en het vroege existentialisme van Søren Kierkegaard (1813-1855).

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
• Heeft de student een overzicht van de ontwikkeling van de geschiedenis van de wijsbegeerte in de eerste helft van de negentiende eeuw, te beginnen bij Kant.
• Is de student in staat het verband te leggen tussen politieke en wetenschappelijke ontwikkelingen aan de ene en de wijsgerige ontwikkelingen aan de andere kant.
• Heeft de student kennisgemaakt met belangrijke primaire teksten van Fichte, Schelling, Hegel en Schopenhauer.
• Heeft de student praktische vaardigheid opgedaan met het interpreteren van deze filosofische teksten.
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/115903,2023,De historisering van het wereldbeeld in de negentiende eeuw II,Nederlands,Erasmus School of Philosophy,,['dr. B Leeuwenburgh', 'prof.dr. AAGM van Raak']",,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: In de cursus ‘Negentiende Eeuw II’ wordt inhoudelijk voortgebouwd op de ideeënhistorische context, de filosofische stromingen, ontwikkelingen en debatten die in de cursus ‘Negentiende Eeuw I’ zijn geïntroduceerd. Hierbij worden de volgende thema’s in chronologische volgorde en in hun onderlinge samenhang behandeld.

Ten eerste de opkomst van het vooruitgangsdenken in Frankrijk, Engeland, Nederland en de Verenigde Staten, waarbij achtereenvolgens aandacht wordt besteed aan de ideeënontwikkeling van de grondlegger van het positivisme, Auguste Comte (1798-1857), de bloei van het utilitarisme in Engeland, zoals in gang gezet door Jeremy Bentham (1748-1832) en verder uitgebouwd door John Stuart Mill (1806-1873), de unieke ‘ervaringswijsbegeerte’ van Cornelis Willem Opzoomer (1821-1892) en het Amerikaanse pragmatisme van Charles Sanders Peirce (1839-1914) en William James (1842-1910).

De invloedrijke theorie van natuurlijke selectie van de ‘philosophical naturalist’ Charles Darwin (1809-1882) staat in de tweede week centraal, zij het ruim ingebed in het bredere debat over evolutie en de positie van de mens in de natuur, waarbij ook dieper wordt ingegaan op de ideeënontwikkeling van de eerste darwinisten en sociaal-darwinisten.

In de periode waarin Darwin zijn theorie ontwikkelde worden ook de eerste contouren zichtbaar van een nieuwe filosofische discipline: wetenschapsfilosofie. Hoe zich dat proces voltrok middels baanbrekende publicaties van John Herschel (1792-1871), William Whewell (1794-1866) en John Stuart Mill vormt het eerste thema. Het tweede thema in deze derde week is geheel gewijd aan het in politiek-maatschappelijk opzicht uiterst invloedrijke historisch materialisme van Karl Marx (1818-1883).

In de laatste week wordt de hernieuwde interesse voor de filosofie van Benedictus de Spinoza (1632-1677), met name in kringen van vrijdenkers in Nederland, nader onder de loep genomen en wordt afgesloten met de ‘Umwertung aller Werte’ van Friedrich Nietzsche (1844-1900), wiens invloed zich in de loop van de twintigste eeuw steeds sterker deed gelden.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: 1. Beschrijven van de belangrijkste filosofische stromingen in het Negentiende-Eeuwse Engeland, Frankrijk, Duitsland en Nederland.

2. Uitleggen van de filosofische begrippen die de inhoudelijke filosofische discussie in de negentiende eeuw kenschetsen. Voorbeelden van begrippen zijn onder andere neo - Kantianisme, idealisme, vooruitgangsoptimisme, positivisme, uniformitarianisme, transcendentalisme etc.
3. Leren samenvatten middels het maken van collegedictaat.
4. Het schriftelijk logisch onderbouwen van een eigen filosofische stellingname ter voorbereiding op een werkcollege.
5. Het schriftelijk evalueren van een eerder ingenomen filosofische stellingname (zie 4) ter voorbereiding op een werkcollege.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Deze cursus biedt de studenten kennis over twee stromingen in de psychologie die belangrijk zijn om gedrag van kinderen, adolescenten en jongvolwassenen te verklaren, namelijk de ontwikkelingspsychologie en persoonlijkheidsleer.

Er wordt kennis opgedaan over de belangrijkste veranderingen in de ontwikkeling die plaatsvinden van conceptie tot en met jong-volwassenheid (0-23 jaar), waarbij de klassieke en hedendaagse ontwikkelingspsychologische theorieën en wetenschappelijke studies bestudeerd worden om de cognitieve ontwikkeling, sociale-emotionele ontwikkeling, morele ontwikkeling, ontwikkelingen in motoriek en gedrag te begrijpen.

Naast bekende ontwikkelingspsychologische theorieën, biedt deze cursus de studenten kennis over de belangrijkste theorieën, visies en wetenschappelijke studies over individuele verschillen van mensen in persoonlijkheid en intelligentie.

Deze kennis is belangrijk voor toekomstig pedagogisch wetenschappers en onderwijswetenschappers om ontwikkeling en gedrag van kinderen, adolescenten, jongvolwassenen en volwassenen te kunnen duiden en verklaren en voorspellen. De cursus biedt daarnaast kennis over sociale identiteit en de ontwikkeling ervan bij kinderen, jongeren en jongvolwassenen.</body>

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Aan het einde van de cursus zijn studenten in staat om:
1. De belangrijkste klassieke en hedendaagse psychologische theorieën van de voornaamste ontwikkelingsdomeinen te onderscheiden, kritisch te beschouwen en toe te passen.
2. De stadia van beïnvloedende factoren op en hersenontwikkeling gedurende de pre-, peri- en postnatale ontwikkeling te beschrijven.

3. De voornaamste mijlpalen in de cognitieve ontwikkeling, taalontwikkeling, sociaal-emotionele ontwikkeling, morele ontwikkeling, en (gender)identiteitsontwikkeling gedurende 0-23 jaar te onderscheiden, kritisch te beschouwen en toe te passen.

4. De belangrijkste psychologische verklaringen voor het ontstaan en in stand houden van individuele verschillen op het gebied van persoonlijkheid, intelligentie, motivatie en identiteitsvorming, te onderscheiden, kritisch te beschouwen en toe te passen.

5. De externe en interne gerelateerde factoren op ontwikkeling en gedrag m.b.t. de voornaamste ontwikkelingsdomeinen en individuele verschillen te beschrijven en onderzoek hierover te kunnen evalueren.
6. De factoren en relaties tussen individuele verschillen in de psychologische ontwikkeling en kansen(on)gelijkheid in de samenleving te onderscheiden en kritisch te beschouwen.

7. De belangrijkste meetinstrumenten (zoals vragenlijsten en observatiemethoden) voor de voornaamste ontwikkelingsdomeinen in de verschillende ontwikkelingsfasen te herkennen en de inzet ervan kritisch te beschouwen.
Aan het einde van de cursus zijn studenten in staat om:
8. Een gepaste en ethisch verantwoorde basisattitude aan te nemen als pedagoog of onderwijswetenschapper in contact met een kind of jongere.
9. Een gesprek te voeren met een kind of jongere waarbij op adequate wijze gebruik wordt gemaakt van basisgespreksvaardigheden.
10. Een psychologisch instrument af te nemen bij een kind of jongere aan de hand van gerichte instructie en begeleiding.
11. De resultaten van de testafname op een wetenschappelijk verantwoorde en genuanceerde manier te analyseren, interpreteren en rapporteren.
12. Een medestudent die gespreks- en testleider is, op een gestructureerde wijze te observeren.
13. Op basis van observatie heldere peerfeedback te geven aan een medestudent over de professionele houding en prestaties als gespreks- en testleider, alsmede zelf feedback te ontvangen.
14. Te reflecteren op de eigen prestatie als gespreksleider en testleider en o.b.v. deze zelfreflectie en de ontvangen (peer)feedback concrete leerdoelen te formuleren.
