column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Diversity comes in many shapes and forms and has become a key notion in societal and scholarly debates. In media studies questions on diversity are usually geared towards gender, ethnicity and sexuality, and more recently also towards age and disability. Not only how diversity is present in media products but also effects of (not-so) diverse media content on the audiences in general and society at large are topic of investigation and often form the core of heated debates. For example, while some consider Beyoncé as a feminist role model who resists the stereotype of white, heterosexual femininity, others vigorously argue that Beyoncé re-emphasizes this stereotype.  In this seminar, the production, representation and consumption of diversity are explored. To do so, concepts such as ‘stereotype’ and ‘diversity’ are critically scrutinized for their meaning and value in relation to media. Gender, ethnicity, and sexuality will be understood as intersectional - in relation to one another and interdependent. Last but not least, popular culture and advertising take a central place, as these highly visual media are thought to contribute most to contemporary society’s imaginations of diversity.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Students have advanced their knowledge, understanding and awareness of:

column2: • diversity in popular culture and advertising in general, and specifically of diversity in gender, ethnicity and sexuality.
• the cultural and historical development of the concept of diversity in academic research.
• current questions and issues of diversity in popular culture and advertising.
• critically examine and evaluate diversity in contemporary popular culture and advertising.
• formulate their thoughts and views on diversity in an academically sound research paper.

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/112632,2023,Doing Business Strategically with China,Engels,Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,['dr. S Liu'],,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: China's economic growth over the past 40 years is unprecedented in terms of its rapidity. While factors such as foreign investment and education have contributed to this growth, as they have in other leading economies, China's ascent also hinges on unique elements, including its market structure. Consequently, China, with its vast market size and formidable manufacturing prowess, has garnered the attention of global managers. Yet, many of these international professionals find it challenging to navigate Chinese business practices based on their Western experience. This is because China's market dynamics and its approach to innovation and entrepreneurship diverge from those in many other countries. This course will delve into business strategies and practices tailored for the distinct Chinese market.
Attendance is mandatory and each student is allowed to miss class only once. Please also communicate this with the other members of your group.</body>

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
• Understand the driving factors and uniqueness of China’s economic growth
• Understand the Chinese market and the Chinese way of innovation and entrepreneurship
• Understand how firms could survive and grow in the Chinese market

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/114359,2023,Doing Research in IMARC,Engels,Erasmus School of Law,,['AI Marzouk', 'dr. A Bouabid', 'JM de Dood, MSc']",,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: This course introduces you to various aspects of doing research on border crossing, security and social justice. The aim of this course is to help you explore cross-cultural research topics and epistemologies and to develop skills to write a basic research proposal. With various guest lecturers we will look in-depth at the socio-political and criminological relevance of the core IMARC themes, the value of critical and cultural criminological approaches, and the involvement of important national and international actors in these fields. These guest lecturers are researchers who have experience with doing research in an international setting. You can ask questions, pitch ideas, discuss doubts and ask for advice.
You are encouraged to analyse the core IMARC themes from different perspectives, specifically those which are key to the three IMARC tracks offered by the three partner universities:

column2: • Global flows, local dilemma’s and glocal solutions (EUR),
• European Union criminal policy and justice in context (UGhent),

column1: We also encourage you to connect these criminological themes with one or more of the seventeen sustainable development goals of the UN.

In addition, the course builds on Globalisation, Digitalisation and Crime to further examine comparative and cross-cultural criminological research, and research in an international setting more generally: either on a global topic, by working with internationally focused actors or by doing international (comparative) research.

Instead of proper ‘ex cathedra classes’, we organise interactive seminars, exercises and assignments to help you explore research themes, formulate appropriate research questions, and understand cross-cultural and international aspects, as well as practical, political and ethical challenges of doing (international) research. This course helps preparing you for choosing your final research topic and writing your research proposal in semester 2.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: <body>Upon completion of the module, the student will be able to:

column2: • Discuss relevant criminological themes related to border crossing, security and social justice in relation to (global) current socio-political and legal developments.
• Describe and reflect on the added value of doing (critical and action) research in an international setting,
• Describe and reflect on various strategies of doing research in an international setting,
• Reflect on the particular practical, political and ethical challenges of doing research in an international setting,
• Discuss and compare the roles of important national and international actors involved in IMARC-issues of border crossing, security and social justice,
• Write and present a research proposal for your master thesis project including a research question and broad outline of a research approach including theory/literature, methodology and ethics.

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/113718,2023,Doing history in the digital era,Engels,Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,"['dr. PJBJ van den Heede', 'prof.dr. RD Futselaar']",,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
• Students are able to critically interrogate digitized and born-digital primary source materials
• Students are able to work with key support tools for digitized historical research (e.g., Transkribus)
• Students are able to carry out a select number of digitized research operations, in particular concerning the scraping and visualization of digital textual data
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: <body>The course introduces students to research methods in digital history. Students will learn how to digitize paper-based primary sources, use and critically interrogate digitized and born-digital information, and work with digital research methods for history. Students will work with, for example, dataset curation, web-scraping, word-embeddings, and visualization of textual data. In this way, the course prepares students for the increased significance of digitized research for 21st-century historians.</body>

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/111318,2023,Dood en letsel: voorkomen, vergoeden en vergelden",Nederlands,Erasmus School of Law,,"['M van den Heuvel', 'mr. LM Stroo', 'PAC Hoynck van Papendrecht', 'prof.mr. KJO Jansen']",,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Niet echt een gezellig onderwerp: dood en letsel. Toch vormt het onderwerp in veel opzichten een belangrijke uitdaging voor het recht en voor vele andere takken van wetenschap, waaronder (rechts)economie, (rechts)sociologie, (rechts)psychologie en gezondheidswetenschappen. Inzichten uit de verschillende wetenschappen en de praktijk worden in deze minor belicht en bijeengebracht. Het centrale onderwerp dood en letsel wordt belicht vanuit drie pijlers: Vergoeden, Vergelden en Voorkomen.

Vergoeden                                                                                                                                                                                          We beginnen met de eerste pijler: het vergoeden van dood en letsel. Deze eerste pijler is vooral juridisch van aard. Enkele vragen die in dit verband aan bod komen zijn: wanneer is een arts aansprakelijk voor letsel na een medische behandeling? Hoeveel smartengeld levert bijvoorbeeld een verloren vinger op? Kun je als slachtoffer van een misdrijf terecht bij de aansprakelijkheidsverzekeraar van de dader? Maar ook: wat zijn belangrijkste behoeften van letselschadeslachtoffers en komt onze maatschappij daaraan tegemoet?

Vergelden                                                                                                                                                                                                In de tweede pijler begeven we ons meer in de praktijk van het strafrecht. Wat is de rol van het OM bij niet-natuurlijk overlijden en hoe wordt een niet-natuurlijke dood eigenlijk vastgesteld? Hoe gaat de maatschappij om met ernstige verkeersdelicten, roekeloos rijgedrag en de roep om hogere straffen? En wat te denken van verzekeringsfraude door een letselschadeslachtoffer; betekent vergelden in dat soort gevallen dan dat we maar helemaal niet meer vergoeden? Kortom, maatschappelijke dilemma’s rondom het vergelden van dood en letsel.

Voorkomen                                                                                                                                                                           Vergoeden en vergelden zijn reacties “after the fact”. Maar hoe zit het met het voorkomen van dood of letsel? Dat is de derde en laatste pijler van de minor. Enkele vragen: wat kost het om risico’s op voortijdig overlijden en blijvend letsel te voorkomen? En wat levert het op? Hoe gaan beleidsmakers om met dit soort rechtseconomische vragen? Wat draagt het aansprakelijkheidsrecht bij aan preventie? Hoe zit het met kinderveiligheid en de preventie van ongevallen bij kinderen? En wat leert de psychologie ons over gedragsbeïnvloeding, bijvoorbeeld in het verkeer?

Kortom: in deze verbredende minor wordt het thema dood en letsel vanuit verschillende invalshoeken (in het bijzonder het recht, maar ook de (rechts)economie, (rechts)sociologie, (rechts)psychologie en gezondheidswetenschappen) benaderd. Verschillende (gast)docenten, die werkzaam zijn in de praktijk, laten hun licht hierover schijnen. De studenten worden uitgedaagd om te discussiëren over de uitdagende dilemma’s op het gebied van dood en letsel en het vergoeden, vergelden en voorkomen daarvan.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: <body>De minor kent de volgende vakdoelstellingen. De student kan na afloop van dit vak:

column2: • Inzichten vanuit verschillende wetenschappen over het vergoeden van dood en letsel beschrijven, analyseren en betrekken in zijn eigen oordeelsvorming over het recht en de verschillende dilemma’s die dood en letsel met zich brengen.

• Inzichten vanuit verschillende wetenschappen over het vergelden van dood en letsel beschrijven, analyseren en betrekken in zijn eigen oordeelsvorming over het recht en de verschillende dilemma’s die dood en letsel met zich brengen.

• Inzichten vanuit verschillende wetenschappen over het voorkomen van dood en letsel beschrijven, analyseren en betrekken in zijn eigen oordeelsvorming over het recht en de verschillende dilemma’s die dood en letsel met zich brengen.
• Relevante rechtsregels op casus over dood en letsel toepassen.

column1: Een cursus Nederlands bestaat uit tien wekelijkse bijeenkomsten van 2,5 uur. Het afsluitende examen vindt na afloop van de cursus plaats op een vooraf vastgestelde datum (zie onderstaande planning). Aan het einde van de cursus is de stof van één cursusniveau behandeld.
Wat leer je tijdens de cursus Nederlands A1?
Tijdens deze cursus leer je de basis van de Nederlandse taal, waarbij de nadruk ligt op de vaardigheden lezen, luisteren, schrijven en spreken in een alledaagse context.
Onderwerpen die aan bod komen zijn bijvoorbeeld:

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Aan het einde van de cursus beschik je over een bescheiden woordenschat zodat je in veelvoorkomende en alledaagse situaties kunt communiceren. Het eindniveau van de cursus is A1 volgens het Common European Framework of Reference (CEFR).

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
• Let op: sommige groepen worden online aangeboden en sommige zijn op de campus.
• Het Language & Training Centre organiseert driemaal per jaar cursussen Nederlands (oktober-december / januari-maart / april-juni).
• Deze cursus is toegankelijk voor cursisten met een academische achtergrond (hbo/wo).
• De steuntaal van deze cursus is Engels. In de lessen wordt echter zoveel mogelijk Nederlands gesproken.
• In de bevestigingsbrief die je ontvangt als de cursus doorgaat, informeren we je over de details.
• Van de deelnemers wordt verwacht dat zij naast de wekelijkse contacturen ongeveer drie uur per week aan zelfstudie besteden.
• De groepen zijn klein: minimaal 12 en maximaal 16 deelnemers. Let op! Bij minder dan 12 inschrijvingen behoudt het LTC het recht om de cursus te annuleren.

• Aanwezigheid bij de lessen is niet verplicht, wel raadzaam. Let op! Tijdens de laatste les vindt er een mondelinge toets en een luistertoets plaats. Om voor de cursus te kunnen slagen, dien je dan aanwezig te zijn.

• De cursus wordt afgesloten met een schriftelijk examen waarin de lees- en schrijfvaardigheid wordt getoetst. Met dyslexie kun je extra tijd krijgen voor dit examen. Vergeet niet om je dyslexieverklaring met je verzoek naar ltc@eur.nl te sturen.
• Je ontvangt een certificaat als je de cursus afsluit met een 'pass' voor alle vier de vaardigheden.

• De cursus wordt afgesloten met een schriftelijk examen waarin de lees- en schrijfvaardigheid wordt getoetst. Met dyslexie kun je extra tijd krijgen voor dit examen. Vergeet niet om je dyslexieverklaring met je verzoek naar ltc@eur.nl te sturen.

column1: Wat leer je tijdens de cursus Nederlands?
Tijdens deze cursus leer je de basis van de Nederlandse taal, waarbij de nadruk ligt op luisteren en communicatie in een alledaagse context. Onderwerpen die aan bod komen zijn bijvoorbeeld:

column2: • Een afspraak maken en de tijd/kalender lezen;
• De weg wijzen, uitleggen wat je hebt gedaan.
• Mondelinge communicatie en schrijf- en leesvaardigheden in het Nederlands;

column1: Tijdens de lessen word je geacht actief deel te nemen aan de conversatie- en mondelinge opdrachten. Je leert tevens hoe je een korte tekst moet schrijven.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: <body>De cursus Nederlands voor beginners A1+A2.1 is een dubbele cursus: aan het eind van het traject is de stof van twee cursusniveaus behandeld. De cursus bestaat dan ook uit 20 lessen van 2,5 uur. Voordeel is dat je tussendoor geen examen hoeft te doen. Je stroomt dus automatisch door van niveau A1 naar niveau A2.1.</body>

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
• Let op: sommige groepen worden online aangeboden en sommige zijn op de campus.
• Het Language & Training Centre organiseert driemaal per jaar cursussen Nederlands (oktober-december / januari-maart / april-juni).
• Deze cursus is toegankelijk voor cursisten met een academische achtergrond (hbo/wo).
• De steuntaal van deze cursus is Engels. In de lessen wordt echter zoveel mogelijk Nederlands gesproken.
• Het cursusmateriaal kost ± € 43,- en is niet bij de cursusprijs inbegrepen.
• Bij het speciale tarief is het cursus materiaal inbegrepen.
• In de bevestigingsbrief die je ontvangt als de cursus doorgaat, informeren we je over de details.
• Van de deelnemers wordt verwacht dat zij naast de wekelijkse contacturen ongeveer drie uur per week aan zelfstudie besteden.
• De groepen zijn klein: minimaal 12 en maximaal 16 deelnemers. Let op! Bij minder dan 12 inschrijvingen behoudt het LTC het recht om de cursus te annuleren.

• Aanwezigheid bij de lessen is niet verplicht, wel raadzaam. Let op! Tijdens de laatste les vindt er een mondelinge toets en een luistertoets plaats. Om voor de cursus te kunnen slagen, dien je dan aanwezig te zijn.

• De cursus wordt afgesloten met een schriftelijk examen waarin de lees- en schrijfvaardigheid wordt getoetst. Met dyslexie kun je extra tijd krijgen voor dit examen. Vergeet niet om je dyslexieverklaring met je verzoek naar ltc@eur.nl te sturen.
• Je ontvangt een certificaat als je de cursus afsluit met een 'pass' voor alle vier de vaardigheden.

column1: Duitstaligen kunnen de Nederlandse taal snel leren, daarom organiseren we een speciale cursus waarin twee niveaus worden behandeld. Deze cursus Nederlands bestaat uit tien wekelijkse bijeenkomsten van 2,5 uur. Het afsluitende examen vindt na afloop van de cursus plaats op een vooraf vastgestelde datum (zie onderstaande planning). In deze cursus behandel je de leerstof die hoort bij niveau A1 tot en met niveau A2.2.
Wat leer je tijdens de cursus Nederlands A1& A2.2?

Tijdens deze cursus leer je de basis van de Nederlandse taal, waarbij de nadruk ligt op de vaardigheden lezen, luisteren, schrijven en spreken in een alledaagse context. Onderwerpen die aan bod komen zijn bijvoorbeeld:

column1: This course consists of ten weekly 3 hour meetings. The final exam takes place after the end of the course on a predetermined date (see schedule below). At the end of the course, the material of one course level has been covered.
What will you learn during the Dutch B2.2 course?

This course is a follow-up to the Dutch B2.1 course. During this course you build on the previously learned topics of the Dutch language, with an emphasis on reading, listening, writing and speaking skills in an everyday context. Topics covered include, for example:

• Bij het afsluitende examen mag je een papieren woordenboek gebruiken. Wij raden het volgende woordenboek aan: Van Dale pocketwoordenboek Nederlands als tweede taal (NT2).
• Je ontvangt een certificaat als je de cursus afsluit met een 'pass' voor alle vier de vaardigheden.

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/114678,2023,Dutch History in a Globalizing World,Engels,Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,"['dr. J Verhoef', 'dr. PJBJ van den Heede', 'dr. Y van Hoef']",,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: In this course, an overview is given of the history of the Netherlands from the medieval period to the present. A particular emphasis will be put on how Dutch history fits in a broader European and global context. During the course, students will also be invited to critically assess the history of the Netherlands by applying globalizing perspectives (e.g., focus on transnational and translocal developments, comparative approaches and new unexplored perspectives).

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: <body>Students understand the broad outlines of the history of the Netherlands in a European and global context from the medieval period to the present. They can describe the significance of the various factors that led to the Dutch Revolt in the 16<sup>th</sup> century. They can illustrate the significance of various political, economic and cultural factors that impacted Dutch society from the medieval period to the present. They can illustrate how processes of (de)colonization and empire building impacted both Dutch society and former colonized territories in various ways. Finally, students can critically interrogate scholarly literature on the history of the Netherlands from a global perspective</body>

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/114121,2023,Dutch law and Dutch Legal Culture in a Comparative Perspective,Engels,Erasmus School of Law,,['dr. AJ de Roo', 'dr. RW Jagtenberg']",,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: The course introduces the participating students to the main characteristics of the Dutch legal system and its legal culture.

The focus of the course is twofold. First, the students are provided with an overview of the general principles of the core areas of Dutch law, i.e. constitutional law, administrative law, criminal law and private law. Second, the focus is on the background and context of the Dutch legal system, based on the assumption that a good understanding of a particular legal system includes an understanding of its legal culture.

To achieve this, the course will address typical (legal) institutions and procedures, such as the administration of justice, including the court system, and the legislative procedure. In addition, court annexed mediation will be discussed in the light of the pursuit of more efficient and better performing courts and the European Mediation Directive.

The general approach of the course is comparative by situating the Dutch legal system in its European context and relating it to other legal systems and legal cultures. By comparing a particular legal system, i.e. the Dutch legal system, with other legal systems its typical characteristics will become (more) evident.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Through this course students will get a basic understanding of the origin and structure of the Dutch legal system and the general principles underlying Dutch constitutional, administrative, criminal and private law. Besides, the participating students will be informed of actual developments in the area of dispute processing inside and outside the courts and to recent landmark decisions such as the Urgenda and Shell cases.
In addition, the students will be able to relate Dutch legal culture to European and other western legal cultures. Therefore, the adopted approach throughout the course is comparative.

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/111817,2023,Dynamiek in Complexe Systemen,Nederlands,Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences,,['dr. PK Marks', 'dr. WAH Spekkink']",,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

De huidige bestuurskundige praktijk wordt gekenmerkt door een confrontatie met vraagstukken die systemisch van aard zijn zoals fileproblematiek, klimaatverandering, veiligheid en stedelijke ontwikkeling. Deze issues vragen om interventies in een complex geheel van relaties tussen publieke en private partijen, sociale en fysieke infrastructuren en natuurlijke ecosystemen. In deze module analyseren we verschillende aspecten van systemen, zoals toeval, stabiliteit, en de relatie tussen de individu en het collectief. We maken daarbij gebruik van evolutionaire theorieën, communicatietheorieën, economische theorieën en gedragstheorieën.

De studenten bereiden de colleges voor door voorafgaand een position paper te schrijven over de leerstof van dat college. Tijdens het college wordt van de studenten gevraagd om hun positie te presenteren en te verdedigen. Door middel van discussie tussen studenten en docenten proberen we beter te begrijpen wat de theorie betekent en tegelijkertijd te ontdekken wat onze eigen veronderstellingen zijn. De position papers worden beoordeeld en maken deel uit van het eindcijfer.</body>

column1: The EFR Involve Consultancy project distinguishes itself from the other EFR's initiatives by its social and research focused approach. In the program, a select group of students apply their academic knowledge to practice and make a sustainable impact on communities that need it the most. This is done in partnership with an NGO or social enterprise and under the supervision of the course coordinator. Both sides will guide and assist the students in setting up their research. This project consists of four months of desk research (April-July), 2 to 3 weeks of field research abroad (August) and a final presentation for the partner (September).
Below are a couple of topics the students worked on the past years:

column2: • A sustainable relation between nature and people in Kenya

column1: International, transnational and domestic actors shape and contest the global regulations and practices we live by. For example, the World Health Organization (WHO), which remains the primary organization involved in global health, provided guidance during the outbreak of Coronavirus. Moreover, the interaction between the WHO, development aid donors and pharmaceutical companies affects access of millions of people to affordable medicine by regulating production and sales of so-called ‘generic drugs’. Such interactions of states, international organisations, NGOs, private actors, legal norms and informal rules create international regimes – sets of written and unwritten rules that guide (but do not predetermine) behaviour in particular policy sectors. These regimes are not just legal rules but practical “ways to do things” on the global arena. Ultimately, international regulatory regimes are an attempt to bring order to anarchy, make sense out of complexity and establish rules and predictability in at least some global policy areas. However, the practice of implementing these global rules is often confusing and contradictory. For instance, anti-money-laundering legislation initiated by the G7 has found higher compliance rates in ‘developing countries’ than in OECD countries. In cases of high-level corruption, it is often NGOs and activist groups which elicit compliance, not the governments who signed anti-corruption legislation. These observations make one ask how we can achieve accountable and effective governance on global and local scales. Do the current rules governing global trade and related activities, including international cooperation in the health sector, provide for a common level playing field?

This course analyses the interaction -both formal and informal - between the different stakeholders (governments, business corporations, civil society representatives etc.) in the development and functioning of international regulations regimes that govern trade and health cooperation, affecting power relations across the globe. Amongst a variety of issues, students will address issues related to the production of generic medicine (TRIPS), fighting money-laundering and tax-evasion as well as bringing transparency to arms trade. By adopting this layout the course reflects on the systemic rules that govern global trade (food, medicine and health, military equipment) and shape our lives, connecting these rules with broader issues like inequality, human rights and political coercion.

Doing so, we challenge the simplistic assumption that global regulatory regimes always transfer most effective and best applicable practices that serve the 'common good'. By going beyond legal aspects, international economics and a focus on international organisations or state actors, this course provides an expansion to the POLIR and EUC curriculum. Students will explore practical issues of global politics in commerce and health to understand how implementation and compliance challenges power asymmetries and international arrangements on a daily basis.

column1: In het kader van het vak EU-douanerecht en accijnzen wordt op verdiepende wijze ingegaan op een geselecteerd aantal onderwerpen uit het wetgevingspakket van het Douane Wetboek van de Unie. Aan de orde zullen onder andere komen het formele douanerecht, (het ontstaan van) de douaneschuld (classificatie, douanewaarde en oorsprong) en bijzondere regelingen. Ten aanzien van het douaneonderdeel wordt tevens ingegaan op de invloed en doorwerking van het internationale douanerecht zoals vastgesteld door de Wereldhandelsorganisatie, en op de juridische instrumenten zoals ontwikkeld door de Werelddouaneorganisatie. Daarnaast wordt aandacht besteed aan de heffing van accijnzen.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

• Zelfstandig complexe vraagstukken vanuit douane- en accijnsrechtelijk perspectief te analyseren en op te lossen op het gebied van douaneschuld, classificatie, oorsprong, douanewaarde, douaneprocessen, -procedures, -regelingen, -bestemmingen en -formaliteiten, belastbare accijnsgoederen, het Europese accijnssysteem (schorsingsregime, uitslag tot verbruik en heffingsbevoegdheid) en accijnsuitzonderingen en -vrijstellingen;
• De uitgangspunten en fundamenten van het Europese douanerecht en accijnzen te benoemen, herkennen, begrijpen en onderscheiden;
• De samenhang en de verschillen tussen de heffing van douanerechten en accijnzen te analyseren;
• Samen te werken met medestudenten op een fiscaal multidisciplinair terrein;
• Een fiscaaltechnisch onderwerp te presenteren ten overstaan van zijn/haar medestudenten en daarbij blijk te geven van beheersing van presentatietechnieken;
• Zelfstandig een aangedragen fiscaaltechnische probleemstelling te analyseren, zich daarover een mening te vormen en deze te beargumenteren op een gedegen wetenschappelijke wijze;
• De analyse en argumentatie t.a.v. een fiscaal juridisch vraagstuk begrijpelijk en overtuigend weer te geven in een verhandeling.

I van den Eijnde, LLM', 'mr.dr. E Boomsluiter', 'mr.dr. M Albers', 'mr.drs. ME Schutte', 'prof.mr.dr. W de Wit', 'WM den Hoed, LL.M']",,"Inhoud

• een fiscaaltechnisch onderwerp te presenteren ten overstaan van zijn/haar medestudenten en daarbij blijk te geven van beheersing van presentatietechnieken;
• zelfstandig een aangedragen fiscaaltechnische probleemstelling te analyseren, zich daarover een mening te vormen en deze te beargumenteren op een gedegen wetenschappelijke wijze;
• de analyse en argumentatie t.a.v. een fiscaal juridisch vraagstuk begrijpelijk en overtuigend weer te geven in een verhandeling.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: In Northern Europe, the late seventeenth and early eighteenth centuries saw the first proliferation of the Enlightenment – a cultural movement characterized by its pleas in favor of toleration, its opposition to ‘prejudices’, its fascination with the results achieved by the ‘Scientific Revolution’ as well as by its proposals for societal reforms. Philosophers played a crucial role in articulating its program. In this course we start close at home, for it was Pierre Bayle, ‘le philosophe de Rotterdam’, whose attacks on religious prejudices and whose demands for toleration would serve later generations of enlightened authors as a major source of inspiration. Next, we will turn to France, and to Montesquieu and Voltaire in particular. In France a new cultural phenomenon emerges: the philosophe, witty, sociable, and fiercely critical of received tradition. Many French authors start reading British philosophers, and in this course we will deal with both Berkeley and Hume, and we will wrap up this overview of the early stages of the Enlightenment with a discussion of the Scottish Enlightenment, including Adam Smith. In an accompanying (facultative) study group we will read one of Hume’s enduring masterpieces: Dialogues concerning Natural Religion.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: To fulltime students of Philosophy the seminars are compulsory.

Having completed this course, students will be familiar with some of the main ideas put forward by Pierre Bayle. They will understand the main characteristics of ‘British empiricism’. They will be able to distinguish some of the main differences between the French and the Scottish Enlightenment. They will develop some awareness of the historical contingency of the history of eighteenth-century philosophy

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Politics speaks to us all. Some of us are involved only as citizens; others also as activists, analysts, reporters, or academics. The concepts we use, the positions we defend and the various practices we take part in belong to a tradition of thought that is as rich as it is fundamental to understanding our own society and politics in general. This course offers an overview of the most influential thinkers and themes of political philosophy from the Renaissance to the Enlightenment.

The week-by-week activities of the course will centre around an influential theorist and one of his key contributions. For example, Thomas Hobbes' innovative theory of sovereignty continues to have an enormous influence on work in the fields of international relations, sociology, political theory, history, and philosophy. By introducing such ideas in their historical context we can make them meaningful in terms of the problems the theorist meant to address; conversely, by having a conceptual interest in their theories we can read them in a way that emphasises the relevance of these classic works to our present world. For this reason, the orientation of the course will be both philosophical and historical. The course is a must for
anyone interested in the meaning and history of such concepts as virtue, sovereignty, power and rights.
history of such concepts as virtue, sovereignty, power and rights.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
<body>After completing this course, students are able to:

column2: • formulate and explain the basic themes of political philosophy from the Early Modern Era, as well as their interrelation;
• relate thinkers and themes of Early Modern political philosophy to politics in the present day;
• formulate the difference between institutional approaches to the analysis of society and those focusing on the person of the leader;
• relate utopianism to its roots in Thomas More, and to explain the relationship between utopianism and interpretations of politics as a moral enterprise;
• explain the relationship between the classical/humanist concept of ‘virtue’ and Machiavelli’s concept of virtu;
• define and analyze the ‘turn to nature’ in Machiavelli’s political philosophy and subsequent authors;
• describe the importance of Hobbes to liberalism, e.g. in terms of consent;
• explain the nature and necessity of sovereignty in Hobbes’ political philosophy;
• connect the concept of democracy to Spinoza’s legacy;
• relate Spinoza’s naturalism to his support for democracy and tolerance;
• relate Montesquieu’s concept of liberty to his philosophical forebears as well as later political developments;
• explain Montesquieu’s ideas on adapting laws to contextual factors;
• describe Rousseau’s views on human nature and the corruption of society;
• explain Rousseau’s conception of the general will.

column1: In academia, business environment and policy-making circles the past decade has given rise to a growing acknowledgment of the design industries as paradigmatic sectors of post-industrial economies, “cognitive-cultural” capitalism, or even better “neo-industrial” economies, in which production and consumption increasingly relies on symbolic and aesthetic considerations as well as on local specificities. They are also examples of the need to pursue alternative economies where not only financial, but also environmental, social and cultural aspects of sustainability are acknowledged and valued. In this seminar we zoom on the fashion industry, we analyze its current structure and practices, issues and challenges, and envision the transition to a more sustainable fashion future. Topics covered in the course, among others: cultural economic characteristics of fashion products; demand for fashion products; economic and spatial organization of fashion industries; labour market for designers; sustainability, circular economy, wellbeing economy and sustainability transition; intermediaries, temporary clusters and global pipelines. The seminar provides a forum for discussion of the week’s topic, reading material and case studies. Students are expected to read and discuss the literature, summarize it for discussion in class and apply it to specific cases. A critical approach is encouraged. Students will carry out a research-based analysis resulting in an individual essay and in a group poster presentation (often in collaboration with stakeholders in the fashion industry). We will discuss relevant literature and specific cases through student presentation, class discussion, fieldtrips, and through an envisioning and futuring workshop. This course builds further upon the courses in Term 1 and 2, and it is connected to topics that students will encounter in their master thesis.
- The maximum number of participants is 25.</body>

column2: • Develop knowledge and understanding of the cultural economic dimensions of the fashion industry and its sustainability transition.
• Evaluate main issues, trends and limitations of theories applied to the the fashion industry and sustainability.
• Apply concepts and theories to specific case studies in the fashion industry in group presentations, discussions and written assignments (written and orally).

column1: Econometrics is characterized by the combination of economic research questions, use of empirical data, application of statistical and mathematical methods, and the use of software to estimate and evaluate models. All these topics are extensively discussed in the lectures and practised in the tutorials.

column2: • Lectures and exercise lectures: Introduction to econometrics, research questions, methods. The linear regression model (simple and multiple), method of least squares, testing. Non-linear models, maximum likelihood, some asymptotic theory of estimation and testing. The models and methods are motivated by economic applications and applied in practical examples. The required econometric methods make intensive use of earlier courses in the programme, in particular statistics, matrix algebra and analysis.
• Tutorials: Exercises on theory and applications. Further, some tutorials consist of computer sessions to apply econometric techniques by means of a software package.

column1: This course uses knowledge of FEB21005X(S) Probability Theory, FEB21007X(S) Statistics, FEB21023X Vector Calculus, FEB22003X Introduction to Multivariate Statistics and FEB22006X Nonlinear Optimalisation, and is required for FEB22005X Econometrics 2.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
• Learn the mathematical structure and statistical properties of linear and non-linear regression models by means of matrix methods and statistical analysis.
• Understand the process of econometric modelling as an interplay of economic insights, data properties, and statistical model assumptions.
• Get experienced in the mathematical analysis and statistical evaluation of econometric models.
• Get experienced in the practical interpretation of outcomes of econometric analysis and in choosing between alternative models and methods.
• Get practical experience in analysing economic data by means of econometric software on the PC.

column1: In this course we provide an understanding of basic econometric methods. Knowledge of these methods allows one to understand modern empirical economic literature and to perform one's own analysis of economic and business data. The technique of regression is discussed, as well as various extensions that are needed in concrete applications to deal with, for example, heteroscedasticity, autocorrelation, endogeneity, and non-linearity. Furthermore an introduction to discrete choice modeling is given. The main emphasis of the course is on the theoretical properties as well as interpretation of models and outcomes of estimation and testing procedures. The students practice this themselves by analyzing economic and business data by means of the software R and by deriving and interpreting formulas for basic models and concepts.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: By the end of the course, students should be able to
1. Evaluate the use of basic econometric methods based on their theoretical properties
3. Apply econometric techniques to answer empirical questions

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Instructors: Prof. Dr. B. van der Klaauw (VU) and Dr. H.G. Bloemen (VU)

Many empirical questions in economics require estimating causal parameters. Regression models provide correlations which only have a causal interpretation if the zero conditional mean assumption holds. This assumption is often violated, for example when there are omitted variables, non-random sampling, reverse causality or measurement errors in regressors. In this course we discuss methods dealing with these confounding factors. In particular, we consider limited dependent variable models, instrumental variables estimation and panel data models. We introduce the potential outcomes model, which is the most general model for defining treatment effects such as average treatment effect, average treatment effect on the treated, quantile treatment effects and local average treatment effects. The emphasis of the course is on identification, estimation and interpretation rather than a thorough treatment of the asymptotic properties of the estimators. During the course applications of the different methods are discussed, mainly in the fields of labor economics, health economics, and the economics of education.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

1. apply microeconometric techniques rather than deriving econometric and statistical properties of estimators
2. decide about the appropriate model; be able to apply the estimation method correctly
3. interpret the estimation results

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: This course covers theoretical and practical aspects of time series econometrics including the analysis of stationary and non-stationary stochastic processes.

The students are introduced to concepts in the statistical analysis of time series, dynamic processes, autoregressive moving average (ARMA) models, autoregressive distributed lag (ADL) models, error correction models (ECM), and generalized autoregressive conditional heteroscedasticity (GARCH) models. Furthermore, the course provides both theoretical and practical insights into parameter estimation for time series models and the use of these models for forecasting, testing for Granger causality, and performing policy analysis using impulse response functions.

Finally, the students are introduced to the fundamental problem of spurious regression in time series analysis. In order to find a solution to this problem, we take a journey into the wonderful world of the theory and practice behind unit-root test, co-integration tests and error-correction representation theorems.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Learning goals for this course: students should have an understanding of, ability to apply, judge, and communicate
1. Basics of time-series data and analysis
2. Univariate time-series models, dynamic properties, parameter estimation, forecasting
3. Dynamic econometric models, non-stationary models, testing, cointegration, error-correction
4. The empirical application of time-series modeling and interpretation of estimation results</body>

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Econometrics is used in many aspects of healthcare. Logistic processes in hospitals are prone to uncertainty in the number of urgent patients coming in and time treatment procedures take, making them excellently suited for econometric prediction and optimization techniques. Identifying health inequalities and promoting population health can be seen as variants on marketing techniques trying to identify the customer population and selling a product. Finally, there is an important role for stochastic decision models to identify optimal intervention strategies to maximize population health with the resources available.

In this course, different real-world examples of econometrics in healthcare will be presented. Moreover, students will work on a hands-on example of using decision modeling in healthcare to develop advice to the health minister on the implementation of a screening program. In this hands-on example, students will follow the different steps of the cycle of decision modeling from model development and estimation of parameters to model application and uncertainty analysis to finally writing advice to the Minister of Health. An important aspect of the work is the realization that neither the model nor the health intervention are ever final, and that in healthcare we continuously strive to improve both. In the series of lectures and the practical assignment, the following aspects will be discussed:

column2: • Population screening and using screening data in calibration
• Other uses of econometrics in healthcare: determinants of health, imaging, and optimizing patient pathways (including site visit to EMC)
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: After this course, students are able to:

column2: • provide different examples of how econometrics is used in healthcare
• develop a simulation model for the natural history of a disease and estimate its parameters
• perform a cost-effectiveness analysis of screening using microsimulation modeling
• assess model uncertainty and explain ways to improve the reliability of simulation models

column1: Networks play an increasingly dominant role in many social, business, and economic environments. Moreover, network data becomes increasingly important and available due to the rise of online social media and digitization. This course offers a concise introduction into the most recent econometric methods developed for processing, visualizing and learning from network data. The course will combine lectures with hands-on empirical and programming exercises.</body>

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Upon successful completion of the course, students will:
• become acquainted with different statistical methods for the empirical analysis of networks while learning how to see these different methods
• learn to model network problem situations mathematically, and adapt the methods learned to new situations at hand;
• be able to recognize, understand, and analyze societal and business problems in which networks are central;
• learn how networks affect demand and supply in markets, how this leads to market failures, and how government policies can address these;

column1: Het vakgebied econometrie wordt gekenmerkt door een combinatie van economische vraagstellingen, gebruik van empirische gegevens, toepassing van statistische en wiskundige methoden, en gebruik van software om modellen te schatten en te evalueren. Al deze onderwerpen komen uitgebreid aan de orde in de hoorcolleges en worden geoefend bij de sommencolleges en in de practica.

column2: • Hoorcollege en sommencollege: Inleiding econometrie, vraagstellingen, modellen, methoden. Het lineaire regressiemodel (enkelvoudig en meervoudig), methode van kleinste kwadraten, toetsen. Niet-lineaire modellen, maximale aannemelijkheid, enige asymptotische theorie van schatten en toetsen. De modellen en methoden worden gemotiveerd vanuit economische toepassingen en toegepast in praktische voorbeelden. De benodigde econometrische methoden maken intensief gebruik van eerdere vakken uit het programma, met name statistiek, lineaire algebra en analyse.
• Practicum: Opgaven over theorie en toepassingen. Voorts wordt enige malen een computer-practicum gehouden, waar econometrische technieken worden toegepast aan de hand van een software pakket.

column1: Dit vak gebruikt kennis van FEB21005 Kansrekening, FEB21007 Statistiek, FEB21023 Vector Calculus, FEB22003 Inleiding Multivariate Statistiek en FEB22006 Niet-lineair Optimaliseren, en is nodig voor FEB22005 Econometrie 2.

• Vertrouwd raken met het analyseren van de wiskundige en statistische structuur van econometrische modellen.
• Vertrouwd raken met de praktische interpretatie van de uitkomsten van econometrische analyse en het kiezen tussen alternatieve modellen en methoden.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: <body>This 8-ECTS course aims at giving students an overview of the most important insights from the economic analysis of private law. It combines economic analysis of property law, tort law, and contract law. As far as property law is concerned, the course integrates the legal and the economic approach to ownership and illustrates costs and benefits of different ways to protect entitlements. As far as tort law is concerned, the course offers a comparative analysis of the legal principles from an economic perspective, particularly regarding the structure of liability, the damage compensation, and the insurance. As far as contract law is concerned, the course illustrates its goals and functions from an economic perspective. Moreover, it aims to provide a functional understanding of the spectrum of feasible contracts and of their use in legal practice.</body>

column1: This course offers an introduction to the economic analysis of regulation, which is broadly interpreted as government intervention in market processes. The course illustrates the purposes of regulatory intervention from a welfare economics perspective, and it discusses the tension between public and private interest in regulatory choices. A special focus of this course is on issues of European regulation and on cost-benefit analysis.

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/114638,2023,Economic Geography of Creativity and Urban Development,Engels,Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,['dr. V Morea'],,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: During the past decade, the concept of creative economy along with that of creative industries have experienced an intensifying academic research and policy attention. The course critically investigates theories and issues linked to culture, creativity, economy and cities. It will provide students with a contrasting set of views on the role of cultural and creative industries in cities through the use of theories, case studies and fieldtrips. Topics discussed include: the role of culture and creativity in   cities across centuries, the emergence of a creative city (e.g. a fashion capital), the economic geography of cultural production, cultural-led urban (re)generation, gentrification, circular economy, cultural intermediaries, (temporary) clusters, the black box of urban growth. We emphasize an analytical approach in understanding the dynamic development of cultural and creative industries and place, and the issues that arise from them.

column2: • This course is only open to Pre-Master students in Cultural Economics and Entrepreneurship, BA students in International Bachelor Arts and Culture Studies (IBACS) and BA Algemene Cultuurwetenschappen

column1: In this seminar students will acquire knowledge and understanding of the spatial dimension and characteristics of creativity as well as the connections between the development of cultural and creative industries and the growth of cities and regions. Special attention is dedicated the role cultural and creative industries play in supporting the transition to the circular economy.
At the end of the course students should be able:

column2: • To develop knowledge and understanding of theories applied to the spatial dimensions of creativity;
• To apply concepts and theories to specific case studies in group presentations, discussions and written assignments;
• To explain main issues and limitations of theories; critically assess the value and relevance of models, concepts and theories.

column1: This course introduces key topics in Economic History. Among others, the following questions are explored:
• What were the causes of the Industrial Revolution? What were its “deep roots”? – geography?, institutions?, human capital?, culture?, the scientific revolution?

• How did the world economy leave behind Malthusian stagnation and transition to modern economic growth? How did the uneven spread of modern economic growth around the globe give rise to the large cross-country income disparities we observe today?
• What were the causes of the Great Depression? What were its consequences? What role did different economic policies play in ending it?

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: 1. Familiarize yourself with the most important theories and the empirical evidence surrounding key events in economic history.
2. Develop a better understanding of how today's world economy came into being.

column1: The minor aims to broaden as well as deepen the knowledge and understanding of economics for individuals trained in econometrics on several dimensions.

This module begins with an introduction to/refresher of game theory to lay the methodological foundations. In the rest of the course we consider classical strategic problems of individual interaction such as
After a general analysis of these strategic situations, we apply the framework to questions of economic relevance.
In this module we will study the long run behaviour of economy and its short-run fluctuations.
In the first part (long-run), we will cover economic growth and unemployment.
In the second part (short-run), the focus will be on the consumption, investment and asset prices’ determination.
The models presented in this course are an introduction to modern macroeconomics and build on the 1st year macroeconomics course. We will study the applications of the models using academic papers.
The module is about micro-econometric empirical strategies used to estimate causal relationships that are of interest to economists. These include:

The module will describe the advantages (and disadvantages) of these different empirical strategies to identify the causal effect of a treatment. Students will learn what kind of identifying assumptions different empirical strategies are based on. We will also appraise which data requirements have to be met for the successful application of a particular strategy.
This will be done, for each method in turn, by:
1. reviewing the econometric theory behind the various methods
2. go through empirical papers which have successfully applied these methods

column1: Almost all socio-economic characteristics (e.g., educational attainment, occupation, and income) have been shown to be moderately heritable. This makes it possible to identify specific genes that are related to socio-economic differences among individuals and to investigate how these genes interact with environmental factors. For example, which genetic factors contribute to educational attainment and do specific family environments moderate the genetic susceptibility to perform well in school? The goal of this course is to make students familiar with recent developments in the field of genoeconomics (i.e., the integration of genetics into economics), and to reflect on the ethical aspects of these developments. This course covers topics such as the nature vs. nurture debate, estimation and interpretation of heritability, gene discovery, and genetic prediction. Moreover, the students become familiar with big data analysis by performing basic genetic analyses using specialized statistical software.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: 1. Critically assess published studies in behavioural genetics/genoeconomics in writing and verbally.
2. Reflect on the ethical aspects of using genetics in economic research and policy in writing and verbally
3. Apply state-of-the-art methods and software to genetic data by conducting heritability analysis and GWAS
4. Interpret the results of heritability analysis and GWAS in writing

column1: Historical developments, political choices, and societal structures strongly influence the organization and financing of health care systems across countries. The main purpose of this course is to provide an introduction to various conceptual frameworks that help you to understand and use economic principles applied to health care systems. The course will deal with theory of supply and demand in health care, the crucial role of (asymmetry in) information, provider payment incentives, private and social health insurance, theory and practice of managed competition, organization and financing of long-term care, and the public/private mix in the financing and provision of care. The course looks at how health care systems, in the Netherlands as well as in other developed countries, deal with important policy issues like competition and regulation, solidarity, and value-based health care.

column2: • Short videos with explanations of key concepts
• Live on-campus lectures with discussion, Q&A, assignments, etc.
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: <body>By the end of this course students are able to:

column2: • Analyze the challenges and economic complexities of health care (systems) that are relevant for health policy;
• Classify different types of health care systems and analyze how these systems are organized and financed;
• Infer and reflect on the implications of the organization and financing of health care systems for efficiency and equity;
• Analyze the comparative performance of health care systems and infer implications thereof for health policy.

column1: ‘Advanced economics of arts and culture’ consists of lectures in cultural economics that articulate the application of the economic framework to the arts, culture, heritage and creative industries. The course relates economic principles and analyses to sectors such as the performing arts, visual arts, and the museum and heritage sectors, in which it investigates the role and activities of the main stakeholders: political decision-makers, policymakers, consumers, producers, patrons, etc. Topics under scope include: the rationale and instruments for public support; demand and supply of cultural goods; prices; the functioning of the art market; artists’ labour markets; the economics of cultural heritage; impact.

Note: This course is only open to BA students in Cultural Studies and exchange students with some basic knowledge of economics (e.g. high school level of economics). The lectures of this course are mandatory.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: The aim of the course is to develop students' understanding of economics as it applies to the world of the arts and culture. Cultural economics studies economic decision-making by artists, organizations, policy-makers and consumers in the cultural sector. After the course, students will be able to evaluate the economic aspects of cultural policy and the market for cultural goods and services, based on economic theories about the arts, culture and creativity.

column1: <body>The course illustrates the contribution of cultural economics to the analysis of cultural heritage to guarantee it a sustainable future. Students will learn the main topics characterizing the cultural-economic perspective on cultural heritage. The analysis will consider the issues related to cultural heritage conservation and enhancement emphasizing the role it can have for a sustainable economic, cultural and social development. The course will refer to the main documents issued by UNESCO and the EU related to the role of cultural heritage for society and will use the cultural economic concepts to reflect on the issues at stakes, the values involved and possible interventions to guarantee a sustainable conservation and enhancement of cultural heritage. The main issues considered are:

column2: • The evolution of the concept of cultural heritage: tangible, intangible.
• The values of cultural heritage, evaluation methods and their limits.
• Conservation and adaptive re-use of cultural heritage.
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: After completing the course, students should have a wide-ranging knowledge and critical understanding of the cultural economic perspective on cultural heritage. They will be aware of the relevance of economic concepts and management issues related to cultural heritage and sites as well as of the main policy dilemmas arising in this field. The course gives specific attention to the connection between theory and practice referring to several case studies.

column1: The course will introduce the main concepts related to tourism in general: its development, its economic impact, the main definitions and concepts (tourist, visitor, excursionist, carrying capacity of a destination), and the trends characterizing the sector and modifying it. The course will then focus on cultural tourism: a specific branch of tourism that is expanding though it is still difficult to identify and define. The economic approach will highlight the characteristics of the sector, its potential for the economic development of regions but also the risks it can entail (for example in terms of congestion and wear and tear of heritage sites). The course will provide a critical review of the virtuous-vicious relationship between tourism and culture and will focus on the possible strategies that can be applied to avoid or, at least, reduce the risks in order to attain sustainable cultural tourism development.

Every week the lecturer will introduce a theme illustrating the main theoretical notions and some examples. The week after a group of students will lead the class making a presentation that provides a thorough analysis of the same topic using a case study.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

The aim of this course is to teach students the main concepts from the economics of tourism, considering the evolution and development of the sector through time, focusing in particularly on the niche of cultural tourism. Based on a critical engagement with the fundamental theories and empirical literature, students are challenged to identify and comment the effects, opportunities and challenges related to cultural tourism. Students will improve their presentation and writing skills by doing presentations in class and writing a final essay.

column1: The seminar looks at the fashion industry as one of the creative industries. It aims to facilitate students’ knowledge and understanding of how the industry works. The seminar will confront students with the most recent theories linked to the characteristics, the demand, the supply and intermediaries for fashion products as well the sustainability issues in the fashion industry. We emphasize an analytical approach in understanding the dynamic development of the fashion industry. In doing so, we will discuss relevant literature and specific cases through student presentations, class discussion and field trips. Students will focus on one fashion product/firm/market and carry out research based on scholarly literature, resulting in an individual essay and in a group poster presentation.

- Priority is given to bachelor students from Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication (7 students from BA Geschiedenis or IBHistory, 7 students from BA ACW or IBACS, 7 students from IBCoM, 3 exchange students, 9 students from other faculties or universities).

- It is not allowed to take this course as an individual course; students are required to take the entire Minor Fashion Industry of 15 ECTs. Minor students should obtain a pass mark for each of the three course; it is not possible to compensate for a score below the pass mark.

- Admission requirements: Proficiency in spoken and written English is essential [VWO-final examination grade: 7 or higher / TOEFL-test: minimum score 580 (paper-based), 237 (computer- based) or 92 (internet-based) / IELTS-test: minimum of 7(overall band)]</body>

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: The seminar looks at the fashion industry as one of the creative industries. It aims to facilitate students’ knowledge and understanding of the cultural economic dimensions of the fashion industry and its spatial characteristics. The seminar confronts students with theories and practices linked to the characteristics, demand, supply and intermediaries for fashion products, in order to better understand, address and facilitate the transition to a more sustainable fashion and textile industry. We emphasize an analytical and design approach. We apply concepts and theories to specific case studies and we suggest ways to move towards a more sustainable fashion industry. We do so through challenges provided by fashion stakeholders for group work, in-class discussion and written assignments. Field trips are a key part of this course.

column1: This course equips you with tools of economic analysis that you can use to explain the distribution of health and healthcare, to evaluate spending on healthcare in aggregate and across treatments, and to evaluate health policies. It covers the main models used in economics to analyze determinants of health and health behaviour. It gives an understanding of concepts that you will apply in modules such as Health Technology Assessment, Public Health Economics and Global Health Economics, and it will help you understand how the material covered in these modules fits within the field of health economics.

• Evaluate the allocation of resources to and within the healthcare sector of the economy.
• Use models of rational and non-rational health behaviour to explain health variation, predict policy responses, and evaluate and design health-improving policies.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Today both developed and developing countries are searching for ways to foster economic growth. Innovation is considered to be a major force for economic growth. Firms are key actors when it comes to innovation. This course focuses on strategic firm decisions to innovate and to improve (innovation) performance. This course provides students with a comprehensive and advanced understanding of what innovation is. It gives insight into how factors that are external and internal to the firm contribute to innovation and how different types of firms (e.g. start-ups, small firms, large firms) innovate. Students also learn how innovation relates to growth, and what problems and actors are involved in the financing of innovation.

Overall, this course aims to provide understanding of what strategic decisions different types of firms can pursue to improve their innovation and growth performance. These strategic decisions include decisions to compete or collaborate, to export, to hire R&D workers and to contract external consultants.

To help students understand what innovation is, this course makes students familiar with main concepts, models and measures of innovation. Different innovation strategies are considered such as investing in R&D, patenting and introducing new products in the market. Furthermore, different theoretical perspectives are discussed (such as industrial organisation theory, evolutionary theory and the resource-based view) to provide students with insight into how different factors (external and internal) may contribute to innovation. Also, attention is paid to environmental innovation as a specific category of innovation. At industry level, patterns of innovation will be explored across the industry life cycle including first-mover (dis)advantages. Furthermore, different views are discussed on how innovative start-ups emerge and on why innovative firms choose to compete or collaborate. The role of labor mobility across firms for innovation will also be discussed as well as relevance of strategy consulting firms for innovation.

To figure out how innovation relates to growth, different types of growth are considered (sales, productivity, and employment). Attention is also paid to whether innovation and export are complementary firm strategies or rather substitutes for achieving firm growth. Regarding innovation financing, the focus is on understanding why investments in innovation are different from other means of investment; what sources of innovation financing depending on the stage on the innovation development are available; and what typical problems can arise in the process of investing in innovation. Moreover, three sources of finance for start-ups, namely venture capital, crowdfunding, and angel investors, are discussed in more detail.

After this course students will be familiar with concepts, ideas and theories related to the emergence and development of innovation and will be able to apply these to real life examples of innovating firms. Furthermore, students will have learned to understand and interpret empirical articles and to use its findings to develop strategic advice for different types of firms (e.g., small firms or large firms) such as on how to improve their innovation and growth performance.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

• Students are able to reproduce and interpret main concepts and characteristics of innovation; economic incentives for innovation; the organization and diffusion of innovation; the economic consequences of innovation; and the economic rationale of public policies for fostering innovation.

• Students apply concepts, theories and paradigms of innovation to analyze complex and current issues of a (business) economics nature such as industry developments and differences, the role of entrepreneurs in fostering innovation and standards races.

• Students analyze developments related to innovation (such as the emergence of industrial clusters and the increased globalization of specialized production) from several perspectives and then explain these developments based on the tension between those different perspectives.
• Students present the results of an industry or company analysis.

column1: Game theory is the study of strategic interaction. It is a structured approach to analysing situations in which there is room for cooperation and conflict. Such situations are abundant in markets, organisations, and beyond. This course provides an introduction to the use of game theory in a variety of contexts, in particular, bargaining and negotiation, contracting, and auctions. The emphasis of the course is on developing skills to approach problems in a structured and systematic manner. The course aims to promote a careful approach to strategic situations, without undue emphasis on technicalities. The reading material assigned for this course is illustrative of the sort of game-theoretic reasoning this course seeks to promote.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column2: • To understand the basic tools of game theory
• To develop skills for systematic, game theoretic, reasoning in decision making
• To apply game theoretic reasoning to bargaining and negotiation
• To understand how the design of contracts affects incentives
• To understand the mechanics of various types of auctions

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/112145,2023,Economics of Markets and Organisation,Engels,Erasmus School of Economics,,['dr. J Delfgaauw'],,Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: In modern societies, people specialize in productive activities and trade to obtain their complete consumption package. Trading occurs in markets, most production takes place in organisations. This makes markets and organisations crucial for our material well-being. Furthermore, organizations are an important source of social interactions and markets and organizations affect many environmental and social outcomes. This makes proper functioning of markets and organizations important, for our material and immaterial well-being. However, examples abound of markets and organizations that do not always function properly. Recognizing such situations, designing improvements, and implementing these will be a major part of your future jobs.

Economists have studied markets for a long time (think about Adam Smith’s invisible hand). This field is known as Industrial Organisation. More recently economists also study organisations (following Ronald Coase), in the field known as Organisational Economics. In both fields, outcomes of markets and organizations are determined by decisions and actions of people, which in turn depend on market design, organizational architecture, and management practices. Both fields have a microeconomic approach.

This course covers several main insights from the fields of Industrial Organisation (IO) and Economics of Organisations (OE), and lets you acquire skills that allow you to understand other parts of IO and OE.

Specialization in society yields two fundamental issues: coordination and motivation. Coordination revolves around decision-making and allocation: What is produced and consumed, by whom, and how? How are such decisions made? Motivation revolves around inducing people to act accordingly. As most production takes place in markets and organizations, coordination and motivation play an important role.

In the market, prices coordinate and motivate. This leads to optimal outcomes under some conditions but may fail to achieve desirable outcomes in other situations (due to market failures or non-desirable distributional outcomes). IO focuses predominantly on market power: How do firms acquire market power (entry / exit decisions, innovation, mergers and acquisitions, exclusive contracting), how does market power affect firm decision making (pricing, market entry, quantity, sourcing, innovation, etc.), how does this depend on market structure, and when and how can regulation improve functioning of markets?

The starting point of OE is that ‘the organisation’ is not a decision-making unit. Rather, production is shaped by the decisions of people within the organisation. People involved in an organisation will have different objectives, which may hamper cooperation. Furthermore, people may have different pieces of information regarding the optimal course of action. Hence, also within firms, coordination and motivation problems arise. This gives rise to questions of allocation of authority (the right to make decisions in particular situations) and leadership, job design, team-work, transfer pricing, (incentive) pay, subjective assessment of non-verifiable performance, social norms and organizational culture, reputational concerns and commitment, etc.

In short, OE and IO study how (i) choices of individuals in organisations and firms in markets affect the outcomes (in terms of production, performance, efficiency, and distribution), and (ii) how these choices are affected by organizational architecture, management practices, institutions, and market circumstances.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
