column1: In interactions between individuals, firms, and countries, their preferences are often not perfectly aligned. Negotiations are a common way for parties to come to mutually beneficial agreements. This course will cover the main principles of negotiations from a game-theoretic perspective.

Most lectures will begin with short experiments, allowing students to experience how economic models approach negotiations in research, which will then be discussed from a game-theoretic viewpoint. Additionally, the course will introduce the impact of cultural and behavioral factors on negotiations.

While theoretical and mechanism designs assume fully rational parties, it is crucial to consider psychological and cultural factors in real-world negotiations. Identifying the parties involved and their ability to act rationally in different circumstances is critical. The course will provide insights from guest lecturers with practical experience.
The course places a strong emphasis on formalizing negotiations, equipping students with tools to strategically analyze negotiations in the real-world and approach them with an analytic mindset.

• Students will learn in which ways behavioral and cultural factors can impact negotiations.

column1: Instructors:  Dr. F. Greimel (UvA), Dr. I.D. Lindner (VU), Dr. M.D. König (VU)

Many economic interactions are embedded in a network of social and economic relationships, shaping economic behavior and outcomes. This course covers economic models that have an explicit role for social and economic networks and social interactions in explaining economic behavior..

column2: • Part 1 (Weeks 1 and 2) provides a toolbox of theoretical concepts and modelling techniques. In this first part of the course we will work with a flipped classroom concept. This implies that we will ask you to watch parts of the massive open online lectures (MOOC) ""Social and Economic Networks"" of Matthew Jackson, Stanford University, in preparation of these meetings. This allows us to use the classroom sessions entirely for training purposes. During our live class sessions, we will summarize the findings, address your problems and discuss exercises.

• Part 2 (Weeks 3 and 4) provide an introduction to the statistical and econometric analysis of networks. We will discuss the empirical background of networks and their regularities, and introduce modern econometric tools to analyze them. The goal is to help students to understand outcomes and behaviors in networked societies, and to be able to evaluate real world policy instruments in this context. In preparation for these meetings, we will ask you to watch clips made available on canvas.

• Part 3 (from week 5 on) consists of student presentations and discussions of academic articles. These articles on social and economic networks will be tailored to the student's interest. We provide a reading list of selected papers as a guideline. However, you are welcome to suggest a paper yourself or ask us for advice.
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: After the course you should be able

column2: • to explain the importance of including network interactions in understanding economic behavior;
• to analyze different types of theoretical and empirical methodologies;
• to develop new lines of research on network economics, either theoretically or empirically.

column1: Over the past two decades or so, the economics shelves in bookshops have been filled with books that assess the state of capitalism. Examples include
* The Crisis of Democratic Capitalism by Martin Wolf, chief economics commentator Financial Times (2022),
* The Silent Takeover: Global Capitalism and the Death of Democracy by Noreena Hertz, professor UCL and author (2001)
* Capital in the Twenty-First Century by Thomas Piketty, professor EHESS and Paris School of Economics (2014)
* Ecocide: Kill the Corporation before It Kills Us by David Whyte, professor University of Liverpool (2020)
* Saving Capitalism from the Capitalists by Raghuram Rajan and Luigi Zingales, professors Chicago Booth School of Business (2002)
These books tend to applaud capitalism for its wealth creation, but also hold it responsible for growing inequality, ecological destruction and a malfunctioning democracy.

Corporations play a central role in virtually all these books, and so they will in this course. Corporations are companies with a specific legal personality, and are among the largest and most powerful companies in the world.
The aim of this course is to
* study how the corporate form emerged, and the role played by the state and the law in its emergence (including a study of the Dutch East India Company (VOC) and the Dutch Republic);

* study how corporations relate to markets and the public sector / state (including an assessment of the neoclassical division of and relationships between firms, markets and the public sector / state);
* investigate some of the claims about the role of corporations in generating inequality, ecological destruction and a malfunctioning democracy, and some of the solutions proposed.

Corporations are not the only organizations that we will study. The intention is to include some organizations that they shape and are shaped by them, with case studies of specific regulatory bodies, international standard setting organizations and investor-state dispute settlement mechanisms.
* neoclassical economics (e.g., Demsetz, Fama and Jensen);
* principal-agent theory (e.g., Holmström, Milgrom and Roberts);
* various forms of institutionalism (e.g., Hodgson and North);
* property rights / incomplete contracts approach (e.g., Grossman, Hart and Moore);
* corporate and comparative law (e.g., Hansmann and Kraakman and Pistor).
The course should be of interest to anyone who wants to have a better understanding of capitalism in the 21st century.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
• Understand and apply important concepts, tools and theories regarding the functioning of corporations and selected others organizations.
• Recognize situations where there may be conflicts of interest between persons or organizations, analyse the effects of the conflict of interest, and assess how interests could be (better) aligned.
• Recognize how specific institutional and organisational features are expressions of the conflicting interests and differences in power between persons or organizations.
• Critically assess literature on capitalism and corporations, from various perspectives

column1: <body>This year marks a radical break with last year, as the course content has been completely revised. Over the past two decades or so, the economics shelves in bookshops have been filled with books that assess the state of capitalism. These books tend to applaud capitalism for its wealth creation, but also hold it responsible for growing inequality, ecological destruction and a malfunctioning democracy. Corporations play a central role in virtually all these books, and so they will in this course. Corporations--or groups of corporations--are economic organizations with a specific legal personality, and are among the largest and most powerful firms in the world. Corporations are not the only organizations that we will study. The intention is to also look at some organizations that they shape and that shape them.</body>

column1: The course integrates insights from industrial organisation and strategy research while building upon a strong theoretical and empirical foundation.
1. First, the course discusses the concept of real options as a tool to make investment decisions under uncertainty.
2. The second part examines investments in research and development and advertising.
3. The last part analyzes strategies for particular types of goods and industries.

The topics are of interest to anyone with both a theoretical and a professional interest in strategic decision making at the firm level. As the course will use basic micro-theory, some knowledge in this field (monopoly, oligopoly, Stackelberg, perfect competition) and the associated mathematics (e.g., basic rules of differentiation such as the product rule and the chain rule) and statistics (probability theory) is required.

column1: The dramatic changes of the last century on the global scale in social, technological and environmental spheres put sustainability at the top of the international political agenda. The objective of this course is to provide students with an introduction to various approaches to the intersection of economics and sustainability. They will be motivated to think theoretically and practically on how to redesign current economic structures focusing on production, distribution and consumption to create a more sustainable world in the 21st century.

The theoretical conceptualization and operationalization of sustainability in Economics is a necessity to understand current changes in the global scale. The linear economic structures which are “take, make, dispose” models of production are replaced with circular economies to avoid resource waste and pollution. Institutions, policies and regulations, and continuous technological innovations play a vital role in realizing these new economic models. Green energy systems, which are introduced as a remedy for the problems of climate change, exemplify such technological innovations. Demographic dynamics and income inequality are other dimensions next to ecological concerns that should be addressed by coordinated actions at the international level for a sustainable future.

column1: In this course you get an overview of the economic aspects of several sustainable development goals. Each week is dealt with one topic related to SDG’s. The week starts with an one hour online lecture of Elbert Dijkgraaf (you can see it at the time you prefer, the recordings are available on Canvas). This introduces the topic. During the week you read the literature and a guest lecture is given on campus from an expert of the field with experience in the policy field. These are:
1. the former prime minister of the Netherlands Jan Peter Balkenende on SDG’s in general
2. director of LTO Hans van den Heuvel on food and agriculture
3. CEO of Acture Group Maudi Derks on the labor market
4. former Chief Innovation & Strategy Officer at Philips Jeroen Tas on innovation
5. former minister of care Tamara van Ark on health care

The expert gives a lecture with enough possibilities for interaction between you, the guest lecturer and Elbert Dijkgraaf. The guest lectures are on campus. You are expected to be present physically. The test will also be based on the contents presented in the guest lectures.

column1: In this course, we explore the science of well-being. Core questions that will be covered in this minor include: What makes whom happy? Do people make optimal choices to achieve their well-being goals? If not, how can people be supported in optimizing their well-being? How to create thriving organizations and societies with flourishing employees and citizens? And, how do happier and healthier citizens and employees stimulate better societal outcomes and company profits?

To answer these and other questions, this minor will use contemporary scientific evidence and offer multidisciplinary perspectives. The focus will be on topics related to economic behavior and phenomena. To learn about well-being, we will read recent journal scientific articles and watch videos from top researchers, and we will subsequently discuss these in the interactive lectures. In addition, you will conduct empirical analyses to explore the topic of well-being. The course material combines insights from applied economics (happiness economics, health economics, behavioral economics, and labor economics), business economics, psychology (positive psychology and organizational psychology), and sociology. Both objective and subjective measures of well-being will be discussed, with a focus on subjective well-being (happiness and life satisfaction).

The graded assessments are mostly individual assignments that focus on (1) developing ideas and interventions to improve well-being, (2) developing new insights on well-being using empirical data, and (3) critically reflecting on existing ideas about well-being. This minor helps you to develop some core skills, including the ability to work with and critically reflect on scientific literature, conduct data analysis, and develop interventions. This course provides future economists, policy-makers, business leaders, HR specialists, psychologists, and related professions with fundamental expertise in a world where well-being has become a primary theme in organizational and public policies. The course material is also relevant on a more personal level, as personal well-being is important in its own right and instrumental in reaching other goals in life such as a successful career.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: <body>Students from all educational backgrounds are admissible for this course. We encourage both students with an economic and non-economic background to participate in this minor. This minor is a 15 ECTS course for non-ESE students (5 modules; 10 weeks) and a 12 ECTS course for ESE students (4 modules; 8 weeks), but ESE students can optionally do the fifth module and earn 15 ECTS points. Students are expected to have a genuine interest in economic, psychological, sociological, and epidemiological approaches to well-being. Yet, students are NOT expected to have already been introduced to these fields. Active class particicipation in the interactive lectures is expected. As this minor is delivered in English, a sufficient command of the English language in speech and writing is needed. Students are expected to have an understanding of basic statistics, such as correlations and the basics of regression analysis. No textbooks or other course material has to be purchased for this course. The reading material will be provided by the lecturers after the start of the course. </body>

column1: <body>Analyses of the production, distribution, presentation and consumption of performing arts in different countries and in different economic and social systems are discussed. Attention will be paid to functions of the performing arts, programming, audience development, public and private financing, pricing theory, economic geography, marketing concepts, collaboration and economics and innovation in the popular music industry. Students will be trained in analyzing the establishment of cultural institutions in the performing arts. They will be encouraged to analyze and compare the economic aspects of performing arts in different countries. During the course two performing arts organizations will be visited. During guest lectures, students will get first hand experiences from specialists in the sector.</body>

column1: European countries are noted for the extent and depth of their welfare systems. Health care coverage is universal and predominantly publicly financed, while social protection against poverty and social exclusion tends to be substantially more generous than on other continents. The continued viability of the European social model is hotly debated. Some question whether generous welfare provisions are consistent with maintaining competitiveness in increasingly globalized markets. Others retort that social insurance eases transitions through the business cycle and public financing of health care constrains costs, including those falling on employers.

This course uses economics to cast light on these issues. Distinguishing between pursuit of equity and efficiency goals, it assesses whether equity gains through state involvement in the finance and provision of health care are achieved at the cost of efficiency, and it considers whether social protection slows the economy by distorting incentives or oils the wheels of growth by cushioning blows to the losers from creative destruction.

The course applies concepts – equity-efficiency trade-off, insurance, adverse selection, moral hazard, tax/benefit disincentives – introduced in Applied Microeconomics (FEB12001X) to analyze public policy on health care and social protection.

You must choose to focus on either health care or social protection. You will work, individually (for 50% of available marks) and with a group of 3 other students, sequentially through assignments on the chosen topic that feed into an assessed policy report, which accounts for 35% of the available marks. Writing such a report will help you acquire analytical skills of the type exercised by economists working in consultancies, government, NGOs and think tanks. You will be randomly assigned to a group that remains fixed throughout the duration of the course. Each group will be randomly assigned one European country (France, Denmark, Germany, Spain, or the Netherlands), and will study either health care or social protection in that country.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

• Students become more critical of debates about welfare policies in Europe
• Students are practiced in developing a logical, coherent argument.

column1: The course ‘Economics, welfare and distribution’ is intended to teach students the main economic theories and concepts and how to apply them in actual social and policy relevant issues. It is essential for public administration students to acquire knowledge of economics, as all great policy challenges and social problems have an economic angle as well. In order to shape policies and tackle these problems, knowledge of how to apply economic principles and instruments is essential.
We pay particular attention to theories and policy problems in the areas of micro-economics and welfare economics.

column1: In deze minor bestuderen wij allereerst díe werken van de filosofen en theologen die, ver vóór de totstandkoming van de economie als wetenschapsdiscipline, in hun werk hebben nagedacht over de wisselwerking tussen markt en moraliteit, tussen marktmechanismen en individuele drijfveren. In de eerst twee modules van deze minor lezen we de cruciale passages in hun werken in chronologische volgorde om de ontwikkelingsgang te kunnen achterhalen in het Westerse denken hieromtrent, vóórdat de economie zich als zelfstandige discipline ontvouwde.

Daarnaast willen wij achterhalen in hoeverre de intrinsieke verbondenheid tussen markt en moraal, tussen marktmechanismen en individuele drijfveren in meer recente literatuur wordt verondersteld. In hoeverre betonen economen zich, na ‘de uitvinding van hun vak’ schatplichtig aan de inzichten van filosofen en theologen die vóór Adam Smith over economische vraagstukken nadachten? In de derde module van deze minor zullen cruciale werken uit de recente economische geschiedenis alsook uit de christelijke (protestantse en katholieke) traditie besproken worden, waarin de voornoemde intrinsieke verbondenheid aan de orde is gesteld.

In de vierde module van deze minor worden de werken die in de vorige modules aan de orde zijn gekomen, samen met enige nieuwe teksten vanuit andere invalshoek bezien teneinde een antwoord te verkrijgen op een laatste fundamentele vraag, namelijk die naar het mensbeeld. Welk beeld van de mens is in de opvattingen over geld, eigendom, arbeid, handel, marktwerking, rente en fraude enerzijds en anderzijds over de menselijke drijfveren, deugden en ondeugden verondersteld? Hoe hangen deze samen? In de vierde module wordt gepoogd op deze vragen een bevredigend antwoord te vinden.</body>

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
• Kennis vergaren over de intellectuele (antieke en christelijke) traditie waarin economische vraagstukken aan de orde werden gesteld.
• Bewustwording van de impliciete mensbeelden die ten grondslag liggen aan ieder denken over economie, de markt of de marktwerking.
• Kennismaking met de filosofische en theologische traktaten van de premoderne tijd.
• Het bieden van een overzicht van de ontwikkelingen in het denken over de economie in de Reformatie.
• Duiding van de belangrijkste themata in het werk van Adam Smith over de markt, de economie en moraliteit.
• Studenten dieper inzicht bieden in de schatplichtigheid van Adam Smith aan eerdere filosofen en theologen.
• Een eerste kennismaking met de katholieke sociale leer en de protestantse doctrines over markt en marktwerking.
• Het verkrijgen van een antwoord op de vraag welk mensbeeld en welke opvatting over de menselijke waardigheid ten grondslag ligt aan de besproken literatuur.

• Het ontwikkelen van de vaardigheid om in artikelen, wetenschappelijke bijdragen en monografieën over economische vraagstukken, het impliciete mensbeeld dat aan deze werken ten grondslag ligt te kunnen ontwaren.

column1: De Educatieve minor biedt je de mogelijkheid om kennis te maken met het leraarschap. In combinatie met het bachelordiploma van je vakstudie levert de succesvolle afronding van de Educatieve minor een beperkte tweedegraads onderwijsbevoegdheid op (hiermee kun je jouw vak geven in de onderbouw van havo en vwo en het vmbo-t).

De Educatieve minor bestaat uit een samenhangend pakket van 30 ECTS, en bestaat voor de helft uit onderwijspraktijk en voor de helft uit een theoretisch deel bij het ICLON Leiden. Beide delen hangen nauw met elkaar samen en lopen parallel. Op maandag neem je deel aan onderwijsactiviteiten op de universiteit ICLON Leiden. Denk hierbij aan een college Vakdidactiek over het ontwerpen, uitvoeren en evalueren van lessen; een supervisiebijeenkomst waarin ervaringen uit gewisseld worden en verbonden worden met theorieën en modellen; of bijvoorbeeld gespreksvaardigheidstrainingen binnen het vak Pedagogiek.

De andere dagen kun je besteden aan het praktijkdeel van de opleiding: een stage op een school voor voortgezet onderwijs. Daarnaast werk je aan opdrachten voor de vakken binnen de Educatieve minor, bestudeer je theorie, bereid je je lessen voor, kijk je werk van leerlingen na, etcetera. Je krijgt veel individuele begeleiding, vanuit het ICLON en op je stageschool.

De Educatieve minor bestaat uit een samenhangend pakket van 30 ECTS, en bestaat voor de helft uit onderwijspraktijk en voor de helft uit een theoretisch deel bij het ICLON Leiden. Beide delen hangen nauw met elkaar samen en lopen parallel. Op maandag neem je deel aan onderwijsactiviteiten op de universiteit ICLON Leiden. Denk hierbij aan een college Vakdidactiek over het ontwerpen, uitvoeren en evalueren van lessen; een supervisiebijeenkomst waarin ervaringen uit gewisseld worden en verbonden worden met theorieën en modellen; of bijvoorbeeld gespreksvaardigheidstrainingen binnen het vak Pedagogiek.

De andere dagen kun je besteden aan het praktijkdeel van de opleiding: een stage op een school voor voortgezet onderwijs. Daarnaast werk je aan opdrachten voor de vakken binnen de Educatieve minor, bestudeer je theorie, bereid je je lessen voor, kijk je werk van leerlingen na, et cetera. Je krijgt veel individuele begeleiding, vanuit het ICLON en op je stageschool.
Zie voor alle informatie de website van het ICLON Leiden.

column1: In Education for Social Change, student teams research social educational challenges from primary school to university, then build educational interventions to address this. To support the projects, an Education Track provides broad philosophical educational training and a Reflection Track grounds students’ learning through journaling, peer-reflection and workshops. Education for Social Change premises that education is transdisciplinary: multiple disciplines constitute its contents, interdisciplinary angles feed its processes, while education gives meaning to undisciplined experiences of the world. Education for Social Change provides a five-level structure for understanding this transdisciplinary whole.

In the Education Track, students encounter problem-based learning, embodied learning, jigsawing, object-based learning, and design-based learning. The track also offers lectures as a safe space for students to discover new philosophical approaches with experts.

The Project Track forms the backbone of Education for Social Change. Under the guidance of a project supervisor, student teams analyse a real-world education problem in a primary, secondary or tertiary education with a methodology of their choosing, then devise a relevant educational intervention that follows appropriate education design principles, offers answers to their research problem, and can lead to implementation.
The Reflection Track accompanies the Project and Education Tracks in a step-by-step build-up, consisting in:

column2: • Two workshops: one focused on cognitive and individual reflection, the other on group and societal reflection.
• An Articulated Learning Reflection, drawing a learning arc based on student diaries.
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
• Students will demonstrate understanding of key thinkers upon whose work the biggest educational innovations of the 20th & 21st century were based.
• Students will analyse classroom experiments from around the world as inspiration for their own project design.

• Students will identify the rationale behind and practice learning with problem-based learning, embodied learning, jigsawing, case-based learning, closed reading, object-based learning and design-based learning.
• Students will make personal learning goals and measure progress on those goals throughout their learning journey.
• Students will reflect on their own learning and practice through a comprehensive reflection track.
• Students will apply their theoretical knowledge to an educational case study.
• Students will practice working in a problem-oriented project work environment, including group collaboration skills.

• Students will design an educational innovation in response to a social problem in primary, secondary or tertiary education that intervenes appropriately at the cognitive, individual, group, society and global levels.

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/111101,2023,Effectieve bestanddelen van psychologische behandelingen in het ziekenhuis,Nederlands,Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences,,['dr. A. van t Spijker'],,Inhoud

column2: <head><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column3: In de onderwijsgroepen wordt gewerkt met verschillende vignetten van somatische zieke patiënten (met of zonder psychische problemen). De hoorcolleges bieden elke week verbreding van het betreffende onderwerp. In de eerste week wordt aandacht besteed aan diagnostiek van psychische problemen bij somatisch zieke patiënten. Psychische problematiek kan het gevolg zijn van ziekte of het ziek zijn en het kan een complicerende factor zijn bij een somatische ziekte. Verder komt het verschil tussen stepped-care en matched-care aan bod. De voorwaarden voor beide worden besproken evenals de voor- en nadelen van deze twee methodieken.

De tweede week gaat over laagdrempelige en kortdurende behandelingen, zoals zelfhulp en e-mental health. Er zijn vele vormen van zelfhulp, zoals zelfhulpgroepen, zelfmanagementprogramma’s en bibliotherapie. Maar kan een behandeling zonder therapeut wel werken? De opkomst van nieuwe media biedt nieuwe mogelijkheden voor de hulpverlening. Zo wordt steeds vaker gebruikgemaakt van internet, e-mail, sms, chat en games in de psychologische hulpverlening. Hoe gaat dat?

In week drie komt een aantal vormen van psychologische behandeling bij somatische patiënten aan bod. Het doel is klachtvermindering en het verbeteren van de eigen gezondheid en kwaliteit van leven. We gaan in op cognitieve therapie, en daarbinnen specifiek op het gevolgenmodel. Op welke theorieën zijn deze behandelingen gebaseerd? Wat zijn de basisprincipes? Hoe werken deze therapieën? Wanneer kunnen ze worden ingezet?

Het beheersbaar houden van de kosten in de zorg staat hoog op de agenda van de overheid en de zorgverzekeraars. Dat betekent dat er wordt gekeken naar de verhouding tussen de effecten en de kosten van een behandeling. In week vier gaat het daarom over kosteneffectiviteit. Een ander onderwerp in deze week is de rol van non-specifieke factoren (zoals de duur van de therapie en de therapeutische relatie) bij psychologische behandelingen. Wat zijn deze factoren en hoe kan je ze beïnvloeden zodat een behandeling zo effectief mogelijk is?

In de vijfde week zijn we aanbeland bij meer intensievere behandelingen, zoals psychofarmacologie. Psychologen schrijven zelf geen pillen voor, maar het is belangrijk dat zij op de hoogte zijn van medische behandelmogelijkheden, hoe deze werken en wat de voor- en nadelen zijn.

Het practicum bestaat uit vier sessies, waarin je met je groep een (simulatie)patiënt met reuma en somberheidsklachten begeleidt. Je oefent o.a. het voeren van een intakegesprek en verschillende psychologische interventietechnieken. Op die manier doe je zoveel mogelijk ervaring op met technieken die je als therapeut kunt gebruiken. Ook heb je na afloop een overzicht van de verschillende fasen van het therapieproces (intake, behandelingsfase en afronding) en de specifieke eisen die elke fase stelt aan de therapeut.
Vanwege beperkte capaciteit kunnen maximaal 50 studenten deelnemen aan dit blok.

column2: <head><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column3: Dit keuzevak is bedoeld voor studenten psychologie die willen weten hoe psychologische behandelingen werken bij patiënten met lichamelijke klachten. Het is een introductie op behandelingen die door medisch psychologen kunnen worden ingezet. De medisch psycholoog werkt vanuit de visie dat somatische, psychologische en sociale aspecten bij elke aandoening een rol spelen. Vragen die o.a. aan bod komen zijn: Waarom zouden somatische patiënten eigenlijk gebaat kunnen zijn bij een psychologische behandeling? Voor welke patiënten is een psychologische behandeling geschikt (of noodzakelijk)? Welke vorm van psychologische behandeling biedt je een patiënt aan? Hoe motiveer je patiënten voor psychologische begeleiding? Wanneer kies je voor een psychologische behandeling en wanneer voor medicamenteuze therapie? Begin je standaard bij elke patiënt aan een eerstelijns psychologische behandeling, of kies je op basis van de kenmerken van de patiënt gelijk voor een tweede- of derdelijns zorgaanbod? Kan je nieuwe media en psychologische zorg combineren? Zo ja, hoe doe je dat? Werkt een psychologische behandeling eigenlijk wel? Zo ja, hoe werkt dat dan? Is het de theorie die ten grondslag ligt aan de therapie of is het de aandacht die je als cliënt krijgt van de therapeut? Hoe bepaal je of je behandeling heeft gewerkt? Na afloop van het blok heeft de student kennis opgedaan over indicatiecriteria voor verschillende psychologische behandelingen (voornamelijk psychologische interventies) die door medisch psychologen worden ingezet, de kenmerken en werkwijze van verschillende psychologische behandelingen en de effectieve bestanddelen ervan. Studenten kennen het principe van stepped-care en kunnen de voor- en nadelen daarvan uitleggen. Studenten zijn in staat om deze kennis toe te passen op praktische casuïstiek van patiënten met sterk uiteenlopende lichamelijke problemen die tijdens de onderwijsgroepen en practica aan bod komt.

Dit keuzevak is zowel interessant en geschikt voor studenten die de minor Medische Psychologie hebben gevolgd als voor studenten die (nog) weinig kennis hebben van het vakgebied van de medische psychologie.

column5: De student kan uitleggen wat de invloed van somatische aandoeningen kan zijn op het psychisch functioneren (en vice versa).
De student kan de stepped-care methodiek met de matched-care methodiek vergelijken.

De student kan aangeven welke verschillende behandelingen medisch psychologen kunnen gebruiken bij somatisch zieke patiënten met psychische problemen, zoals (online) zelfhulp, cognitieve gedragstherapie en psychofarmacologie.
De student kan aangeven wat de mogelijkheden en onmogelijkheden zijn van verschillende behandelingen die medisch psychologen kunnen inzetten bij somatisch zieke patiënten met psychische problemen
De student kan onderbouwen voor welke psychologische behandeling het beste gekozen kan worden bij een gefingeerde casus over een somatisch zieke patiënt met psychische problemen.
De student kan de basistechnieken van de cognitieve gedragstherapie benoemen en zelf toepassen bij een simulatiepatiënt.
De student kan benoemen en toelichten welke factoren bij psychologische behandelingen werkzaam zijn.

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/111176,2023,Electrophysiology,Engels,Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences,,['dr. MI Sahan', 'ing. CJC Tieman', 'K de Groot, MSc', 'SKS Singh']",,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Psychophysiology assumes that cognitive, emotional, social and behavioral processes are mirrored in physiological processes in the human body. Electrophysiology focusses on electrophysiological processes, like activity in the brain, the heartbeat and muscle activity. It can be used to study all kind of mental events, like emotions and thoughts. With electroencephalography (EEG), we can visualize the activity in the brain, electrocardiography (ECG) investigates activity of the heart and electromyography (EMG) records activity of the muscles. In this practical training all three techniques will be covered. There will be lectures in which the theoretical background will be explained and there will be hands-on training sessions.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
• you know how to measure EEG/ERP, ECG, and EMG, and you can explain the procedure;
• you know how to analyze EEG/ERP-data, and you can explain the procedure;
• you can write a report on a scientific electrophysiological experiment, according to a scientific format.

column1: This course focuses on the following key question: How can we responsibly embed digital technologies in healthcare systems? Digital technologies have the potential to solve some of the pressing contemporary healthcare challenges. This potential can only be fulfilled if the unique challenges that these technologies bring can be overcome. The future healthcare manager/decision maker/policy maker must therefore be able to critically reflect upon digital technologies in healthcare and understand the critical success factors to their implementation and adoption.

This course will teach student to plan and manage the responsible implementation and adoption of digital technologies in healthcare. The course will introduce students to innovation and implementation science which are interdisciplinary fields that contribute to our understanding of how technologies are introduced to and taken up in regular use by practitioners and policymakers.

Specific questions we will address in this course are: What are the key challenges of implementing digital technologies in healthcare? Who are important stakeholders in the implementation and adoption process? What kind of impacts can digital technologies have on clinical practice? What does it mean to embed digital technologies responsibly?

The examination of the course consists of a written reflection on policy advice on digital technologies in healthcare and a written implementation and adoption plan. Students will also have a formative assessment (pass/fall) during which they pitch their implementation and adoption plan.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
• Students can critically reflect upon an advice about the responsible use of digital technologies in healthcare
• Students can identify the main challenges of the implementation and adoption process of digital technologies in healthcare
• Students can reflect upon and apply implementation and adoption models
• Students can pitch and write an implementation and adoption plan for the responsible embedding of digital technologies in healthcare

column1: This course will provide a global outline of how the human body develops from a fertilised egg. From an embryological perspective, human prenatal development can be grossly divided into three periods, i.e. the early pre-embryonic period covering the first two weeks, the embryonic period from 2 to 8 weeks after conception, and the foetal period that extends from the 9th week to birth (usually at 38 weeks after conception). The early period is characterised by cell multiplication, implantation in the uterine wall, and the development of extra-embryonic tissues, such as the placenta and the amniotic membrane, which also arise from the fertilised egg. During this period, the cells that will give rise to the embryo remain undifferentiated. After two weeks of development, these undifferentiated cells are arranged in a disk-like structure. During the embryonic period this disk will transform into a small human body (~4 cm in length) with almost all organs and body parts present in a recognizable form. The foetal period is characterised by growth of the body and maturation of the organs. An important topic of this course will be the transformations during the 3rd and 4th week of development, when the early embryo transforms from a disk-like structure into a cylindrical embryo, in which most body parts and organs are formed in rudimentary form.

column2: <head><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column3: After completing this course you will have basic knowledge of:

column5: Development of primordial germ cells, genital tract development and sexual differentiation
Early pre-implantation development
Sizes and gross appearance of the developing human body throughout pregnancy.

Development of the basic body plan, including the development of the major germinal layers (ectoderm, mesoderm, and endoderm), the development of the body axes (cranio-caudal, left-right, dorso-ventral), the role of key embryonic events, i.e. gastrulation, neurulation and embryonic folding, and the role of temporary embryonic structures such as the primitive streak, the notochord, neural crest, pharyngeal arches, somites, and lateral plate mesoderm

The role of signalling molecules, such as Sonic hedgehog, BMPs and Wnts, and transcription regulators such as the Hox family of proteins in the regulation of developmental processes such as the development of limbs and the vertebral column.
How abnormalities in embryonic signalling cascades may result in congenital malformations

column2: <head><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column4: In this course we study emerging economies. This has become a popular theory since the end of the Cold War in the late 1980s. What exactly do we mean by emerging economies? Why and how do they develop? What are the effects of emerging economies on the global division of labour? This course takes a historical approach because the concept of emerging economies. Throughout world history we can discern the rise and decline of markets and economies. Before c. 1800 the economic centre of the world was firmly in Eastern Asia, but shifted to Western Europe and North America during the Industrial Revolution. We are now perhaps witnessing a new shift with the rise of the BRIC-countries: Brazil, Russia, India and China. These important economic processes also change the balance of economic and military power in the world and thus the system of international relations.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
• Students will be able to assess the concept of emerging economies.
• Students will be able to compare various cases of economic 'emergence' since ca. 1800 and in different world regions.
• Students will be able to write a speech, prepare a political programme, conduct a formal debate and compose an opinionated essay on economic development.
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Instructors: Dr E. Eiling (UvA) and Dr A. Andonov (UvA)

Empirical Asset Pricing studies the time-series and cross-sectional behavior of asset prices. This field is highly relevant for research in financial economics. Empirical asset pricing research is the basis for any study in investments and essential part of many financial management applications such as risk management, portfolio selection, and performance evaluation. This course focuses on the topics listed below and, during the lectures, we will discuss the main empirical findings as well as the methodological issues along with a few insights into the main theoretical models. The lectures will also include student presentations of selected academic articles. Students will also complete an individual referee report assignment and they will work on a term project in pairs. The objective of these term projects is to replicate empirical asset pricing papers and the students will present their key results during the last lecture.
• Cross-section of stock returns
• Investments and consumption-based asset pricing Mutual funds and asset management
• The cross-section and time series of currency returns
• Mutual funds and asset management industry
• Private equity and alternative assets
Students should have an understanding of, ability to apply, judge, and communicate:

column2: • The cross-section and time series of currency returns.
• Asset management industry: Mutual funds and alternative investments.
• Gain in-depth and systematic knowledge of empirical asset pricing.
• Discuss empirical anomalies to the CAPM and the current debates about their causes.
• Discuss the implications of multi-factor asset pricing.
• Become familiar with empirical asset pricing methods.
• Test multi‐factor models on the cross‐section of stock returns.
• Test for time-series return predictability in equity investments.
• Discuss empirical anomalies to the CAPM and the current debates about their causes.
• Discuss the implications of multi-factor asset pricing.
• Communicate effectively and at a high level, both in writing and verbally
• Collect and combine historical data on assets and returns.
• Demonstrate self-direction and originality in resolving asset pricing problems.
• Respect and practice matters of scientific integrity, ethics, responsible data management and privacy.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Instructors: Dr. T. Eisert (EUR), Prof. Dr. P.A.E. Koudijs (EUR),  Prof. Dr. P. Verwijmeren (EUR), Dr. S. Obernberger (EUR)

Empirical corporate finance has traditionally studied the financing decisions of firms. More recently, the field has broadened into, among other things, labor economics, and household financial decision making.

This course provides an introduction into the empirical research into some of the fundamental themes in empirical corporate finance, as well as a number of newer topics. In each of the six lectures, we focus on a specific topic. We will discuss the state-of-the-art of the current literature and the methodological challenges faced by researchers to draw causal inferences from observational data.
During the course, students will work on an (empirical) research proposal.
1. The firm, the corporation and limited liability

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/114235,2023,Empirical Legal Studies,Nederlands,Erasmus School of Law,,['dr.mr. WJ Kortleven', 'mr.dr. NL Holvast', 'MT de Ruiter', 'prof.dr. P Mascini']",,"Inhoud

column2: <head><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column4: Dit vak biedt een inleiding in de rechtssociologie, waarin de wereld van het recht centraal staat. Die wereld gaan we mede aan de hand van de actualiteit verkennen op empirische wijze. Daarbij laten we zien welke sociale (f)actoren het recht beïnvloeden en –omgekeerd– welke rol het recht in de samenleving speelt. Aandacht wordt besteed aan wetgevingspraktijken en zo wordt inzicht gegeven in de feitelijke processen die schuilgaan achter de teksten die in het Staatsblad verschijnen. Tevens worden inkijkjes geboden in de wereld van de advocatuur en die van de rechterlijke macht. Daarbij laten we zien hoe die werelden veranderen in relatie tot de algemene veranderingen die in de samenleving als geheel aanwijsbaar zijn. Een belangrijk aandachtspunt is ook het thema handhaving, waarbij wordt ingegaan op vraagstukken rond effectiviteit van wetgeving en regelnaleving.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
• inzicht geven in de wisselwerking van recht en samenleving
• inzicht geven in de positie en de rol van de pijlers van de rechtsstaat, te weten wetgeving, advocatuur, rechterlijke macht en handhavingsorganisaties in de moderne samenleving
• inzicht geven in theoretische en empirische bevindingen van de rechtssociologie
• inzicht geven in de mogelijkheden en beperkingen om met behulp van juridische interventies maatschappelijke problemen op te lossen
• het leren schrijven van een werkstuk waarin een kritische reactie gegeven wordt op een maatschappelijk en juridisch actueel thema

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Bij Empirical Legal Studies (ELS) bestuderen we het recht vanuit een empirisch perspectief. Het vak is niet gericht op het positieve recht, maar de wisselwerking tussen het recht en de samenleving staat centraal. Wij stellen vragen als “Waar komt deze wet- en regelgeving vandaan?”, “In hoeverre wordt deze wet- en regelgeving nageleefd” en “Op welke wijze komt een rechter tot een uitspraak?”. Kortom: tijdens dit vak verschuift de belangstelling van law in the books naar law in action. Bij ELS worden sociologische, maar ook psychologische, antropologische en (in mindere mate) economische methoden en inzichten gebruikt om het recht te bestuderen. We kijken naar wat er van het recht terecht komt in de alledaagse maatschappelijke werkelijkheid.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
• Het empirische perspectief op het recht identificeren en toepassen.
• Empirisch wetenschappelijke onderzoeksmethoden herkennen, benoemen en met elkaar vergelijken.
• Sociale velden en sociale normen die interacteren met recht(snormen) in de samenleving herkennen, benoemen, interpreteren en toepassen.
• De wijze waarop geschillen ontstaan, zich ontwikkelen en aflopen herkennen, benoemen, interpreteren en verklaren en factoren die hier invloed op hebben herkennen en benoemen.
• De maatschappelijke ontwikkelingen op het gebied van de juridische professie en opleiding tot jurist, waaronder digitalisering, herkennen, benoemen, interpreteren en toepassen.

• Psychologische processen waaronder (v)oor(oor)delen die actoren in het strafproces beïnvloeden en van invloed zijn op het ontstaan van rechterlijke dwalingen herkennen, benoemen, interpreteren en toepassen.
• Het maatschappelijk krachtenveld rondom de totstandkoming van wetgeving herkennen, benoemen, interpreteren en verklaren.
• Verschillende stijlen van toezicht en handhaving en de effectiviteit daarvan herkennen, benoemen, interpreteren, toepassen en evalueren.
• De wijze waarop (rechts)regels en de overheid gedrag van burgers beïnvloeden herkennen, benoemen, interpreteren en toepassen.
• De sociale werking en effectiviteit van wetgeving herkennen, benoemen, interpreteren, verklaren en evalueren.
• Sociaalwetenschappelijke en empirische inzichten gebruiken bij het beschrijven en analyseren van een actuele casus of onderwerp.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: During this course, you will get acquainted with a toolbox consisting of the most commonly applied statistical and econometric techniques to carry out empirical research in finance. It starts with the basics of linear regression, and continues with models for panel data and limited dependent variables (dichotomous; categorical; ordered).
Empirical methods covered (particular selection can vary per academic year):

Linear cross-sectional/time-series regression; diagnostic tests; event study analysis; endogeneity; dummy variables; non-linearities; fixed effects/random effects panel regression; probit modeling; principal components analysis (PCA); quantile regression.

The course consists of lectures and group assignments. The various methods and applications will be presented in the lectures; with the group assignments you will get familiar with applying the techniques to (real-life) data sets.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
• Get familiar with the most commonly applied empirical methods for finance.
• Get familiar with how to model cross-sectional, panel, and limited dependent variables in empirical finance.
• Get familiar with caveats related to empirical-finance models, such as omitted variables bias, endogeneity, heteroskedastic/serially correlated error terms, non-linear relations, etc.
• Get familiar with modelling, model interpretation, and empirical methods by doing small-scale (empirical) assignments.
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: The course aims to deepen students’ theoretical expertise in the domain of consumer engagement. It aims to touch upon different practices that can be used to increase consumer engagement. The main goal is to create a basic understanding of consumer engagement which can be deepen throughout the master thesis.

This course consists of lectures and tutorials. These are organized on 7 themes: 1) consumer engagement, 2) branding and identity, 3) consumer decision making, 4) advertising, 5) storytelling, 6) branded content and 7) influencer marketing. For each theme, theoretical frameworks will be discussed and applied to real-life cases.

In this course, students will be invited to challenge main concepts within consumer engagement and marketing communication. Moreover, they will analyse campaigns that companies employ from a theoretical standpoint and research new trends. The main goal of the course is to empower students with theoretical frameworks that can be applied to academic research and various real-life case studies.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Students have advanced their knowledge, understanding and awareness of:
- State-of-the art theory and research on consumer engagement, branding and consumer decision making
- Processing frameworks of advertising, storytelling, branded content and influencer marketing
- Present academic literature in a written and oral form
- Synthesize academic literature on a topic related to consumer engagement
- Apply theoretical frameworks to academic research and real-life campaigns</body>

column1: Deze cursus bestaat uit tien wekelijkse bijeenkomsten van 3 uur. Het afsluitende examen vindt na afloop van de cursus plaats op een vooraf vastgestelde datum (zie onderstaande planning). Aan het einde van de cursus is de stof van één cursusniveau behandeld.
Wat leer je tijdens de cursus Engels B2.1?

Een cursus Engels bestaat uit tien wekelijkse bijeenkomsten van 3 uur. Deze cursus voor academische doeleinden omvat alle belangrijke vaardigheden en taalaspecten die nodig zijn voor het verbeteren van de Engels taalvaardigheid in zowel academische als alledaagse situaties. De volgende onderwerpen komen aan bod:

Tijdens de cursus ligt de focus mede op het gebruik en verbeteren van grammaticale structuren, zodat je in diverse situaties kunt communiceren. Bovendien heeft deze cursus een interactief karakter. Het eindniveau van de cursus is B2.1 volgens het Common European Framework of Reference (CEFR).

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Tijdens de cursus bouw je verder op eerder vergaarde kennis en ligt de focus naast het uitbreiden van de grammaticale kennis, ook op het vergroten van de bestaande woordenschat, zodat je in diverse situaties leert communiceren. Bovendien heeft deze cursus een interactief karakter. Het eindniveau van de cursus is B2.1 volgens het Common European Framework of Reference (CEFR).

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
• Het Language & Training Centre organiseert driemaal per jaar cursussen Engels (oktober-december/januari-maart/april-juni).
• Deze cursus is toegankelijk voor cursisten met een academische achtergrond (hbo/wo).
• Het cursusmateriaal is bij de cursusprijs inbegrepen. In de bevestigingsbrief die je ontvangt als de cursus doorgaat, informeren we je over de details.

• Van de deelnemers wordt verwacht dat zij naast de wekelijkse contacturen ongeveer drie uur per week aan zelfstudie besteden. Dit is een richtlijn; sommige cursisten zullen mogelijk meer tijd nodig hebben.
• De groepen zijn klein: minimaal 11 en maximaal 16 deelnemers. Let op! Bij te weinig inschrijvingen behoudt het LTC het recht om de cursus te annuleren.

• Aanwezigheid bij de lessen is niet verplicht, wel raadzaam. Gedurende de cursus zul je presentaties moeten geven en deel moeten nemen aan discussies. Om voor het spreekgedeelte van de cursus te kunnen slagen, dien je daarom voldoende aanwezig te zijn.
• De cursus wordt afgesloten met een schriftelijk examen. Met dyslexie kun je extra tijd krijgen voor dit examen. Vergeet niet om je dyslexieverklaring met je verzoek naar ltc@eur.nl te sturen.
• Je ontvangt een certificaat als je voor alle onderdelen van de cursus een Pass hebt gehaald.
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/112232,2023,Enterprise Information Systems,Engels,Erasmus School of Economics,,['drs. RHRM Aernoudts'],,Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Why do students need to understand the context of Information Systems within enterprises?

column2: • Information Systems (IS) have enormous strategic value so when they are not working even for a short time, an organization cannot function;
• The Life Cycle Costs (acquisition, operation, security, and maintenance) of enterprise systems is considerable;

• It is therefore essential to manage information systems properly. The planning, organizing, implementing, operating, and controlling of the infrastructures and the organization's portfolio of applications must be done with great skill;
• To obtain awareness of different types of Information Systems and different roles that different systems play in organizations;
• To gain awareness and knowledge of ERP, CRM, SCM and E-Commerce;
• To be able to recognize opportunities that are enabled by information technology and to be able to decide to what extent information technology is needed within an organization.
• To understand critical issues in Information Systems, such as security, project risks and outsourcing of Information Systems. Be able to identify these issues and deal with them.

• The course also helps students digest why most ERP systems do not live up to its acronym of planning resources for the enterprise. Students should be able to critically evaluate the following questions:
• What is ERP? What is EIS? How do People and Process come into Technology?
• What are the similarities and differences between ERP and EIS?
• How do Enterprise Systems affect Accountants and Economists?
• How can economic theory help explain the effects of information technology on organizations and value chains?
• What benefits have been realized by certain companies by implementing Information Technology?
• How can information technology be an enabler but also be an inhibitor for realizing an organization its strategy?
• What are advantages and disadvantages from new technologies as Big Data and Blockchain
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
• Students have knowledge of the use of Enterprise information systems within organisations.
• Students have knowledge of different applications of Enterprise information systems in organisations.
• Students have knowledge of different economic theories that enable them to explain and understand the effects of the use of information systems within organisations.
• Students have knowledge of how research is performed with regard to information systems.
• Students are able to analyse and identify different situations in which technology is able to help an organization succeed in its goals.
• Students are able to use different theories to explain how the use of technology may affect organisations.
• Students are able to critically analyse and report on research findings from a project they perform in a logical and consistent way.
• Students are able to present their research essay as well as answer critical questions about this essay in a convincing manner.
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/113784,2023,Entrepreneurial Challenge,Engels,Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,"['dr. FPH Jaspers', 'MR Thomaz Viana Reis']",,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: The course Entrepreneurial Challenge is an intensive module. You will explore and experience what it entails to start a new and ambitious company. You will come to understand that not only existing businesses, but also new businesses require management. As you are enrolled in the Master in Management program, it is important to understand that without businesses there is nothing to manage, and without entrepreneurs there would be (and will be) no businesses. Furthermore, many RSM graduates will – at some stage in their career – consider entrepreneurship as a serious career opportunity.

In line with RSM’s mission statement we will focus on social entrepreneurship, supporting one of the SDG’s which will be introduced elaborately. The course contains a concise introduction to the domain of social entrepreneurship theory and research. To apply the key concepts and tools in a real-life setting, teams will develop and revise their own start-up opportunities and explore viable business models in the field of social entrepreneurship. Entrepreneurship is about turning unmet needs and unsolved problems into viable economic activity. The essence of entrepreneurship has been described as ‘the pursuit of opportunity without regard to the resources currently controlled.’ Entrepreneurship starts with the discovery of promising opportunities. Understanding the origins of such opportunities is key for start-up entrepreneurs and existing companies alike to develop business models that will effectively create and capture value from the identified opportunities. Entrepreneurship is not just a process, but also a mindset. In this module you develop that mindset by exploring the first stages of the process: the identification and evaluation of opportunities and the search for viable business models.

The course requires that all students actively participate in the classes. In addition, we expect the students to spend additional time per day on class preparation by reading the literature and doing project work. This course is a crash course into the (theoretical) foundations of entrepreneurship and a pressure cooker module for developing a business case and presenting it in front of a jury; both of them require your full dedication.

The sessions in this module will differ in nature, ranging from student presentations, to workshops, to feedback sessions. During these meetings, a proactive and constructive atmosphere will be stimulated: a collaborative, open approach is needed to help each other and to learn from each other. The instructor in this course will serve primarily as a coach, rather than as a teacher. His main concern is to guide the group and the teams through the necessary thought and work processes.
Attendance of all university sessions is compulsory

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

• You will come to understand that new venture creation is a process to systematically turn business model assumptions into knowledge, and that this learning process typically involves business model change.

• You will come to understand the complexity of the new venture creation process, i.e. you will be able to explain and illustrate that its key steps, activities and challenges are highly interrelated, interdisciplinary, unpredictable, heterogeneous, and iterative.
• You will develop the capability to construct, evaluate, and refine business models for new ventures.
• You will develop the capability to set-up effective and efficient research designs to turn critical assumptions into knowledge.
• You will develop the capability to document your business modelling process concisely, with clarity, logical flow, and coherence.

• You will develop the capability to discuss and present your new venture creation process in a variety of contexts, i.e. in your multidisciplinary student team, during the plenary workshops, in a feedback session with startup coaches and entrepreneurs, and in front of an expert panel at the final presentation session.

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/112166,2023,Entrepreneurial Finance,Engels,Erasmus School of Economics,,['dr. F Core'],,Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: This course aims at providing students with an overview of opportunities and challenges faced by entrepreneurs in young, high-growth ventures.
The course is divided into three parts.
In the first part, the course explores valuation methods for entrepreneurial ventures (e.g. DCF analysis and multiples) and how to assess their growth potential.

The second part of the course focuses on obtaining external funding: it studies the advantages and disadvantages of different funding players (e.g. angel financing, Venture Capital, crowdsourcing), furthermore it explores the design of financing instruments (e.g. staging, convertible instruments).
Lastly, the third part of the course describes and investigates exit strategies and their related costs and benefits (e.g. acquisitions, IPOs).

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
• Understanding the main challenges faced by entrepreneurs in the early stages of their ventures, especially in uncertain and innovative streams of business.
• Understanding the factors considered by investors when selecting which entrepreneurial project to fund.
• Analyzing the benefits and costs associated with different sources of funding, both for the entrepreneurs and financiers.
• Understanding the various ways investors and entrepreneurs can exit from their ventures and monetize their investments.

• By the end of the course, students will gain an overview of the process of starting, funding, growing and exiting an entrepreneurial project. The course will have them equipped with the tools to better understand the financing of innovation and the venture capital industry.

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/115019,2023,Entrepreneurial Firms and Governance,Engels,Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,['dr. AC Brown'],,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: The aim of the course is to introduce students to theories of corporate governance. The course will cover the topics on corporate board, ownership structure, IPOs, institutional investor, regulatory reforms, stakeholder involvement and corporate social responsibility. Some of the theory included are: Agency theory; Transaction costs economics; Stakeholder theory; Stewardship theory; Institutional theory; Political theory as well as Network governance and case studies/ examples real life corporate stories.
The course will include lectures combining theory, cases and live examples including a project, for students to analyze, discuss and present on during seminar sessions and workshops.

Students will be expected to be active participants in exploring real instances of effect of governance issues on actual entrepreneurial firms of all sizes but with particular attention to smaller and family enterprises.

Students will be encouraged to make use of provided articles, case studies but also to explore themes and topics by accessing news sites, databases and public informational depositories in a guided but self-proactive environment

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: The ability to critically reflect on and provide well-grounded analysis of these elements crucial for small, and medium businesses
The ability to analyse the main elements of good corporate governance

column1: De Entrepreneurial Challenge is een kort en krachtig vak. In teamverband verken en ervaar je wat het is om een nieuw en ambitieus bedrijf te starten. Je leert dat management niet alleen management nodig is in bestaande bedrijven, maar ook geldt in nieuwe, jonge bedrijven. Veel van de lessen blijken bovendien niet alleen van toepassing op nieuwe bedrijven, maar zijn ook relevant voor het management in volwassen bedrijven en organisaties.

In lijn met de missie van RSM – A force for positive change – richt de challenge zich meer in het bijzonder op het het starten van een social business met als doel om impact te maken in lijn met een of meer Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs). In het vak worden enkele theoretische concepten en theorieen geïntroduceerd, met als doel om deze toe te passen in de praktijk. Deelnemers gaan in teams zelf ideeën verkennen en business modellen ontwikkelen.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
• Uitleggen en illustreren van de verschillende hoofdstappen, -activiteiten en -uitdagingen van het start-up proces
• Ontwikkelen, evalueren en aanpassen van business modellen voor startups

• Systematisch ontwikkelen en testen van kritieke veronderstellingen over het business model die tijdens het starten van een bedrijf bestaan, rekening houdend met de leerprocessen die doorgaans gepaard gaan met flinke veranderingen in het business model zelf
• Ontwikkelen en toepassen van effectieve en efficiënte onderzoeksmethoden om startup-ideeën te valideren
• Beknopt en helder documenteren van het startup proces
• Presenteren en bediscussiëren van het startup proces

column1: The objective of this course is to provide students with a state-of-the-art understanding of private capital, valuation of start-up companies, and the economics of contracts as it applies to entrepreneurship and new venture finance/private equity.

Entrepreneurship concerns the undertaking of new business ventures. The financial issues confronting entrepreneurial firms are fundamentally different from those that face established companies. The focus of this course will be on analyzing the unique financial issues relating to entrepreneurial firms and to develop a set of skills that has wide applications for such situations. Specific topics will include: start-up ventures; financial management of rapidly growing firms; deal structuring; valuation; private equity; initial public offerings; and the decision to harvest. Note that large firms can also be entrepreneurial, not only small start-up companies. The important element of entrepreneurship is the relentless pursuit of opportunity without regard to resources currently controlled.

We will discuss the various sources of capital for entrepreneurial firms. These sources include venture capital, angel investors, and crowdfunding. The decisions of firms at various phases of their life cycle will be examined and the advantages and disadvantages of various sources of financing will be compared. Throughout the course, analytical tools will be introduced and utilized. Financial analysis, various valuation methods, negotiations, and deal structuring will be examined in the context of entrepreneurial firms.

This course is aimed at students who at some point in their careers plan to start, acquire, finance or work for entrepreneurial, fast-growing businesses. It will also be useful for students who plan to join venture capital/private equity firms, investment banks. The course aims at instructing the student in how “real world” and professional investors operate to create wealth from entrepreneurial activity.
You should e-mail us in case of absence. Attendance of guest lectures is compulsory.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
• Appraise and construct a valuation for a start-up company
• Compare and select the different sources of financing
• Demonstrate an understanding of recent trends and developments in entrepreneurial finance and private equity
• Connect theory and practice in the context of entrepreneurial finance and private equity
• Critique academic research in the field of entrepreneurial finance and private equity

column1: Many students from RSM Erasmus University will consider starting (or working for) a new venture as a serious opportunity at some stage in their career. As entrepreneurs generate unique theories and models about how to create value, and then craft experiments to test their hypotheses, this course’s overall objective is to develop a set of capabilities to critically evaluate startup opportunities, develop theories about the business idea and test its several assumptions. This course provides real-world, hands-on experiential learning on what it’s like to start a company: you will work in teams to learn how to transform a great idea into credible business propositions. This course provides intensive, hands-on workshops, lectures, and numerous of the latest entrepreneurial tools and techniques to facilitate this learning process.

As part of the Strategic Entrepreneurship program, this course emphasizes an experiential learning approach: hands-on activities inside and outside the classroom have greater prominence than traditional one-way lecture time inside the classroom. Such an approach stimulates and engages student teams in defining and testing their business model hypotheses of their business models outside the classroom. This course is not about writing a business plan, and you are not asked to execute your business model (yet). The main objective is to develop a theory of your business that could create values, validating several hypotheses of your business model and by learning from and interacting with potential customers, suppliers, experts, and partners.

Attendance of all other sessions (but the team progress presentations) is compulsory. During this course, you will meet with many different stakeholders, such as potential suppliers and customers. Please try to arrange those meetings outside class hours, but should a clash be inevitable, then please go ahead and meet.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
• Define and assess the elements of new business models and recognize how these elements interrelate to each other
• Compose and construct a startup’s business idea with relevant business model elements
• Develop a theory for your business idea

• Identify and evaluate the major assumptions in their startup’s business model and translate assumptions in their startup’s business model into measurable hypotheses, test them, and, eventually, pivot the business model accordingly
• Design and execute a small experiment on their own
• Communicate and effectively interact with others to discover and develop a viable startup business model
• Reflect critically on the entire process of the project and evaluate peer and own contribution to the project

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/115011,2023,Entrepreneurship,Engels,Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,['dr. G Criaco'],,"Inhoud

In this Minor, students learn how entrepreneurs create business opportunities and transform them into successful start-ups and sustainable businesses. You experience what it takes to become an entrepreneur by developing your own business idea in a team of students, under the guidance of expert coaches and start-up experts. We believe that entrepreneurship is not only reserved for exceptional visionary people such as Steve Jobs, Richard Branson and Elon Musk, but that everyone can be an entrepreneur, provided they are motivated and know where to start. We provide students with a toolbox that helps them to get started. You will learn and practice an effectual and lean approach to creating new ventures. This approach is based on action-oriented core principles that underlie the decision-making approach and behavior of expert entrepreneurs. The emphasis is not on writing a business plan but on testing ideas in the market and building real partnerships with relevant stakeholders such as customers, suppliers and investors.

The entrepreneurial adventure in this Minor concludes with a pitch event where student teams present their business idea and achievements to a panel of experts. For this course, there is intense collaboration with the Erasmus Centre for Entrepreneurship (ECE), i.e., the Rotterdam knowledge hub that supports the teaching staff of the Minor with their expertise and network of entrepreneurs within the Rotterdam area. For more information, see: http://ece.nl
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column2: The major part of this Minor is the Core Module where you learn how to get started and develop entrepreneurial skills (such as pitching, financial bootstrapping and design thinking). Next to the Core Module, students choose one out of two elective modules that help them to develop their entrepreneurial knowledge and skills in a specific area: Entrepreneurial Marketing or Entrepreneurial Finance. These electives focus on (1) marketing challenges and how entrepreneurs with limited budgets reach, communicate and co-develop with their customers; and (2) unique financial issues related to entrepreneurial firms and the (dis)advantages of various sources of financing, respectively.

column1: In this course the focus is on understanding and developing entrepreneurial behavior, i.e., mainly involving the identification and exploitation of (new) opportunities. Entrepreneurial behavior may be motivated by economic or social value creation, and can take place within companies or organizations, or via starting up an own business. The course focuses on learning ‘about’ entrepreneurship and entrepreneurial behavior from an academic perspective and on a hands-on approach that is focused on experiencing entrepreneurial behavior yourself.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: - Understand entrepreneurship, its core elements, and its different manifestations in today’s economies and societies.
- Analyze the process underlying new venture creation based on academic literature and your own experience.
- Lead discussions on the course-specific scientific literature on entrepreneurship.
- Develop a value proposition and business model based on the Lean Startup method.
- Present your own business idea to stakeholders of your proposed startup.
- Execute an entrepreneurship project in a team with fellow students.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: In this course we will introduce entrepreneurship as an academic discipline and we will discuss some important aspects of starting a new venture. This course contains a concise introduction to the domain of entrepreneurship theory and practice. Entrepreneurship is all about identifying opportunities and pursuing them. Understanding the origins of such opportunities is key for entrepreneurs and existing companies alike in order to develop business models that will effectively create and capture value. In this course students will focus on three views of entrepreneurship theory: entrepreneurship, corporate entrepreneurship and social entrepreneurship. Entrepreneurship is not just a process but also a mind-set; it is behaviour.  Students will also develop that mind-set by practically exploring the initial stages of entrepreneurial process: the identification and evaluation of opportunities and the search for viable business models by following lean canvas principles. This course is a crash course in the (theoretical) foundations of entrepreneurship and a pressure cooker module for developing a business venture and presenting it in front of a jury from Entrepreneurship Center of Erasmus (ECE).

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
<body>After the course, students are able to:

column2: • Explain what entrepreneurship is, what its central elements are, and why entrepreneurship is crucial for our economy and society;
• Explain the difference between entrepreneurship and management in general, and between entrepreneurship, intrapreneurship and social entrepreneurship in particular.
• Develop a business model by applying the principles of the lean startup method.
• Explain how new ventures emerge and develop.

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/114787,2023,Entrepreneurship in Media and Business,Engels,Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,"['PM Leendertse, MA']",,"Inhoud
