column1: This course emphasizes the role of entrepreneurship within media markets, examining it from two perspectives: the entrepreneurial endeavors of challenger start-up companies and the application of entrepreneurial principles within existing media firms. We will explore relevant literature on entrepreneurship and business model innovation and employ these insights to analyze media-related case studies. Additionally, we will discuss how entrepreneurial principles can be utilized in media ventures with not-for-profit social objectives. Throughout the course, we will address key questions such as identifying new market or social opportunities, discovering competitive advantages within the media market, transitioning from idea to execution, and managing growth and scalability.

Aligned with the entrepreneurial focus, students will be required to develop a business plan for a media-related startup. This process will enable students to experience the valuable contribution of scientific inquiry and insights in the development of innovative products and services. Moreover, students will have the opportunity to pitch their business ideas and receive presentation training during the course.

As entrepreneurship serves as the central theme of this course, we will invite several professionals from the media industry to share their entrepreneurial experiences and encourage students to participate actively.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
• Current theory and research on entrepreneurship and innovation and entrepreneurship in media.
• Analyze entrepreneurial activity and entrepreneurship both from the perspective of the challenger and the incumbent companies.
• Apply models such as the business model canvas and strategy tools to the media industry.
• Develop a business idea for a media-related start-up.
• Create a business plan and strategy for an entrepreneurial endeavor for an existing media company.
• Create a business plan and strategy for a social entrepreneurship initiative

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Instructors: Dr. ir. F.O.O. Wagener (UvA), Dr. G. van der Meijden (VU), Prof. Dr. R. van der Ploeg (UvA), Prof. Dr. S. Poelhekke (VU)

This course focuses on climate change: one of the greatest challenges of our time. What can the science of economics teach us about its causes and potential solutions? What are the damages and benefits of climate change? Its impact on poverty? Should we tax carbon, cap-and-trade emission rights, or subsidize solar and wind power? Does the answer depend on how we value the future? Why/when should we discount the distant future less than the proximate future? What is the impact of risk and true uncertainty (ambiguity) on the discount rate? Can a tradeoff between growth and the environment be avoided, and if so with what sort of policies? Does trade harm the environment? Will our industry move abroad if we take a leading role and 'go it alone'? Can well-intended climate policies actually accelerate global warming? What are good second-best climate policies? How to deal with climate tipping points? What is the international incidence of climate change and of the climate policies needed to combat it? Why is it so difficult to negotiate international agreements?</body>

column1: This focus area seminar aims to understand environmental protest culture on a theoretical level and to explore the relevance of mass media and different social media platforms for protest communication.

We will examine different case studies of environmental protest campaigns since the 1960s and consider the roles different types of media played in their developments. In this context, we will discuss how questions of globalization, consumption, social injustice, inequality, and environmental protest are intertwined and how as well as why these different issues gain and lose relevance over time.

As in recent years, environmental activism engages in new ways of disrupting visual routines and situations of everyday life, the role of social media in the circulation of videos and images of single protest actions will be questioned in particular to understand how they achieve wide reach and visibility.

The use of ritual as well as visuality and framing in past and current cases of environmental protests will be analysed and it will be examined, whether a protest habitus can be observed and how communicative actions in environmental protest culture can be described. We will study sociological concepts of knowledge and social systems and transfer them to exemplary case studies to grasp how environmental protest actions operate on the level of symbol and meaning and thereby challenge understandings of different aspects of everyday life.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

• Apply sociological concepts and theories to case studies in a group
• Critically reflect on and review relevant academic literature
• Describe the scholarly debate on the role of media in environmental protest culture
• Independently design and write an essay, compare different theoretical positions

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/114711,2023,Epidemic Disease, Famine and Development in Historical Perspective",Engels,"Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,['dr. DR Curtis'],,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Entering the 21st century, climate change, globalization, inequality, and rural-to-urban migration have created conditions conducive to emerging infectious diseases and food production challenges. Epidemics and famine are yet to be consigned to the past – most noticeably seen in the food price spikes seen in the aftermath of the global financial crisis of 2008-9, and in the challenges of Ebola or COVID-19. However, measuring the causes and consequences of these traumatic events is not straightforward. Can history allow us to view these challenges in a new light by offering a deeper temporal perspective?

During this course we zoom in on how different societies have experienced and dealt with epidemics and famines, exploring differences and similarities across places and continuities and changes across time–episodes such as premodern plagues and 19th-century cholera outbreaks all across Eurasia; terrible famines such as Holodomor in Ukraine of 1932/3, the Bengal famine of 1943/4, and the Great Leap Forward Famine in China of 1958-62; and modern emerging infectious diseases such as HIV and AIDS outbreaks around the world from the late 1970s onwards.

Students will learn the causes and characteristics of epidemics and famines, and their effects on inequality and welfare, social (dis)order and cohesion, gender inequalities, public health, and their relationship with climate change and warfare. We also consider how epidemics and famines have been represented and remembered by surviving generations, how “outbreak narratives” are created, and consider controversies over ‘who is to blame’.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
• Students can identify the major causes, characteristics and consequences of epidemic diseases and famines throughout history using the extensive secondary literature.
• Using the extensive secondary literature, students can explain why outcomes from epidemics and famines could be different across time, region, and outbreak.

• Students can apply general theoretical concepts from the course to a specific historical case study of an epidemic or famine, by integrating other secondary and primary source evidence of their own.

• By comparing epidemics and famines in the pre-industrial past, modern history, and today using the extensive secondary literature, students can explain the value of a historical approach to epidemics and famines.
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: <body>This course will teach you the main concepts of Epidemiology and Global Health. Epidemiology is the quantitative study of disease occurrence and distribution in specified populations, the study of consequences of health problems as well as risk and protective factors, and the application of this knowledge to prevent and control health problems. You will learn (i) how to use methodological approaches to measure the incidence and prevalence of diseases in populations, (ii) how to determine causes of diseases, and (iii) how and when interventions may contribute to improvements in population health. Throughout the course you will work on an evidence-based prevention plan for a disease and country of your choice.</body>

Understand causes of diseases and relations between exposure and disease
Analyse relative importance of causes for the burden of disease
Understand the effectiveness of interventions
Design effective intervention strategies

column1: What does it mean to be a philosopher today? What can we as philosophers contribute to pressing debates on societal issues? Shall we try to offer solutions or rather ask the right questions? What can we learn from the philosophical tradition in current crisis situations?

This course aims to promote philosophical reflection on contemporary challenges through exploring various dilemmas and possible responses, We will examine key contemporary examples in practical philosophy of pressing social, political and cultural issues, or ‘challenges’ such as the climate crisis and the crisis of truth and trust in politics. We will discuss the specific function and value of a philosophical approach to these challenges, the relation between descriptive and normative statements in contemporary debates, the relation between philosophy and politics and the role of the philosopher in society.

column1: Ethical Aspects of Economics is a course about topics at the intersection of ethics and economics. You will be introduced to several contemporary topics in this area and given the opportunity to write on issues that you find particularly interesting.

The course will begin with two economic concepts with great importance for contemporary ethics: efficiency and utility. Next, we look at ethical aspects of research in economics. We then turn to debates over distributive justice: how should the resources produced in the economy be distributed? Finally, we dive into the arguments concerning the ethical limits of markets.</body>

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: By the end of the course, students can:

(1) define and elaborate on core concepts in economics (utility, Pareto improvements, randomised controlled trials etc.) and ethics (moral incentives, rule vs. act utilitarianism, moral corruption, distributive justice, etc.)
(2) understand and critically assess philosophical arguments and theories involving these concepts in terms of their coherence, cogency, and relevance.
(3) argue independently within the debates about these arguments and theories, both in written research and interactive discussions.</body>

column1: <body>This graduate course offers a profound examination of ethics and economics in theory and practice. Firstly, we will study some key concepts and values in economics. What is a market, and what are the virtues and moral limits of markets? What are property rights, and what is their moral relevance? What are the values usually invoked to defend markets? How are markets taken to promote efficiency, freedom and human well-being respectively? Secondly, we will analyze some substantive normative positions on economic questions, such as those held by right-libertarians, left-libertarians or Marxists. This will also allow us to study different ethical foundations that have been offered for different economic systems, such as varieties of capitalism and socialism. In a third step we explore the moral limits of markets and discuss possibly alternative economic systems. Among others, we discuss some specific policy proposals related to debates about ethical problems of our current economic system, such as basic income as a response to increasing material inequality or the role and limits of the market in addressing environmental degradation and climate change.</body>

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: <body>The main objective of this course is twofold. Firstly, students acquire an understanding of the relationship between ethics and economics in terms of its historical development, as well as in terms of its role in the contemporary discipline of economics, as well as the economy. Secondly, students learn to critically assess the positions in the field and further develop their oral and written argumentation skills.

column2: • By the end of this course you should have a good overview of recent work done in the field of economics ethics. You will have studied work by the main contemporary philosophers as well as the most important discussions and issues in this field.
• You will be equipped to do research (e.g. for a Master’s dissertation) on questions of economic ethics, both theoretical/conceptual as well as applied questions.

• This course will help you to improve your knowledge of methods and styles of arguments in analytical moral philosophy (esp. ethics/normative political philosophy) – which can also be useful for other streams within analytical moral philosophy.

• You will be able to practice, refine and further develop your writing and argumentation skills for analytical practical philosophy. This will be a special focus of this course, since you will receive detailed and extensive individual feedback on your written pieces of work.
• You will be able to practice, refine and further develop your oral argumentation and presentation skills in moral philosophy, through participating in the class discussions.
• You will be able to acquire, refine and train presentation and discussion skills, as required for the participation in international academic conferences.
• You will be able to learn/practice/rehearse some basic skills related to literature searching and use of libraries and bibliographical search methods.

column1: One part of the course is about doing the right thing while practicing professional accounting. One part of doing the right thing is knowing what you are expected to do in various situations and recognising what will be the effect of our choice taken while practicing professional accounting. The hardest part of doing the right thing is, therefore, recognizing and avoiding ethical hazards with conflicting expectations. Accountants have special obligations and responsibilities beyond those of other business practitioners so this course aims to develop the ethical analysis of different scenario beyond philosophy ethics courses and beyond business ethics courses.

Another part of the course, we will turn to non-financial (sustainability) reporting. In particular, we will discuss (economic) incentives to provide non-financial reporting on a voluntary base. We will also discuss the various mandatory reporting requirements in the context of sustainability and CSR reporting.

• evaluate and implement management accounting tools to facilitate social and environmental decision making.

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/112224,2023,Ethics in Econometrics,Engels,Erasmus School of Economics,,['PA Opschoor', 'prof.dr. JJ Vromen', 'prof.dr. PHBF Franses']",,"Inhoud

Econometricians use methods and techniques drawn from mathematics and statistics to address economic issues and questions. These questions can concern the macroeconomy, finance, microeconomic issues, labor, and various business economic settings. Typically, econometricians examine economic theories, create forecasts, develop multiple scenarios, propose optimal decisions, or evaluate policies. When the examinations are substantially novel and relevant to share with academics, the research findings can be published in academic literature, where other econometricians judge the merits of the work. In many other settings, however, the studies end up in an advice to an end user who can use the forecasts, who decides on the continuation or a change of the policy, who implements a proposed decision, or who picks one of the scenarios for making further plans.

It is important to recognize that such an end user rarely is an econometrician too. An end user can for example be an employee (top level or middle level) in a government, in a company, or in a bank. This implies that rarely an end user can fully grasp every single step that an econometrician has set when creating the product. At the same time, it is often also not possible to present every single step, and perhaps it is also not instrumental for the end user’s intentions. This means that the end user must trust that the econometrician made the right choices during the analysis.

There are various ethical guidelines around, and these usually concern honesty related to for example data cleaning (from raw data to the data to be analyzed), estimation methods, decisions based on statistical inference, trial and error and the reporting. Basically, these guidelines should establish that the final product can be reproduced when a list of choices and also the programming code is provided.

In this course we will initially discuss these guidelines but after that, in the main content of the course, we will address more specific ethical issues that follow from the fact that there is a knowledge asymmetry between the end user and the econometrician. Loosely said, even when the standard ethical guidelines are obeyed, it is still possible to provide an advice that meets a specific request of an end user. For example, it is not difficult to create a forecast that comes close to a desired target of an end user.

This course provides a range of cases where the knowledge asymmetry can be exploited intentionally, even though reproduction still is possible. There are cases where the result crucially depends on a single observation, cases where the statistical test is performed such that an outcome is manipulated, and for example cases where initial configurations dominate the result, even though it is very difficult to see.

This courses uses knowledge of FEB22015(X) Academic Skills and FEB22009(X) Introductory Seminar Case Studies Econometrics and Operations Research, and is required for each major seminar and the bachelor thesis.

column2: • General aspects of ethics in econometric academic research and application
• Specific aspects of the ethics of econometrics which are caused by knowledge asymmetry between model builder/forecaster (the adviser) and the the advisee.

column1: Ethische dilemma’s doen zich regelmatig voor in de financiële sector. Vooral na de financiële crisis van 2007/08 heeft ethiek in de financiële sector meer aandacht gekregen van wetgevers, toezichthouders en de media. Schandalen zoals Enron, Panama Papers en ING worden vaak besproken in ethische discussies en leiden tot bewustwording in de financiële sector. Toch blijven dergelijke schandalen zich voordoen, wat bijvoorbeeld blijkt uit het schandaal rondom betaaldienstverlener Wirecard en de Mondkapjesdeal. Hoe dienen wij deze problematiek te benaderen? Hoe kunnen klassieke ethische theorieën ons hierbij helpen? Op welke wijze geven ontwikkelingen in de financiële sector invulling aan ethische kaders? Hoe verhoudt ethiek zich tot het voldoen aan wettelijke verplichtingen en het handelen naar waarden en normen?

Het vak Ethiek, duurzaamheid en compliance is voornamelijk gericht op vaardighedenonderwijs. U wordt – al dan niet in groepsverband – de vaardigheden bijgebracht om een wetenschappelijke bijdrage te leveren aan ethische discussies die betrekking hebben op de financiële sector. Daarnaast worden enkele hoorcolleges verzorgd waarin diverse actuele onderwerpen worden aangesneden die in ethische perspectief worden geplaatst. Hierbij kan worden gedacht aan de ethische overweging bij corporate governance, waarbij gedrag en cultuur een aanzienlijke rol speelt. Daarnaast wordt aandacht besteed aan de ethische implicaties van technologische ontwikkelingen in de financiële sector. Het onderwerp duurzaamheid wordt ook uitvoerig onder de aandacht gebracht met bijzondere aandacht voor de Sustainable Development Goals (SDG’s) van de Verenigde Naties. Voorts wordt stilgestaan bij de wisselwerking tussen compliance en ethiek.
Tijdens het vak wordt getoetst aan de hand van tussentijdse mondelinge en schriftelijke vaardighedenopdrachten en een reflectieopdracht. Het vak wordt tevens afgesloten met een afsluitend tentamen.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
• De student herkent een moreel dilemma en kan hierover een oordeel vormen op basis van de ethische theorieën en presenteert dit in groepsverband.
• De student kan vanuit het theoretische kader argumenteren en debatteren rondom duurzaamheid en ethiek.
• De student kan de samenhang tussen ethiek enerzijds en corporate governance, financieel recht en economie anderzijds beoordelen.

• De student kan zelfstandig een kritische visie geven vanuit een ethisch perspectief over de positie van actoren op de financiële markten in relatie tot maatschappelijke opvattingen en de economie aan de hand van internationale kaders.
• De student kan de financiële en ethische verantwoording van een financiële onderneming toetsen en daarover adviseren.
• De student is in staat om op de samenwerking in teamverband en het eigen leerproces te reflecteren.

column1: De cursus ethiek, technologie en de jurist richt zich op ethiek voor het juridische beroep in een technologische context. Met dat laatste wordt gedoeld op zowel technologie in het juridische beroep (legal tech) als de technologie in de samenleving die de aard en het type rechtsvraag beïnvloeden. In de cursus maken studenten kennen met standaard-ethische benadering (bv. Deugdethiek, plichtethiek) en gaan ontdekken op welke manier deze benaderingen aangevuld zijn of zouden moet worden vanuit een techniek-ethische benadering. Studenten maken ook kennis met de belangrijkste technologie en design-gerichte ethische benaderingen zoals responsible innovation, ethics of risk en value sensitive design. Er is ook aandacht voor meer waarden-gerichte verschuivingen, zoals bijvoorbeeld door legal tech in de advocatuur. De doelstelling is dat studenten vanuit een techniek-ethisch perspectief voldoende worden toegerust voor de ontwikkeling van een constructief-kritische benadering naar technologie.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: <body>Aan het einde van de cursus kan de student:

column2: • Zelfstandig de verschillende standaardbenaderingen in de ethiek bekritiseren in het licht van technologische ontwikkelingen. Deze kritiek kan de student relevant maken voor het juridische beroep.
• De ethische waarden signaleren en evalueren die technologieën in het juridische beroep introduceren aan de van inzichten uit good life ethische benaderingen van technologie.
• Een praktijksituatie kritisch beoordelen en beschouwen op de specifieke ethiek van risico’s aan de hand van de AI-act.
• Een technology assessment uitvoeren op het ontwerp van een specifieke technologie en aanbevelingen doen voor aanpassingen van het ontwerp vanuit het gedachtegoed van responsible innovation.
• In groepsverband reflecteren op de rol en houding van de jurist van de toekomst in de digitale samenleving, en een digitalisering van het juridische beroep.

column1: This course has the aim for students to become familiar with different offender types and differentiating these offender types based on their etiology and risk factors. Questions that will be addressed are: ""What risk factors for violence does an offender with a psychopathic personality have?"" and ""which subtypes of offenders with a psychotic disorder can we distinguish on the basis of their background?"" In addition, this course involves using fundamental insights from neuroscience. These insights relate to forensic topics such as the emergence of aggression and antisocial behavior and how different brain networks are associated with psychopathic personality. Questions that will be addressed are: ""How do different processes in the brain contribute to the development of aggression?"" and ""how come that a psychopath feels ‘nothing’?"" But also: ""How can activity in the brain be measured and used in violence risk assessment and management?""

Attention is also paid to the emerging field of science named 'neurolaw'. In court, there is an increase in the use of neuroscientific evidence, for example by giving a court ordered forensic neuropsychological examination of the suspect of a crime. This is also increasingly being used by the defense to reduce the sentence, or even to plea for insanity.</body>

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: During this course, the student learns to:

column2: • Distinguish different types of offenders on the basis of etiology and risk factors
• Describe functions of different brain structures that play a role in aggressive behavior
• Explain which neurobiological factors are related to the delinquent behavior of different types of offenders.
• Explain how different neuropsychological conditions play a role in forensic practice.
• Distinguish between forensic neuropsychology and forensic neuroscience.

• Assess the added value of neuroscientific information in assessing the risk of violence (compared to the common risk factors used in the risk assessment of violence) and the subsequent risk management.
• To substantiate the advantages and disadvantages of the use of neuropsychological and neuroscientific information within the legal system (""Neurolaw"").

Europe in the World is a Master course for students in the International Public Management and Policy program. This course aims at developing students’ understanding of the activities of the European Union in the world. By the end of the course, the students will be able to understand and theoretically explain the EU’s external action. They will appreciate the difficulties of EU’s foreign action, and will be able to critically appraise the EU’s foreign policy. Students will have improved soft and transferrable skills.

Students in this course will be expected to have covered the basics of international relations theory. This can be done by having passed the course Global Governance in the IMP program, or an alternative program elsewhere (recognized at the discretion of the instructor).

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Justice and Home Affairs refers to the various policies gradually developed by the EU on border management, migration and asylum, criminal and civil justice, police and judicial cooperation and, lastly, data processing and data protection. These policies are necessary in order to ensure one of the overarching goals of the European Union: creating and maintaining an internal market and facilitating the freedom of movement of EU citizens by removing internal borders controls between the Member States. In parallel with the establishment of the internal market there was a need for the EU to develop policies, referred to as flanking measures, to compensate for abolishing the internal border controls.

First, the EU set up a common external border policy which is supported by common rules on border control, a common visa regime and the creation of common approaches on immigration and asylum from outside the Union.

Second, a common criminal policy, entailing consolidated judicial and police cooperation, was developed in order to prevent criminals benefitting from the abolition of internal border checks. This required the European Union to develop common policies on criminal justice, law enforcement cooperation and, where necessary, common measures on substantive and procedural criminal law. However, these subjects also deal with sensitive aspects for the Member States and raise deep sovereignty concerns for them.

Therefore, Justice and Home Affairs has developed a distinctive cooperation form, via legal measures such as harmonization and through cooperation between Member States authorities and by having mutual trust and recognizing each other’s criminal justice systems and judicial decisions. To aid the cooperation between the Member States the EU has created special bodies called ‘agencies’. These agencies often bring together the competent authorities of the Member States and help coordinating common action within AFSJ policies.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: <body>This course is organized according to the main themes of the AFSJ. These are:

column2: • Freedom: freedom to move and abolition of internal border controls, migration and asylum policies.
• Security: security at the borders and law enforcement cooperation.
• Justice: criminal justice cooperation and common approaches to criminal law, criminal procedural law and sanctions

column1: After finishing this course, you are able to:

column2: • Understand the legal framework of the European Union regarding the Area of Freedom, Security and Justice;

• Assess the basics of the EU free movement regime, the Schengen-area and the policies needed to support it, namely a common external border management and enhanced cooperation in the fight against cross-border crime;
• Identify the fundamental elements of the Common European Asylum System;
• Analyse the legal framework of regular and irregular migration within the European Union and the legal framework applicable to Union citizens and third-country nationals;
• Identify different categories of persons entitled to protection, such as asylum seekers, refugees and persons entitled to subsidiary protection;
• Distinguish the different tools of integration used by the European Union in the Area of Freedom, Security and Justice, such as harmonization and mutual recognition;
• Evaluate how mutual recognition and mutual trust are applied in the Area of Freedom, Security and Justice;
• Examine the various forms of cooperation within the EU criminal justice policy and, in particular, the application of the European Arrest Warrant;
• Analyse the basic principles of data processing and data protection and the application thereof in the Area of Freedom, Security and Justice;

• Assess the role and functions of various European Union agencies operating within the Area of Freedom, Security and Justice (e.g. FRONTEX, Europol, Eurojust, European Asylum Support Office, European Public Prosecutor’s Office);
• Evaluate the role and relevance of fundamental rights in the Area of Freedom, Security and Justice.

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/114015,2023,European Private International Law,Engels,Erasmus School of Law,,['drs. EC Smit - Bennemeer', 'prof.mr.dr. XE Kramer']",,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: The globalisation of trade has led to an increase of transnational relations and situations that can require the application of different sets of rules in a cross-border context. For instance, an English company concludes a sales contract with a French company; an agent settled in the Netherlands represents a United States-based company in several European countries; a German consumer buys goods from a Swiss company over the internet; a semi-finished product manufactured in Spain causes damages in further production chain in Poland.

International legal practice is increasingly confronted with questions of private international (including procedural) law. The substantial diversity of jurisdiction and procedure rules, and the lack of harmonisation may increase legal uncertainty and ineffective adjudication.

This course focuses on the general concepts of private international law and the application of private international law. Particular attention is given to private international law at European Union level and to related international conventions. Where relevant, attention will be paid to comparative aspects, for example common law jurisdiction vs. civil law jurisdiction.

The instruments to be discussed include those dealing with international jurisdiction, recognition and enforcement, evidence, service of documents, harmonised European procedures (i.e. European Order for Payment, European Small Claims, European Account Preservation Order, Representative Actions), and the applicable law to (commercial) contracts and torts.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: A student who has successfully completed this course should:

column2: • identify the sources of private international law;
• assess the importance and problems of harmonisation of private international law at European level, and to some extent at international level;
• understand general concepts of international jurisdiction, including lis pendens and forum non conveniens, forum shopping, choice of forum, jurisdiction in personam, and jurisdiction in rem;
• understand the concepts of recognition and enforcement, including reciprocity, exequatur, free movement of judgments, and grounds of refusal;
• understand general concepts and principles of conflicts of laws, including party autonomy, connecting factors, public policy, and overriding mandatory rules;
• compare the process of service of documents under the European Service Regulation and the Hague Service Convention, and apply the European Service Regulation;
• compare the process of obtaining evidence under the European Evidence Regulation and the Hague Evidence Convention, and apply the European Evidence Regulation;
• assess the position of weaker parties in European Private International Law;
• have a basic understanding of European uniform procedures, in particular on the order for payment, small claims and collective actions;
• apply European jurisdiction rules to concrete civil and commercial matters;
• determine how a concrete judgment regarding civil and commercial matters given in a Member State can be recognised and enforced in another Member State;
• determine on the basis of European legislation in a concrete case which law applies to commercial or civil relationship or claim;
• describe the interplay between the UN Convention of International Sales of Goods and Rome I Regulation;
• analyse the relationship between European Private International Law and third states.

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/114126,2023,European Union Health Law,Engels,Erasmus School of Law,,['mr.dr. AP den Exter'],,Inhoud

Conceptualising Union health competences, the main focus is on Article 168 TFEU. Though understandable, this is however not the entire story. Other legal bases have also been lawfully applied to ensure a high level of health protection (eg, free movement provisions, consumer and environmental protection, social policy, competition policy, etc). For instance, under the consumer protection policy, the general product safety directive (2001/95/EC) established general safety requirements for all consumer products, including medical devices. Combined with the ‘horizontal’ liability directive for defective products (89/374/EEC), both directives are aimed to protect consumers’ (patients’) health against defective products. Additionally, Union social and employment law - aimed at protecting workers and fighting discrimination - had some unintended consequences in health care settings. A clear example is the Working Time Directive’s applicability to medical professionals, which it is claimed has hampered the planning and organization of medical care. Furthermore, the coordination of social security law, the mutual recognition of diplomas of regulated health professions, combined with the harmonization of pharmaceutical law, as well as the impact of European competition law, have a clear health dimension. At the same time we will be confronted with new challenges since the Union is becoming increasingly involved in human rights and health care. The recently endorsed EU Charter of Fundamental Rights and newly established Human Rights Agency may influence EU law on health and health care in the member states. For instance, courts may consider the Charter as the basis of judicial review of the activities of EU institutions. Relevant rights may include the right to life, equal access to health care, human integrity, and informed consent.
Minimum number of participants: 5 pp
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

This course will contribute to promote excellence in teaching and equip students with knowledge of European integration and health law. So far, a separate course on EU integration and health law covering a full range of health (related) topics on European integration is missing. Instead, the fragmented legal approach only addresses certain elements of EU law and health. By developing an extensive and unique teaching program this course will focus on the entire spectrum of EU health law, enabling teachers and students to invest in a relatively unknown area of European integration.

On completion of the course the participant will have a broad knowledge within the EU legal framework. Furthermore, the course will enable participants to understand, apply and analyse EU health legislation, related to relevant cases/topics, more specific this course aims at:
- Increasing new knowledge of the European legal framework on EU health law
- The student will be able to identify, analyse and understand contemporary legal problems and dilemmas in EU health law, and apply this knowledge on similar issues
- The student will be able to formulate relevant legal arguments in the EU health legal debate,
- Encouraging students to develop competence in communication skills,
- The student will be able to analyse and summarize the case law of the EU Court of Justice on health integration issues,
- The student will be able to apply the acquired knowledge in writing an academic legal paper on European integration and health law,

- Promoting innovation in teaching. The innovative teaching method (mix of various teaching methods, student-centred approach and combination of enhancing knowledge and skills) combined with applied (digital) tools stimulate a more problem-solving learning process, therefore fostering new teaching methods and technologies which contributes to enhance communication skills and further understanding of this part of European integration.
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: The course offers and introduction to the European Union Law. It provides insights into: a) the evolution of the European Union and the sources of EU law; b) EU institutions; c) the decision making process of the EU; d) the relationship between EU law and the legal systems of the EU Member States; e) the internal market All subjects within the course are approached from a point of view which enables the students to grasp the evolution of European integration. The course intends to embed law related questions into the wider political, social and economic EU-context, without leaving out the developments and discussions as to the future of the European Union.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
On completion of this course, the student will be able to:

column2: • Understand the institutional structure and the legal system of the EU, as well as its competences and the limitations thereof,
• Understand the foundations of EU Single Market Law, EU Competition Law, EU Citizenship, principle of Equal Treatment and Human Rights within the EU, and EU Migration Law,
• Distinguish the legal issues embedded in news items, literature etc.
• Point to the legal and institutional ways of solving basic legal problems/cases

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: In recent decades, there has been a rapidly increasing influence of European Union law on more and more areas of national law. Because of this development, people often speak of the progressive 'Europeanization' of different parts of the national legal systems of the Member States of the EU. Virtually all jurisdictions are affected by EU law, which means that the developments in EU law have a major impact not only on the functioning of the national legal jurisdiction and judicial organization, but also on the daily lives of ordinary citizens.

Building on the students’ existing knowledge about the basic principles of EU law and the institutional framework of the EU, the second-year course ‘European Union Law’ goes beyond the basics of the EU’s construct. In particular, the course focuses on the substantive law of the EU. Students will gain an understanding of the internal market and the four fundamental freedoms, the system of legal protection in the EU, EU competition law, as well as Brexit.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Upon completion of this course, students will not only be able to understand the foundations and background of EU law, but will also be able to find, understand, analyze, interpret, critique, and apply the (primary and secondary) rules on legal protection, the four freedoms of the internal market, and EU competition law in the EU to case studies. In addition, student will also be able to find, analyze and apply the relevant case law of the ECJ to a case study.

column1: This course analyses the European Union as a political system. Rather than just describing the various political actors and formal and informal decision-making procedures, the course aims at a higher level of understanding by applying theories based on institutional rational choice to the various facets of the EU. The basic idea is that political outcomes are the result of actor preferences and institutions (as rules of the game). Equipped with this approach we will analyse among other things, executive politics, legislative politics, interest group politics, and policy making in a variety of areas.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: After completion of this course, students are able to:
• describe the composition, tasks, internal structure and formal decision-making role of European Commission, the Council of Ministers, the European Parliament, and the European Court of Justice;
• describe the main issues and explain the developments of the EU’s regulatory policies, expenditure policies (budget), and interior policies;

• define and explain central concepts of rational choice-informed political science theories, such as principal agent theories and coalition-formation theory and to describe the assumptions and hypotheses of these theories;
• apply rational-choice informed political science theories to executive politics, legislative politics, interest groups politics, regulatory policies, expenditure policies and interior policies;
• predict EU policy change based on synthesizing information about changes in the actor's environment, their effects on actor preferences, and changing institutions to predict policy change;
• effectively communicate orally about policy developments in the EU and case study findings.

column1: Een van de redenen voor de Europese toenadering en de totstandkoming van het Verdrag betreffende (de werking van) de Europese Unie is het streven van de lidstaten om te komen tot een interne, markt zonder fiscale belemmeringen, beperkingen of distorsies. Hierdoor moeten onder andere ondernemingen in staat worden gesteld om zich beter aan te passen aan de interne markt, hun productiviteit te vergroten en hun concurrentiepositie op de internationale markt te versterken. Tijdens dit vak wordt geanalyseerd hoe lidstaten deze economische voorspoed kunnen bereiken zonder oneerlijke fiscale concurrentie. Naast de positieve Europese integratie - de regelgeving - wordt ruimschoots aandacht besteed aan de negatieve integratie, de arresten die door het Hof van Justitie worden gewezen.
Het vak bevat o.a. de volgende onderwerpen:

column2: • Bespreking van de verkeersvrijheden in het VwEU
• Wisselwerking tussen EU-recht en nationaal fiscaal recht
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
• Inzicht verwerven in de algemene beginselen van het EU belastingrecht en in het bijzonder het beslisschema van het Hof van Justitie.
• De vaardigheid ontwikkelen om aan de hand van het EU belastingrecht nationaalrechtelijke belastingregels te toetsen op hun aanvaardbaarheid.
• Het kritische vermogen ontwikkelen om op zelfstandige wijze naar nationaalrechtelijke belastingregels te kijken.
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: <body>De doorwerking van het internationale recht op het Nederlandse arbeidsrechtelijke rechtssysteem zal worden besproken. Daarnaast maakt met name het Europees recht het relatief eenvoudig dat een werknemer vanuit Nederland elders in de EU te werk wordt gesteld en vice versa. De regels die hierbij gelden en de problemen die hierdoor kunnen ontstaan worden besproken. Vraagstukken die worden behandeld zijn onder meer: welke fundamentele vrijheden staan de werkgever en de werknemer ter beschikking, hoe verhouden deze vrijheden zich met arbeidsrechtelijke beginselen en rechten, welk recht is van toepassing op de internationale arbeidsovereenkomst en welke rechter is bevoegd bij een geschil. Daarnaast zullen enkele aanpalende actuele onderwerpen worden besproken.</body>

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: <body>Aan het einde van dit vak kan de student:

column2: • de invloed en doorwerking van Europees en internationaal (sociaal verzekerings)recht in het Nederlandse arbeidsrecht toepassen op een concrete casus.
• beoordelen welke rechter in een internationaal arbeidsgeschil bevoegd is en welk recht van toepassing is.
• beoordelen wanneer sprake is van internationale detachering, wat de gevolgen daarvan zijn en welke beperkingen wel en niet kunnen worden opgelegd aan internationale dienstverleners.
• de wijze waarop Europese vrijheden doorwerken in een concrete casus beoordelen en identificeren hoe en waar zich spanningen voordoen tussen deze vrijheden en het (nationale) arbeidsrecht.
• reflecteren op de impact van Europees recht op de Nederlandse (arbeids)rechtsorde.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

Evolution is such a crucial discipline of modern biology that, in 1973, evolutionary biologist Theodosius Dobzhansky wrote: ""nothing in biology makes sense except in the light of evolution"". In this course, a comprehensive introduction to the fascination field of evolutionary biology will be presented. Topics that will be covered include: the origin of abiotic and cellular life, the theory of evolution by natural selection (descent with modification), concepts of fitness and adaptation, the genetic and developmental basis of evolutionary change, micro- and macroevolution, speciation and extinction, elementary population genetics, palaeontology, and human evolution.

column2: <head><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column3: After completing this course, you will have a basic knowledge of:

column5: the theory of evolution by natural selection (descent with modification);
the concepts of fitness and adaptation;
the genetic and developmental basis of evolutionary change;
the origin of abiotic and cellular life;
micro- and macroevolution;
speciation and extinction;
population genetics;
palaeontology;
human evolution.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: In an infinite population setting, we will learn to use static equilibrium concepts (such as the evolutionary stable strategy), dynamic concepts (such as the replicator dynamics), and we will learn what the relation is between these. In a finite population setting, we will learn what the Moran process is, and get accustomed to evolutionary graph theory.

In order to explain the evolution of prosocial behaviour, we will then apply these evolutionary dynamics and stability concepts to settings with population structure (which then leads to kin selection and/or group selection), repetition (which can lead to the evolution of reciprocity), and partner choice/sexual selection (and its relation to signaling in economic theory). We will also look at subgame perfect equilibria in games where commitment to ""rationally irrational"" behaviour (such as altruism or vengefulness) can have an evolutionary advantage.
We will consider how these predictions can be tested, in and outside the lab, and discuss parts of the empirical literature with each other.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: By the end of the course, students should have an understanding of
1. mathematical techniques for evolutionary dynamics
2. how evolutionary dynamics help formulate predictions for human behavior
3. how these predictions can be tested empirically
They are also expected to be able to
4. judge the quality and relevance of technical papers
5. judge the quality and relevance of empirical studies
6. write about either a technical or an empirical finding in a clear way
7. present (and critically discuss) an empirical paper
Hopefully, they will be inspired to
8. include evolutionary foundations as one of the considerations when modeling, explaining and describing human behavior in their future research

column1: Experiments are an increasingly important tool in economics. They are, for instance, used to understand why financial investors spend too little on stocks, why consumers are reluctant to change brands, and in the analysis of labor market decisions. This course deals with the following questions:

column2: • Why are experiments such a powerful tool to discover the causal effect of a treatment?
• Why should incentives be given in economic experiments work? Do they always work?
• What kind of statistical analyses are needed for experimental data?
• What is the optimal sample size to discover the causal effect of interest?
• Are results found in the laboratory predictive of behavior in the real world?
• How can we test lab-field generalizability by means of field experiments?
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
• Understand why randomization is crucial to gather causal inferences of behaviour.
• Understand why economists use incentives in experiments.
• Understand why non-parametric tests are needed to analyze data gathered in experiments.
• Understand why it is sometimes important, and sometimes not important that results from laboratory experiments generalize to other 'real world' settings.
• Know how many indepedent observations one can get out of an experiment.
• Be able to apply some power calculations.
• Be able to come up with an experimental design and derive hypotheses.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Instructors: Prof. Dr. J. van de Ven (UvA) and Prof. Dr. R. Dur (EUR)

Experimental Economics studies economic behavior in a controlled, laboratory or field environment. This course teaches the student how to design an experiment aimed at answering a self-developed research question. In addition, it gives an overview of recent trends in Experimental Economics. The course will focus on a set of recent experimental papers and on experimental designs developed by the students. Each student is expected to actively participate in class by discussing selected papers and to develop and present his or her own experimental design.

Each student is expected to actively participate in classes and to develop an experimental design of his or her own. The grade is determined by a presentation of the design (30%) and by a written proposal of the design (70%).

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
• have an overview of recent trends in Experimental Economics
• be able to develop a research question
• be able to design an experiment aimed at answering the self-developed research question
• be able to present a research question and design

column1: Knowledge and understanding: Acquire knowledge of important insights from experiments and an understanding of methods in experimental economics.
Application of knowledge and understanding: The ability to develop a research question and an experimental design.
Making judgements: The ability to critically evaluate experimental designs and results from experiments.
Communication: The ability to write a well-structured research proposal and present the design of an experimental study.
Learning skills: Know how to look for related studies and independently set up further studies.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: The course is built on three pillars: Testing research ideas with clean and rigorous experimental designs, applying the appropriate statistical techniques necessary to analyse these designs, and properly interpreting the implications of the observed results in light of the study design and research question. Topics include: causal inference, experimental designs (factorial designs, within- vs. between-subject designs, mixed designs), validity of designs (internal, external, criterion-related, and construct validities), experimental caveats (demand characteristics, confounds, experimenter expectancy, checks, measurement order, control variables), applying statistics to experimental designs (e.g., simple effects, simple slopes, contrasts, outliers, statistical power, simple mediation, moderated mediation, mediated moderation), data visualization, and scientific integrity (researcher degrees of freedom, questionable research practices, transparency, p-hacking)

We will examine these topics from the perspective of an applied behavioural researcher (with examples from fields such as marketing, organizational behaviour, economics, and psychology). Our focus is thus very practical—to help you overcome any issues that might arise in designing and conducting your experiment, analysing your data, writing up your results, and getting your paper published. An intermediate proficiency in a programming language (preferably R) is strongly encouraged for this class.
As in previous years, we may be able to collect data in the Erasmus Behavioural Lab.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: <body>The goal of this course is to learn how to design, analyse, and interpret field and laboratory experiments.</body>
https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/112040,2023,Experimentation & Causal Inference,Engels,Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,['dr. JMT Roos'],,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Course content is organized into seven modules covering the following topics:

column2: • Introduction to Causal Inference—Overview of the course, motivating questions about causes and effects, and the challenges of measuring effects from data
• Potential Outcomes Model—A framework for measuring causal effects from observational data or experiments that begins with what you want to measure and works backward from that

• Graphical Models—Another framework for measuring causal effects from observational data or experiments that begins with what you are willing to assume about the world (and what you can measure) and works forward from that

• Randomized Experiments and Hypothesis Tests—Sampling from a population and random assignment to different treatments are powerful tools for measuring causal effects. Hypothesis tests provide a way to quantify how likely our results are due to these sources of randomness.

• Confounders and heterogeneity—The world is messy. Variables that are correlated with causes and effects can help or hinder our ability to measure causal effects for the entire population or for subsets of the population
• Matching and Regression Estimators—Introduction to typical methods for estimating causal effects

• Challenges to Causal Inference—If we send an email to a customer, they may or may not use that coupon on their next purchase. Here we discuss tools for inference when some people don’t do what we expect them to do.
• Prior to the lecture, you will read the assigned material.

• After reading the material, and before the lecture, you complete a assignment via Canvas to test your comprehension of the material. You can refer to the reading as you complete the assessment. You can also post questions and comments to the discussion board on Canvas, and I will use these posts to determine which material needs more emphasis during the lectures
• During the lecture, we will review material covered by the assigned reading, focusing on what was less clear to most students. We will work through examples, both as a class and in small groups.
• After the lecture, you apply what you’ve learned while completing longer problem sets.
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
• Understand and differentiate between statistical concepts such as correlation, conditional independence, and likelihood; and causal concepts such as randomization, confounding, and exogeneity
• Express causal relationships among data using Pearl’s graphical framework, and counterfactual quantities of interest using Rubin’s potential outcomes framework
• Derive conditions under which causal relationships can be estimated from data
• Simulate outcomes corresponding with an assumed causal model, and use these simulated outcomes to predict the precision of empirical estimates of causal effects
• Think critically about the ethical consequences of performing randomized experiments, and of making causal claims

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: In het vak ‘Externe verslaggeving en accountancy in juridisch perspectief’ wordt vanuit juridisch perspectief aandacht besteed aan de jaarlijkse financiële verslaggeving door (beurs)vennootschappen en het interne en externe toezicht dat daarop wordt gehouden. De jaarrekening, het bestuursverslag en de overige stukken die behoren tot de jaarlijkse financiële verslaggeving van (beurs)vennootschappen spelen een belangrijke rol in het economisch verkeer. Deze stukken vormen bijvoorbeeld de basis waarop het bestuur van een vennootschap verantwoording aflegt aan kapitaalverschaffers. Naast de wettelijke vereisten voor de totstandkoming van de jaarrekening, bestuursverslag en overige informatie, de besluitvorming daaromtrent en de openbaarmaking van de jaarlijkse financiële verslaggeving worden ook de mogelijkheden voor uitstel voor het opmaken en de openbaarmaking van deze stukken besproken. Zowel de nationale als Europese wet- en regelgeving (EEG-richtlijnen, de EU-verordening inzake de IFRS en de Corporate Sustainability Reporting Directive (CSRD)), als de niet-wettelijke voorschriften (van de Raad voor de Jaarverslaggeving) passeren daarbij de revue.

De rol van de raad van commissarissen, de accountant, accountantsorganisatie en Autoriteit Financiële Markten komt aan de orde bij het behandelen van het interne en externe toezicht op de totstandkoming van de financiële verslaggeving. Ook de aansprakelijkheid van bestuurders, commissarissen, accountant en accountantsorganisatie wordt behandeld, zowel buiten als in faillissement. Gedurende het vak is ook aandacht voor de mogelijkheden voor belanghebbenden om in rechterlijke procedures naleving van de jaarrekeningvoorschriften af te dwingen.

In het vak is ook ruimschoots aandacht voor actuele ontwikkelingen in de externe verslaggeving zoals duurzaamheidsverslaggeving en digitalisering. Duurzaamheidsverslaggeving is de term die gebruikt wordt voor niet-financiële verslaggeving, de rapportageverplichtingen die voortvloeien uit de CSRD vormen hier een voorbeeld van. Ook kan gedacht worden aan de rapportage over VN Sustainability goals. Duurzaamheidsverslaggeving speelt een steeds belangrijkere rol in het economisch verkeer. De wet- en regelgeving voor duurzaamheidsverslaggeving is volop in ontwikkeling en roept interessante vraagstukken op over bijvoorbeeld inrichting, openbaarmaking en controle ervan die gedurende het vak uitgebreid aandacht krijgen.

Verslaggeving heeft op verschillende manieren te maken met de trend van verdergaande digitalisering. Bij de digitale ontwikkelingen rondom verslaggeving kan gedacht worden aan digitaal ondertekenen en deponeren van de jaarrekening maar ook aan de digitale vaststelling van de jaarrekening op de digitale aandeelhoudersvergadering. En ook aandacht voor digitalisering als onderwerp van verslaggeving, als bijv. cybersecurity in de risicoparagraaf, ontbreekt niet.</body>

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Na afloop van het vak kan de student zelfstandig:

column2: • het juridisch kader rondom de totstandkoming en inrichting van de externe zoals financiële verslaggeving en duurzaamheidsverslaggeving van vennootschappen en het toezicht daarop beoordelen.
• de uiteenlopende rollen en verplichtingen van de actoren betrokken bij het opmaken, controleren, overleggen, vaststellen en openbaar maken van de financiële verslaggeving beoordelen.
• de uiteenlopende rollen en verplichtingen van de actoren betrokken bij de totstandkoming en het openbaar maken van externe verslaggeving beschrijven.
• op hoofdlijnen juridische en maatschappelijke trends en ontwikkelingen in externe verslaggeving in hun (inter)nationale context becommentariëren.

• op hoofdlijnen de mogelijke civielrechtelijke, bestuursrechtelijke en/of tuchtrechtelijke aansprakelijkheidsprocedures die samenhangen met de totstandkoming en openbaarmaking van de financiële verslaggeving binnen een specifieke casus toetsen.
• het nationale jaarrekeningenrecht met Europese en internationale jaarrekeningvoorschriften vergelijken.
• de samenhang tussen voorschriften van jaarrekeningenrecht en inzichten uit de (bedrijfs)economie beoordelen.
• een juridisch gefundeerd advies formuleren over vraagstukken van externe verslaggeving met oog voor de maatschappelijke en (bedrijfs)economische context.

column1: The FAECTOR Consultancy Project is a 10-week project organised by FAECTOR for econometrics and BSc2 students. The purpose of this project is to give students practical experience and challenge their knowledge and skills. It does so by offering a practical application of their econometric knowledge in the consultancy field. An additional aim of the project is to offer affordable data consultancy to non-profits and (semi-)governmental institutions, who normally cannot afford professional consultancy. This way, the project has an impact on the
real world while still providing valuable education to students.

column1: The Excellence Programme is a programme designed for the highly motivated Econometrie/Econometrics/BSc2 students. The goal of the programme is to give Bachelor (second year or higher) and Pre-Master students the opportunity to see different sides of an econometric theme. This programme is organised by FAECTOR in cooperation with the Erasmus School of Economics and upon successful completion participants receive 4 Extracurricular ECTS and a certificate signed by the Dean of ESE. Last year's theme was Econometrics and Health. This year's theme will be announced in November/December. During this programme students attend weekly lectures and practical workshops given by field experts and companies. Moreover, the programme includes several company visits. Programme lasts from January until June.

column1: Facility logistics, sometimes called (company) ‘Intra logistics’ (NL: “Interne logistiek”) covers material handling, i.e. the design, planning, control, and execution of material flows within the facilities (plants, warehouses, hospitals, cross-docks, hubs, terminals, etcetera) of the company. The course primarily focuses on warehouses and cross-docks. Many companies use warehouses to receive products from suppliers and deliver them to their customers. They decouple supply from demand. Moreover, warehouses have a role in forming an assortment or as a point in the supply chain to group material flows to create transport efficiencies.

Topics that will be covered include, but are not limited to, the relation between supply chain networks and facility operations, layout design, material handling systems, automation technologies, storage and order picking methods, warehouse management systems, operations benchmarking, leading and managing employee behavior, and shop floor safety.

Class attendance is mandatory. Certain obligations may require you to miss a class, but no more than three absences are allowed (including the company visits). Class attendance is a prerequisite for assessment. Without regular attendance, it will be difficult to get a passing grade, since the exam will be largely based on issues discussed in class. If you need to miss a class, you have to notify me in advance by email, with the reason for your absence. Moreover, note that class attendance is not the same as class participation. I assume that you be completely prepared for every class (i.e. read the case, prepare questions, read the literature. What you have to do is specified for each class individually).

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
• Understand the role of warehouses in the supply chains; the impact of the organization of supply and delivery on warehouse operations, and vice versa
• Distinguish factors that play a role in warehouse performance, their interaction and the relation with supply chain processes
• Understand the interaction between layout, storage, and process organization in warehouses
• Analyze warehouse operations to identify problems and improvement opportunities
• Create feasible plans of action and develop sensible decisions on how to deal with a particular material handling challenge
• Defend problem formulations and solutions based on sound arguments

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/111818,2023,Families and Inequalities,Engels,Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences,,['dr. BE French', 'prof.dr. PA Dykstra', 'prof.dr. R Keizer']",,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Families are a key link between macro-level processes (political, cultural, and economic shifts) and individual outcomes such as socioeconomic and health status in later life. Many of the decisions that people might perceive as fundamentally personal and individual (whether or not to become a parent, whether or not to take up a paid job and what kind of job to take) are shaped by the interaction between our families and broader social, cultural, and institutional conditions.

In this course, students will learn about the links between families and social inequalities. We will not only look at social class as dimension of social inequality, but also focus on differences by ethnicity, race, sexuality and gender. Students will gain insights into key theoretical and methodological approaches to the study of families and social inequalities. Attention will be paid to interactions between micro- and macro-levels of analysis; e.g. how states (e.g. social policies and national laws), markets (e.g. the precariousness of jobs), and political, cultural and economic shifts structure family members’ life courses and well-being outcomes, thereby reducing, maintaining or strengthening social inequalities at large.</body>

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: After successful completion of this course, students will be able to:
1. Understand the key theoretical and methodological approaches to the study of families and social inequalities;
2. Illustrate how social inequalities arise within and between families;
3. Indicate how changes at the macro level context (e.g. policies, cultural climate, economic circumstances) influence family relations and in turn social inequalities;
After successful completion of this course, students will also have developed the following skills:
1. Understand and evaluate research and link this to trends and patterns observed in a specific country;
2. Build arguments and assess evidence in a clear and effective manner in written text;

column1: <body>During the first sessions, we will get familiar with the concepts and theories regarding brand activism and then how they are effectively applied in media campaigns in the specific field of fashion. Through seminars, lectures and engaging with case studies, we will further delve into the consequences that being openly and commercially linked to a social stance has affected (or not) the identity and performance of brands in a new media environment.</body>

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Aims: This seminar will explore how fashion industry organizations use brand activism and media campaigns for market benefit. The seminar will look into the academic discussions on brand activism connecting it with the experiences of fashion brands in the market. We will focus on recent case studies but also consider the historical way in which fashion has evolved in the market as a luxury product.

column2: • Explore the history and current events around brand activism
• Analyze how brand activism is executed by fashion brands in digital media
• Discuss the different models of brand activism implemented by fashion brands through (social) media campaigns
• Reflect critically on the potential and opportunities of using social media and activism for market gain
• Work in campaign development following the concepts defined in class

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/114775,2023,Fashion Media,Engels,Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,['dr. AC Uribe Sandoval'],,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: This seminar aims to provide an in-depth understanding of past and recent developments in the fashion media. Students will explore the shift from printed media to today’s online media platforms and globalized communication networks, as well as changes affecting advertisement and marketing and the use of various fashion communication technologies and outlets. Special attention will be paid to the impact of globalization and social movements on the media coverage (formats, content, discourses) given to fashion and the ways in which various media outlets influence processes of reputation building, consecration and valorization in the fashion world.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Define and understand the importance of media in the development of Fashion through the 20th and 21st Centuries. Be able to explain how different media have represented changes in the Fashion market and how the market itself is configured differently in an international, online media environment. Reflect on the contents of fashion media, its influence to the market and makers, and its’ possible futures.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Dutch culture is marked by two interdependent themes: the color orange and a history of colonization. While the first, orange, is expressed in the (un)popularity of the Royal Family (with the epitome of the King’s Birthday Celebration), soccer, and mythical narrations of how the Netherlands as a small country was a refuge for artists, philosophers, and religious people. The second has much more negative expression that marks contemporary debates. The fierceness of debates on ‘Zwarte Piet’ (black Pete), the images of slaves on the Royal family’s Golden carriage, or museums’ attempts at decolonization are just a few examples of how the Dutch struggle with their past.

In this course, students will familiarize themselves with both themes from the three perspectives our faculty offers. Starting with a historical perspective, students will form a firm understanding of the meanings of ‘orange’ and the colonial history. Both important foundations for current Dutch culture. Building onto this understanding, student will explore how these two themes impacted the current art world. While the Netherlands have brought forth many important (visual) artists, Dutch museums are also struggling with the Dutch colonial past. Last but not least, the last two weeks will be dedicated to exploring popular culture’s expressions of these two themes. The TV format trade and Dutch soccer culture will be taken as a case.</body>

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: - Key concepts and perspectives on Dutch Culture from three perspectives: historical, cultural and mediated.
- The interrelations between the historical developments of Dutch society, the way the Dutch deal with their artistic past, and their contemporary mediated/popular culture.
- The image of the Netherlands abroad as, on the one hand, a very tolerant and open country and, on the other hand, a place where racism and ethnocentrism abound.
- Put current discussions in the Netherlands in their historical and social context.
- Reflect critically on the viewpoints and research materials presented in class.
- Reflect upon developments in the Dutch Culture in the context of global trends.</body>
