column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: This course introduces students to the field of feminist philosophy through key texts by some of the most prominent figures in the field, such as Simone de Beauvoir, Judith Butler, Audre Lorde, Donna Haraway and Luce Irigaray. Through the analysis of these texts, we will engage with a genealogy of feminist philosophy and explore one of its most contested sites of debate: the body.

We will start by critically assessing mainstream canonical philosophy, which has relied on a hierarchically charged binary opposition between mind and body that also correlates with the opposition between masculinity and femininity.  The course will examine how such binary thinking relates to structural (gender) inequalities, and how this has elevated the theorizing of the body in critical feminist thought. By unpacking different feminist positions regarding the themes of embodiment and binaries, students will develop an understanding of key traditions within the field of feminist philosophy, including sexual difference theory, gender performativity, feminist phenomenology and feminist new materialisms.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column2: • Have a basic understanding of key texts within the field of feminist philosophy of the body.
• Have a basic understanding of key re-conceptualisations of the body within feminist philosophy.
• Have a basic understanding of key thinkers in feminist philosophy such as Lloyd, de Beauvoir, Irigaray, Haraway, Butler, Young and hooks.
• Be able to describe and explain the problematic relation between feminism, philosophy and the body.
• Be able to describe and explain how the rational subject has typically been constructed against the natural realm and what this entails.
• Be able to describe and explain what is at stake politically, ethically and epistemologically in rethinking the body in feminist theory.
• Have a basic understanding of feminist stakes in addressing, and sometimes going beyond, binary thinking.

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/113412,2023,Field Paper and Research Internship,Engels,Erasmus School of Economics,,[],,Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: n a Field Paper the student summarizes the literature on a particular topic, describes the major contributions and identifies the direction in which the literature is heading. The topic of the Field Paper should be related to a TI course and the supervisor of the Field Paper is the teacher of the course.

During a Research Internship a student contributes to an ongoing or newly starting research project of a TI (candidate) fellow. The student is thus not the principal investigator on the project. The students devotes about 75 hours of work to the Research Internship and can do tasks such as collecting, cleaning, analyzing data, programming, summarizing literature, and modelling.

The Field Paper and the Research Internship are not meant as extension or start of the thesis. The two products should be clearly distinct. Therefore, work done for the Field Paper or Research Internship cannot - without substantial modifications - be used for the thesis. However, this does not rule out that the thesis is for example on a related topic as the Field Paper or uses data that has been collected during the Research Internship.

Students receive credits for Field Paper or the Research Internship. Therefore, students are not allowed to receive payments for their work. Financial motives may not be the reason for choosing the Field Paper or Research Internship over a field course.
The Field Paper and the Research Internship are individual work of the student.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: <body>The students learns to work independent on part of a research project. The student should therefore acquire knowledge on the process of conducting research, a systematic and rigorous way of working and develop a critical attitude. The students learns about communicating research and develops the capacity to reflect upon their own contribution.</body>
https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/112110,2023,Filosofie,Nederlands,Erasmus School of Economics,,['dr. CJ Clarke', 'dr. S Wintein', 'dr. SM Vergara Fernandez']",,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Kwesties uit de methodologie van de economie, zoals de vragen hoe onrealistisch economische modellen mogen en moeten zijn en hoe we kunnen beoordelen hoe groot hun verklarende kracht is, en kwesties uit de ethiek van de economie, zoals de vraag naar het doel van economisch beleid, naar ongelijkheid, verdelende rechtvaardigheid en morele grenzen van de markt, worden in de hoorcolleges geïntroduceerd en toegelicht. In vijf werkgroepen worden ethische kwesties in het bedrijfsleven en in de markt besproken en geanalyseerd. Door actief met de materie bezig te zijn ontwikkelen studenten een sterker moreel besef en maken zij zich denkkaders eigen om tot een meer doordachte en evenwichtige eigen oordeelsvorming te komen.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
• Studenten hebben basiskennis van de voornaamste perspectieven, ideeën en argumenteerwijzen in de filosofie van de economie.

• Studenten worden geacht voorbeelden te kunnen bedenken die helpen om onderscheid te maken tussen de hedonistische opvatting, de voorkeursbevredigingsopvatting, en Sen en Nussbaums capaciteits-opvatting van welzijn.
• Studenten moeten argumenten vóór en tegen elke opvatting kunnen aanvoeren en in staat zijn om premisse-conclusie-argumenten te geven in essayvorm.
• Studenten moeten onderscheid kunnen maken tussen verschillende opvattingen over rechtvaardigheid.
• Studenten moeten Broome's theorie van eerlijkheid kunnen formuleren.
• Studenten moeten kunnen uitleggen hoe goedheid en eerlijkheid van elkaar verschillen.
• Studenten moeten in staat zijn de praktijk van het gebruik van QALY's voor de verdeling van medische middelen te beoordelen, door in essayvorm premisse-conclusie-argumenten hiervoor te geven.
• Studenten moeten de historische achtergrond van het debat over gelijkheid versus toereikendheid in het onderwijs kunnen vertellen.
• Studenten moeten in staat zijn om het verschil tussen de gelijkheid versus toereikendheid als (sufficiency) in distributieve rechtvaardigheid te kunnen uitleggen.
• Studenten moeten de basisbegrippen en -resultaten (paradox van Condorcet, theorie van Arrow, theorie van Gibbard Satterthwaite) van de sociale-keuzetheorie kunnen definiëren.
• Studenten moeten verschillende functies van sociale keuze kunnen toepassen.
• Studenten moeten enkele prominente axioma's voor sociale-keuze functies kunnen verklaren en toepassen.
• Studenten kunnen samenwerken met andere studenten bij het plannen, opstellen en herzien van een argumentatief essay.

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/116557,2023,Filosofie in de Praktijk,Nederlands,Erasmus School of Philosophy,,['drs. DMG Roovers', 'drs. E Huijsman', 'prof.dr. LHJ Noordegraaf - Eelens', 'prof.dr. S Jensen']",,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Deze cursus is een verplicht vak binnen het curriculum van voltijdstudenten.

Tijdens de cursus Filosofie in de Praktijk leren studenten om de filosofische kennis en vaardigheden die zij gedurende (de eerste jaren van) hun studie hebben opgedaan toe te passen op praktische problemen. Het uiteindelijke doel is dat studenten ervaren hoe zij met hun filosofische perspectief een bijdrage kunnen leveren aan de analyse en oplossing van maatschappelijke vraagstukken.

De cursus begint met enkele inleidende sessies tijdens Filosofisch Atelier III in blok 2A van het derde bachelorjaar. Deze sessies zijn bedoeld om studenten kennis te laten maken met methoden om hun (theoretische) filosofische kennis te vertalen naar de praktijk.

Aan het einde van blok 2A dienen studenten gekozen te hebben tussen twee manieren om de cursus voort te zetten in blok 3A en 3B: de studenten nemen ofwel deel aan het ‘Filosofie en Maatschappij’-traject, of lopen een zogenaamde ‘Filosofische Stage’.

Bij het eerstgenoemde traject ontwikkelen studenten de eerste ideeën betreffende de relatie tussen filosofie en de maatschappij die zij hebben ontwikkeld tijdens de introductiesessies van Filosofisch Atelier III. Dit doen zij aan de hand van verschillende opdrachten waar door het docentteam feedback op wordt gegeven.

Bij de Filosofische Stage lopen studenten stage bij een organisatie en dienen ze een bedrijfsprobleem te identificeren en bij te dragen aan de oplossing ervan. Hierbij worden de studenten ondersteund door de stagedocent(en) tijdens tweewekelijkse begeleidende sessies. Studenten werken toe naar een presentatie van hun bevindingen in een afsluitend symposium.

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/116065,2023,Filosofisch Atelier I,Nederlands,Erasmus School of Philosophy,,['dr. B Leeuwenburgh', 'drs. R Knipscheer, MA', 'FA Deinum', 'KJ Kuipers, MA', 'NS Janssens, MA', 'prof.dr. FA Muller', 'T Heijmeskamp, MA']",,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: De cursus is uitsluitend bedoeld voor de voltijdstudenten. Aanwezigheid en participatie zijn verplicht.
Deze cursus bestaat uit een 'Filosofisch Atelier I'-gedeelte dat plaatsvindt in blok 1A en 1B, en een 'Filosofie en Film'-gedeelte dat plaatsvindt in blok 2A.

In het eerste jaar van de bachelor krijg je een introductie op academisch onderwijs. De focus ligt hier op studievaardigheden. Al tijdens de eerste bijeenkomst zal worden gezocht naar een goede balans tussen jouw verwachtingen en de eisen die de studie stelt. Ook zal aandacht worden besteed aan motivatie, attitude en het structureren van zelfstudie (voorbereiding op colleges en tentamens). Er zijn bijeenkomsten voorzien over ‘de ethiek van het lezen’, waarin verschillende genres teksten worden besproken en de daarbij passende houding van de lezer. Maar er worden ook bijeenkomsten gewijd aan het volgen van hoorcolleges, het gebruik van de UB, citeren, verwijzen en frauderen, en het schrijven van een samenvatting.

Aanvullend hierop wordt als onderdeel van deze introductie één college gegeven met als thema loopbaanoriëntatie. Het doel van dit college is om je kennis te laten maken met de loopbaanperspectieven en om (voor jezelf) expliciet te formuleren wat je uiteindelijk verwacht van de opleiding.

Ook wordt tijdens dit college verteld over de mogelijkheden om jezelf naast de opleiding te ontwikkelen. Hierbij gaat het om informatie over het Honoursprogramma, exchange, medezeggenschap, commissie of bestuur bij ERA en het lopen van stage.

In het ‘Filosofie en Film’-gedeelte van deze cursus staat een urgent filosofisch probleem centraal waarrond een aantal films wordt geselecteerd en vertoond. Verschillende docenten verzorgen colleges over het thema en de gekozen films. Van de studenten wordt verwacht dat zij essays schrijven, elkaars essays beoordelen, en presenteren en discussiëren over de films en het thema. De nadere invulling van dit deel van de cursus wordt via Canvas bekend gemaakt.

column1: Na het volgen van Filosofisch Atelier I:
1. Heb je een duidelijk beeld van wat er van je wordt verwacht tijdens de voltijd bachelor Filosofie als het gaat om de omgangsvormen en het studiereglement.
2. Kan je zelfstandig een filosofische tekst lezen, analyseren en samenvatten.
3. Ken je de regels wat betreft het schrijven van een academisch filosofische tekst.
4. Weet je welke hulpmiddelen en faciliteiten de universiteit biedt ter ondersteuning van je studie.
5. Weet je welke mogelijkheden er zijn om je in en naast je studie persoonlijk te ontwikkelen.
6. Heb je een onderbouwde visie op de loopbaankansen na de studie filosofie.
Het doel van Filosofie en Film is:

a) Inzicht krijgen in de academische beoefening van filosofie en het vermogen ontwikkelen om in korte opdrachten de filosofische thematiek en importantie van verschillende films onder woorden te brengen.
b) Het opdoen van de basisvaardigheden van het schrijven van een filosofisch artikel.

column1: De cursus is uitsluitend bedoeld voor de voltijdstudenten. Aanwezigheid en participatie zijn verplicht.

Deze cursus bestaat uit een scriptiewerkgroep-gedeelte dat plaatsvindt in blok 1B, 3A, 3B, 4A en 4B, en twee voorbereidende sessies op de cursus 'Filosofie in de Praktijk' die plaatshebben in blok 2B.

In een aantal bijeenkomsten van oktober tot en met het einde van het collegejaar wordt een technische instructie gegeven voor het schrijven van een bachelorthesis en wordt collectief gewerkt aan eenieders concept voor de thesis. Dat concept dient uiterlijk 1 februari, goedgekeurd door de begeleider, aan de Examencommissie te worden voorgelegd. Voltijdstudenten die in 2023-2024 hun bachelorexamen willen afleggen dienen deel te nemen aan de bijeenkomsten. Zonder deelname kan geen bachelorexamen worden afgelegd.

In blok 3A en 3B wordt de cursus Filosofie in de Praktijk geven (verplicht voor voltijders). In die cursus dien je een keuze te maken tussen één van de twee volgende richtingen: 1) Filosofie en Maatschappij, of de 2) Filosofische Stage. Om een goedgeïnformeerde keuze te kunnen maken tussen deze twee specialisaties krijg je in twee voorbereidende sessies in blok 2B wat informatie over/een impressie van beide specialisaties.</body>

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Het doel van de scriptiewerkgroep is:
a) Het schrijven van een concept voor de eigen bachelor thesis.
b) Het presenteren en kritisch bespreken van tekstgedeelten uit de eigen thesis.
c) Het constructief-kritisch becommentariëren van tekstgedeelten uit de theses van medestudenten.

Door de voorbereiding op Filosofie in de Praktijk in blok 2A krijg je inzicht in beide richtingen van die cursus — 1) Filosofie en Maatschappij, en de 2) Filosofische Stage — waardoor je aan het einde van blok 2A een goed geïnformeerde keuze kan maken voor één van deze specialisaties.

column1: FinTech covers digital innovation and technology-enabled business model innovation in the financial services industry. FinTech is rapidly evolving across the globe and represents an existential challenge for major parts of the financial sector. These innovative technologies are disrupting existing industry structures and blurring industry boundaries, facilitating disintermediation, radically changing how firms create and deliver products and services, generating significant privacy, regulatory and law-enforcement challenges, offering new gateways for entrepreneurship, and creating opportunities for inclusive growth.

This course provides an introductory overview of innovations that are central to FinTech in the areas of payment, capital raising, investment, and credit. The focus is on blockchain technology and its specific issues and applications. However, other important innovations covered include crowdfunding, robo-advising, peer-to-peer lending, and central bank digital currency. The course also explores the opportunities of these technologies for business creation and development. Furthermore, the course typically features several guest speakers from industry.
Attendance for the lectures is not mandatory, but strongly advised.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
• Describe what FinTech is and why it emerged

• Explain both fundamentals and economics of the following FinTech: bitcoin and blockchain, crowdfunding, blockchain-based tokens, DeFi, robo-advising, social trading, peer-to-peer lending, mobile money, and central bank digital currency
• Analyze the potential and limitations of these FinTech (and their applications)
• Develop a new venture idea linked to blockchain

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/112052,2023,FinTech: Business models and Applications,Engels,Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,['prof.dr. DGJ Bongaerts'],,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: The financial sector has been increasingly disrupted by the use of technology. Moreover, recent regulations such as the EU PSD2 directive, have created an environment that further facilitates the use of technology, big data, and algorithms in financing applications. One can think about payment systems, Peer to Peer Lending, Crowdfunding, Crypto-currencies, Robo Advising, and High-Frequency Trading.

The course consists of two parts. In the first part, we analyze and discuss FinTech business models, their value propositions, their impact on traditional players in the financial sector, and their impact on market outcomes. We structure this discussion according to business activity (e.g., investing, fund raising, lending, market making). During the first part, students develop a business plan for their own fintech venture.

In the second part of the course, students are confronted with the reality of running a venture and work towards a prototype or minimum viable product (MVP). In doing so, they can use feedback they received on their business plan. Moreover, they will be coached by someone with ample experience with implementing FinTech solutions.
Lectures are not mandatory but attendance is strongly advised.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
• Understand the potential role of technology in designing financial business models and the value created for various stakeholders
• Understand and be able to analyze the impact that new, technologically advanced players have on the incumbent financial sector
• Be able to formulate technology, data, and algorithm requirements corresponding to certain functions that financial markets fulfil
• Be able to write a business plan for a FinTech business model and conduct a corresponding investor pitch
• Be able to implement and test a stylized version of a FinTech business model as a team and present the setup and performance in a clear and concise way

column1: The FI Honours Class includes an interactive course by academics and practitioners on the Role of Finance in Society and a living management case. Among others, the course provides insights in the societal role of finance: what can finance contribute to a good society. It is aligned with the mission statement of RSM: A force for positive change. Topics and cases are each year refreshed reflecting the newest trends in societal thinking and their application to finance.

column2: Blocks 3 & 4: Ten lectures (a mix of academic lectures and guest lectures by industry, both on campus) on the Role of Finance in Society and the role of technology in financial markets. The lectures are scheduled for 3 hours; some lectures will be 2 hours. The topics for academic year 2021/2022 are Sustainable Investment, FinTech and Blockchain, and Responsible Finance and Financial Inclusion. The form of assessment is an individual exam for the interactive course.
Block 5: Living management case with corporate partners. The form of assessment is a group assignment for the case.

column1: Students will learn to critically review societal and technological trends, to link them to finance, and to identify opportunities for financial institutions and markets. In the living management case, the academic concepts are applied to practical finance problems. Students learn more about management of projects: to understand the work of a consultant, how to analyse finance problems, how to develop solutions and recommendations, and how to develop a professional client relationship.
Students should attend lectures, workshops, and presentations. Failure to do so may result in an additional assignment.

• Understand and apply the impact of sustainability on investing and lending
• Understand the working of FinTech and blockchain and their impact on the financial sector
• Understand the concept of financial inclusion and apply it to the financial sector
• Link Finance theory to practical, real-world and often poorly structured problems

column1: Dit vak behandelt de kennis die nodig is om een onderneming te kunnen waarderen. De waarde van de onderneming beinvloedt de beurskoers van een aandeel van die onderneming en bepaalt de prijs die betaalt wordt voor de aandelen van de onderneming bij een fusie of overname. Vanuit de perspectieven van een financieel manager en de financiers van de onderneming behandelt Finance 1 hoe investerings- en financieringsbeslissingen de waarde van de onderneming beïnvloeden. We gaan niet alleen uit van de klassieke rationele winst-maximalisatie denkwijze, maar besteden ook aandacht aan recente ontwikkelingen op het gebied van behavioural finance en het financieren van duurzaamheid.

Finance 1 omvat hoorcolleges, tutorial sessions, webcasts en on-line oefeningen. Tijdens de wekelijks colleges behandelen verschillende docenten de stof. Tijdens de tutor sessions worden actuele case studies besproken, waardoor studenten zien hoe de stof wordt toegepast bij echte investeringsbeslissingen, beursintroducties en overnames. In webcasts worden oefeningen besproken en geven docenten extra toelichting.

• de basis-principes van ondernemingsfinanciering en beleggen begrijpt.
• voorbeelden heeft gezien van werkelijke beursintroducties, fusies en overnames en bedrijfswaarderingen;
• een beter perspectief heeft over de waarde van de onderneming en duurzaamheid.

column1: During this course we will study the knowledge necessary to value a firm. The value of the firm influences the prices of its shares en determines the price paid for shares in case of mergers and acquisitions. From the perspective of the financial manager and the financers of the firm. Finance 1 will show how investment and financing decisions influence the value of the firm. Besides thinking in terms of classical rational profit maximization thinking, we will address important developments in behavioural finance and sustainability as well.

Finance 1 encompasses classes, tutorial sessions, webcasts and on-line exercises. During the weekly classes, teacher present knowledge. The tutorial sessions will be focused around real-life case studies, such that students understand how the knowledge is applied for real investment decisions, IPOs and take overs. The webcasts are short films wherein exercises will be discuss and teacher give additional information.

column2: • know what cash flows are and can translate future cash flows to values today;
• can interprete financial information from a firm and assess the value of that firm.
• understand the basic principles of corporate finance and investments.
• have seen many examples of IPOs, mergers, acquisitions and firm valuation.
• have a perspective on the value of the firm and sustainability.

column1: In the last phase of your study, it is important to apply the knowledge and skills you have developed by doing an internship. There is an option to do an internship as part of your MSc in Finance & Investments by choosing the Internship Elective in Block 5. During the Internship Elective, the students will be working independently at a well-established company (or other organization) where they will be involved in the financial activities, projects, and decisions that the firm is engaging in. More importantly, students will actively have to work on a project within the company that is of a solid academic level where the students can demonstrate and apply their knowledge in the field of finance in a real project. While working at this company, the students have to write a report in which they explain the contents of their work and translate the knowledge and skills obtained in the MScFI program into the working field. The students are responsible for finding their own internship company.

Approval by MScFI Internship coordinator. Students who potentially want to consider doing an internship as elective need to register on SIN-Online before December 12th 2022 at 17:00. At this stage it is not required that students already found an internship. Neither does this SIN-Online registration imply that you are selected for the internship.

In the first week of January 2023, students who have registered via SIN-Online will get access to the Canvas page of this Internship elective. From that moment until April 1st 2023 at 17:001 students should submit:

column2: • A proposal of the plans for the internship report

column1: The MScFI Internship coordinator will judge these submissions on a first-come-first-serve basis until the maximum capacity of 50 students has been reached.

column1: Achieving the Sustainable Development Goals is the grand challenge of our time. This course gives insight in ‘how the financial system can contribute to sustainable development’.

The finance transition is about transforming the financial system from operating on financial value only to working with the concept of integrated value. This combines financial, social and ecological value. Assessing financial value is part of the toolkit of finance professionals for a long time. New developments now also enable the measurement and (monetary) valuation of social and environemental factors.

The concept of integrated value is approached from an academic and practical angle (e.g. incorporating social and ecological value flows alongside the financial cash flows in the net present value (NPV) calculation).
Students apply the integrated value concept in exercises and a group assignment.

column1: <body>After following this course, the student is able to:

column2: • understand the allocational role of finance in society
• measure and apply integrated value in investment decisions

This course provides an introduction to finance for students with a non-business background. The themes we deal with in this course are particularly relevant for business decision-making in areas such as how to evaluate the financial health of companies, whether or not to invest in a project, and how to deal with risks. We ultimately aim to build intuition in finance and as such, we will also analogize to other domains, such as personal finance. The course is both theoretical and applied, and builds on lectures, discussions, take-home exercises, and case studies.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: The amount of data in our world has been exploding. Having been equipped with skills to analyze large data sets will become a key basis of competition for individuals and companies, according to research by MGI and McKinsey’s Business Technology Office. According to a report of J.P. Morgan’s quantitative investing and derivatives strategy team issued at the end of 2017, “(financial services jobs) are all about machine learning and big data”. The report suggests machine learning will become crucial to the future functioning of markets. Analysts, portfolio managers, traders, and chief investment officers all need to become familiar with machine learning techniques. Otherwise, they will be left behind: traditional data sources with low frequency (such as quarterly earnings and GDP figures) will become more irrelevant as managers using newer datasets, and more methods will be able to predict them in advance and to trade ahead of their release.

The course will discuss two main techniques to deal with structured data and unstructured data at entry level: 1) textual analysis, and 2) machine learning. It aims to introduce a set of analytical tools for understanding and examining real-time data examples in Python. Students need to complete empirical assignments to enhance the knowledge and skills learned in the course.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
• Analyze real-life cases with result interpretation and implication discussions
• Apply machine learning techniques to work with Python on structured data
• Apply textual analysis to work with Python on unstructured data

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: This course integrates advanced managerial accounting topics with recent techniques of financial management, strategic analysis and management control. It focuses on preparing, evaluating and interpreting financial information for managerial decision making and control in different types of organizations. Topics covered include advanced cost allocation techniques (like Time-Driven Activity-Based Costing and process costing), environmental/sustainability management accounting, evaluation of financial information to support project appraisal, pricing strategies and forecasting, among others.

The course makes use of the case method to analyze and discuss how financial information integrated with non-financial information is used to effectively support managerial decision making. Students are expected to apply appropriate analytical frameworks to diagnose and solve complex problems by emphasizing the connection between financial information and data analysis techniques that fit with management’s specific needs. The course combines theory and practice sessions with group assignments, guest lectures and discussions.

Being part of RSM, we aim to be a force for positive change in the world, and we use the UN Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) as a reference framework to classify the most urgent social, economic and environmental challenges facing the world. Accounting and financial decision making plays a fundamental role in this respect. Consequently, within this course we will discuss in lectures, workshops and via cases how students as the financial managers, controllers and accountants of the future can contribute to the SDG’s.

For instance, we will contribute to SDG 3 (good health and well-being) and SDG 10 (reducing inequalities) by discussing the immediate consequences and wider implications of cost allocation and pricing in the healthcare sector. Moreover, by raising awareness for the financial aspects of sustainable manufacturing, as well as identifying, quantifying and accounting for environmental hazards in the accounting system and financial decision making we provide a strong link to SDG 6 (clean water and sanitation) and SDG 12 (sustainable consumption and production patterns). Finally, there is always an ethical dimension to financial decision making and performance measurement which will be discussed more broadly throughout the course.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
• Understand and apply advanced management accounting techniques in different types of organization
• Analyse and explain how financial information integrated with non-financial information is used to effectively support managerial decision making
• Evaluate and discuss appropriate analytical frameworks to diagnose and solve complex managerial problems
• Apply the appropriate problem solving, computational and communication skills essential to the preparation and analysis of managerial reports that aid in managerial decision making

column1: This course provides the mathematical foundations for the analysis of financial derivatives, in particular, futures, forwards and options. It explains pricing and hedging under the no-arbitrage assumption. Basic discrete and continuous probabilistic models are used to illustrate the binomial tree approach to option valuation and the Black-Scholes formulas for option pricing using Brownian motion and Ito calculus. Further topics include European option Greeks and hedging strategies, American and Exotic options, implied volatility, order books and market makers.
Throughout the course, numerical examples and applications of empirical financial data are used to illustrate the analytical and Monte Carlo approaches.
By its very nature, the course involves a considerable amount of mathematics and statistics. Of all subjects in finance, the area of derivatives has used these tools most intensively.

column2: • To become proficient at maneuvering through the fundamental derivative pricing concepts and modeling approaches.
• To open the black box of the underlying modeling assumptions and understand the pros and cons of the most widely used models in practice.
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
• Learn the main characteristics of the financial derivatives available to perform such hedge
• Study different ways to price derivatives, with a focus on binomial and the Black-Scholes model
• Understand the implementation and benefits of hedging financial risks
• Advanced quantitative analyses of all above points

column1: This course teaches a general management perspective on financial distress. Participants acquire the skills and knowledge to understand and manage financial distress risks. The course should appeal to participants who want to work as finance executives within a corporation, consultants, investment bankers, private equity, or venture capital investors. As financial distress is relevant for every area of finance, this course is also suited for participants who simply want to extend their knowledge in financial distress.

The course discusses features of the legal environment for financially distressed firms, financial distress costs, bargaining strategies, corporate finance theory on financial distress, stakeholder incentives, default predictions, and investments in financially distressed securities. The course is highly interactive and employs a variety of didactic formats, including lectures, case studies, and a bargaining simulation game.

The course is designed as an interactive learning experience. Experience from past years shows that attendance during the lectures greatly increases the learning benefit. For this reason, all participants are strongly encouraged to be present in all meetings. The course features a participation grade. The participation grade is calculated based on the score of correct answers to in-class exercises. In case of a missed class, the participation grade is, therefore lower. The final participation grade is adjusted for one missed class (i.e., students can miss one lecture without impacting their participation grade, e.g., due to illness). The correction is done automatically and students do not need to inform the instructor. Missing more than one class will lower the participation grade, however, (i.e., the score for the missed lecture is zero). There are no other consequences of missing a lecture.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
• Develop empirical predictions using a conceptual understanding of financial distress
• Understand the role of illegal financial activities related to financial distress
• Distinguish types of financial distress costs and its implications for firms and society
• Develop a bargaining strategy for a distressed firm
• Discuss stakeholder incentives for a distressed firm
• Critique resolution choices for a financially distressed firm

column1: Graduates of the HCM master programme will work in complex institutional contexts with high levels of professional autonomy, conflicting interests and financial pressure. Such a working environment involves lots of challenges without clear-cut solutions. In the course Financial Management, students will work on a realistic case study and are asked to draft and defend an advice related to the problem at hand. After this course students will be able to analyze the financial health of an organization and derive substantiated and defendable improvement suggestions. These learning objectives will be assessed in two ways: (i) by working in a group on an organizational case and writing a report about the analyses and recommendations, and (ii) by individual examination. Both components contribute equally to the course grade.

The group project will allow students to learn from each other while developing the knowledge and skills for mastering the learning objectives. The individual examination will be about critically assessing the outcomes report of another group. Students will be instructed to critically reflect on the analyses and recommendations. Students will write the critical assessment report under supervision.

During the course students will build up the skills and knowledge related to the learning objectives by means of a case study. Students will practice with financial health assessment, evaluate the financial and non-financial consequences of improvement suggestions, and critically assess each other’s work.
Students will work on their group project demonstrating that the learning objectives are achieved. The case related to the group project will be announced at the beginning of the course.

Important: Depending on students’ prior education, students might be more or less familiar with economic concepts and financial management. For those who lack familiarity, the following books might be a valuable background read:
Koetzier, W. & Brouwers, R. (2018). The Basics of Financial Management. Fourth Edition. Noordhoff Uitgevers.
Walsh, C. (2008). Key management ratios: The clearest guide to the critical numbers that drive your business. Fourth revised edition. Pearson Education.
Language: Only the workgroups are in Dutch</body>

column1: Most companies around the world are controlled by their founders or founding families. Family control raises unique challenges as well as value-creating opportunities for these companies and their various stakeholders. This course introduces students to the management, governance, and financial issues faced by family businesses.

Financing decisions in a privately held firm, and specifically the family-owned and controlled privately held firm, can be subtly complex in comparison to a publicly owned corporation with well distributed ownership. Whether it is a budding entrepreneurial venture, a growth-stage strategic expansion, or a well-established latter-stage concern, the private firm decision matrix must consider the balance of insider control, timely growth and expansion, and shareholder liquidity needs when making key financial decisions.
Attendance is expected. For the case studies, students will prepare case memorandums in preparation of the discussions.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
• Understand role of family businesses (or more generally closely hold firms) for employment, economic growth, innovation, or inequality
• Identify the characteristics that differentiate a family business from other businesses
• Develop a system framework to analyze factors influencing family business financial decisions such as capital raising, valuation, diversification, mergers and acquisitions
• Examine the life cycles of family businesses from the perspective of business, family and ownership
• Understand and analyze the governance of the family business system with particular emphasis in the light of the management of intergenerational transitions

column1: Using earlier acquired knowledge and skills, students will be made familiar with several important methods and techniques used in Financial Econometrics. The emphasis is on understanding the techniques, and why the methods are relevant and appropriate for specific financial applications. In addition to the lecture there are weekly Stata assignments and one hand-in group assignment.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

• Apply OLS (Ordinary Least Squares) regression analysis ans analyze its underlying assumptions.
• Evaluate and correct violations of the OLS assumptions, including the use of GLS (generalized least squares) and instrumental variables.
• Understand and apply advanced regression analysis such as panel data, non-stationarity and GARCH models.

• Select relevant methodologies for problems in Finance (identifying the main bottlenecks in the methodology for writing a thesis), execute the analysis in STATA statistical software, interpret the results from that statistical program, judge the robustness of their conclusions.

column1: This course introduces a set of analytical tools to solve practical problems in finance using Microsoft Excel. The objective is to bridge the gap between theory and practice by understanding the theoretical foundations of financial models, implementing these models in Excel with real-world data, and using the outcomes to support financial decision making. The course helps students to gain the financial knowledge and modeling skills needed to succeed in the financial industry that is increasingly relying on quantitative models. Key topics covered in the course include portfolio optimization techniques, performance evaluation methods, option pricing models, and risk management models. The course builds on the introduction to financial markets and portfolio theory given in the Investments course and prepares students for more advanced elective courses in investment management, derivatives, and risk management.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
• Understand the Excel functionality required for financial modeling, such as native Excel functions, matrix manipulation, optimization methods, and simulation tools
• Understand the basic principles of hedge funds and portfolio construction and apply tools to evaluate portfolio performance in an asset management context
• Understand the problems that arise when applying portfolio optimization in practice and be able to implement various approaches to address these issues
• Understand the payoff structure of options, be able to price them using the binomial and Black-Scholes model, compute option Greeks, and understand how options can be used for hedging purposes
• Understand key principles of financial risk management and be able to compute and interpret the market risk exposure (e.g., Value at Risk) of an investment position using various methods

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/116080,2023,Financial Reporting & Analysis,Engels,Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,"['dr. CD Peter', 'prof.dr. E Peek']",,"Inhoud

column1: Financial reporting is vital for the functioning of our economies: investors use accounting information to value shares, loan officers use this information when deciding on whether or not to lend money to a business, and managers use financial performance information to communicate to outside parties the extent to which they were successful in running the business. Financial statements are the principal means of communicating such information about a business to outsiders. The objective of this course is to help you become critical users of financial reports. The achievement of this goal requires an understanding of the concepts and techniques that underlie financial statements and an appreciation for the amount of judgment required in applying accounting concepts. Topics include: the fundamental concepts and techniques underlying financial statements, the accounting treatment of various financial statement items (e.g., investments, liabilities, and shareholders’ equity), the analysis and forecasting of financial statements, and estimating company value and creditworthiness using financial statements.

In sum, students will gain a solid understanding of financial reporting and analysis, enabling them to understand the intricacies of financial reporting and to extract the implications of financial performance reports for businesses, investors and other stakeholders.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: After following this course, the student is able to:

column2: • Explain the purpose of the different components of financial statements and fundamentals of book-keeping
• Apply and evaluate how the main items in financial statements are reported
• Analyze financial statements and use the results of the analysis for decision-making
• Critically evaluate the limits of financial statements and their analyses
• Understand reporting discretion and how it affects financial statements and its analyses

column1: Companies take and manage risks to thrive and survive. In this course, you will learn how to identify, measure, and manage risks that arise in financial markets and institutions. You will explore different types of financial risks, including credit risk, market risk, liquidity risk, and operational risk, and examine various techniques and strategies used to manage these risks. Through case studies and real-world examples, you will gain an understanding of the role of risk management in financial institutions and markets, and develop the skills necessary to analyze and manage risk in a dynamic and complex financial environment.
We cover the following topics in detail:
• Sources of risk for financial institutions
• Risk measures used in the financial sector

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
• Understand the fundamental principles of financial risk management and their application in financial markets and institutions.
• Identify and measure different types of financial risks, including credit risk, market risk, liquidity risk, and operational risk.
• Apply quantitative methods and tools to measure and manage financial risk.
• Develop critical thinking skills to assess the effectiveness of risk management practices and the impact of regulatory and environmental factors on financial risk.

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/116059,2023,Financial and Tax Consulting,Engels,Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,"['dr. S Kohlhase', 'prof.dr. M van Rinsum']",,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: This course is the first course of the financial strategist track, which introduces students to challenges in performance measurement, incentive alignment, tax policies, financing needs and constraints, and managing a broad range of risks. In particular, this course explores how managing financial resources and navigating tax complexities affect the success of organizations. Students will gain insights into the strategies and tools used by financial managers to optimize corporate performance, align incentives, and address tax-related concerns. This entails topics such as performance measurement, incentive alignment, compensation systems, transfer pricing strategies and their tax consequences, global tax reforms and compliance challenges.

Students will learn how organizations design measurement and incentive systems to steer managers and coordinate between business units, to achieve their strategic objectives. This includes identifying and mitigating factors that may lead to (dys)functional decisions and (sub)optimal performance. One key instrument in achieving organizational alignment is transfer pricing, which is important to maximize performance for incentive reasons as well as for tax reasons. The course will illustrate the tax rules for transfer pricing and explore the balance between achieving coordination among business units and optimizing tax liabilities. Since governments are changing tax rules at unprecedented pace and scale to limit tax-motivated income shifting, we will also evaluate recent global tax reforms and their implications for financial and tax consultancy.

Understanding financial management and taxation in today's dynamic business environment forms basic knowledge for business controllers, CFOs, tax advisors, auditors and professionals in accounting and tax departments of companies of any size. Yet it is also useful and important knowledge for managers in general, as it links back to corporate strategy. Thus, the course is of interest to a broad student audience including students thinking about a career in accounting & finance, strategy, and general management.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
• Analyze the role of performance measurement, incentive alignment, and bonus plans in driving organizational success.
• Evaluate how incentives, managerial biases and transfer pricing influence decision-making within organizations.
• Evaluate the complexities of transfer pricing decisions and their impact on tax planning.
• Analyze the increasing complexity of international tax allocation and the demand for greater tax process efficiency.
• Create and report solutions for Financial Management and Taxation assignments, both individually and based on team discussions.

column1: Het domein van financieel management gaat over een doeltreffende en doelmatige toewijzing van middelen en financiën, beheersvraagstukken en de interne en externe (financiële) verantwoording van organisaties.

Gedegen kennis en inzicht in de financiële functies van organisaties in de publieke sector is onontbeerlijk voor een publiek manager. Het publiek en de politiek verwachten inzicht in welke prestaties een publieke organisatie geleverd heeft en of er geen belastinggeld verspild is. In dit vak leer je hoe deze processen worden gemanaged, hoe wordt geprobeerd middelen zo doelmatig mogelijk te besteden, en hoe daar verantwoording over wordt afgelegd. Daardoor leer je om op effectieve wijze schaarse (geld)middelen toe te wijzen aan doelstellingen van beleid. De insteek bij deze module Financieel Management is daarnaast om (kritische) te reflecteren op de toepassing van vaak aan de private sector ontleende management control-instrumenten. Zo ontstaat inzicht welke mogelijkheden en welke beperkingen zijn verbonden aan de benutting van deze instrumenten in het publieke domein.
De opgedane kennis wordt steeds toegepast op concrete en actuele casussen uit de Nederlandse publieke sector. In een van de colleges komen echter ook voorbeelden uit andere landen voorbij.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: <body>Deze module kent de volgende leerdoelen. Na afloop van de module, is de student in staat om:

column2: • De begrotingscyclus en onderliggende staatsrechtelijke principes daarvan in eigen woorden te beschrijven;
• De belangrijkste spelers en hun rol m.b.t. financieel management bij de overheid herkennen;
• De functie van management control in publieke organisaties te duiden: hoe weet je of de belastingbetaler waar voor zijn geld krijgt?;
• Hervormingen om het financieel management van overheden te verbeteren in binnen- en buitenland te beoordelen en te vergelijken; en
• Mechanismen van verantwoording door publieke organisaties te herkennen en beoordelen.

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/114378,2023,Financieel-economisch strafrecht,Nederlands,Erasmus School of Law,,['prof.mr. PAM Verrest', 'prof.mr.dr. JS Nan', 'SA Eckhardt']",,"Inhoud

Het bijzondere rechtsgebied financieel-economisch strafrecht krijgt een steeds grotere plek binnen het strafrechtelijke systeem. Om ondermijnende en (zware) criminaliteit tegen te gaan worden veel geïnvesteerd in het aanpakken van onder meer witwassen en corruptie (zowel ambtelijk als niet-ambtelijk) en het reguleren van het financiële systeem. Mede aan de hand van de vigerende internationale en Europese (verdrags)bepalingen wordt dit fenomeen behandeld. Daarbij wordt bezien hoe dit rechtsgebied zich verhoudt tot het 'gewone' straf(proces)recht en wordt aandacht besteed aan de wederzijdse beïnvloeding. De vraag is uiteindelijk hoe bijzonder het financieel-economische strafrecht eigenlijk is. Via actuele thema's en interactieve colleges en opdrachten worden contemporaire discussies inzichtelijk gemaakt.
De volgende onderwerpen komen in dit vak in het bijzonder aan bod:
Stevige introductie in het financieel-economische strafrecht als species, bezien vanuit het commune strafrecht als generalis en de interactie tussen beide gebieden binnen het strafrecht.

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/116060,2023,Financing Strategy over the Corporate Lifecycle,Engels,Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,"['dr. D Yan', 'dr. G Xu']",,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Much like individuals, the financing needs and the strategic choices made by firms differ widely across different stages of their lifecycles.  Young, growing firms with few assets or cashflows have different financing needs and constraints from mature firms.  Firms also pursue different growth strategies over different stages of their lifecycle – younger firms typically grow via organic investments while older firms grow via a mix of organic and inorganic investments (e.g., alliances, joint ventures, mergers and acquisitions).  Finally, as firms mature and grow, they may perhaps even exceed the optimal boundaries and may pursue different options for reducing scope via divestitures, for example, via asset sales, spin-offs, or carveouts.  The goals of this course are (i) to provide an overview of the financing needs, constraints, and terms faced by firms over the different stages of their lifecycles; (ii) to discuss different financing strategies, their determinants, and implications over different stages of firms’ lifecycles and (iii) to provide an overview of exit options available to firms.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
• Understand different financing needs for small (entrepreneurial) firms and large corporations
• Understand different financing sources for entrepreneurial companies
• Apply different approaches to valuing a company
• Understand how venture capitals work and the exit strategies of VCs
• Understand and assess fundamental aspects of M&A and private equity. This includes the economic rationale, process, means of payment, financing choices, and agency frictions.
• Describe and evaluate the various types of debt instruments used to finance firms.

column1: <body>This course will explore questions in the philosophy of science and discuss them in relation to examples from all areas of management science. These topics include:

column2: • How do we decide what is scientific and what is not? How can we demarcate science from other activities?
• What makes science hard? What are the problems of induction and underdetermination, and how can they be addressed?
• What are the goals of science? What are concepts of causality? What counts as a good explanation? When are models successful?
• How can we evaluate science? What are the notions of scientific revolutions, paradigms and research programmes? Can science be objective and value-free?

column1: Each session includes a lecture part that introduces key concepts in philosophy of science, and a seminar part in which the readings as well as examples from all areas of management science are discussed.</body>

The use of reference managers will be discussed: using one from the start of your research will help you to manage your literature and to create references and reference lists in your own papers. The services of the Erasmus Data Service Centre will be introduced: the EDSC enables access to financial databases and supports EUR-researchers in using these databases.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Technologische ontwikkelingen veranderen de wijze waarop financiële dienstverlening plaatsvindt in rap tempo. Zeker sinds Covid 19 waarbij iedereen online ging werken is dit in een stroomversnelling gekomen. Traditionele modellen in de financiële sector lijken plaats te maken voor nieuwe, innoverende modellen. De spilfunctie van de bank en andere traditionele financiële ondernemingen wordt op steeds lossere schroeven gezet. Tegenwoordig wordt lenen, beleggen en betalen in toenemende mate gefaciliteerd door middel van andere fenomenen, zoals crowdfunding, Decentralised Finance (DeFi), data sharing (Open Finance) en big data. Toezichthouders en wetgevers onderkennen dat de financiële sector is gebaat bij FinTech, maar breken zich tegelijkertijd het hoofd over de potentiële risico’s die het met zich kan brengen. Het vak FinTech geeft de Rotterdamse financieel recht student de bagage waarmee hij of zij verzekerd is van een bestendige toekomst als financieelrechtjurist.

Tijdens het vak FinTech wordt deze nieuwe beweging in de financiële sector uitvoerig behandeld. Gedurende het vak worden de verschillende de aspecten van FinTech behandeld. In elke college wordt steeds de connectie gelegd tussen de praktijk en de juridische gevolgen volgens het volgende stramien:
Wat is mogelijk door de voortschrijdende techniek?
Tot welke nieuwe (wijze van) dienstverlening leidt dit?
Welke risico’s brengt de impact op de markt met zich mee?
Wat doen de toezichthouders en wetgevers in reactie op de risico’s?

Tussendoor zal in groepsverband worden gewerkt aan een doorlopende groepsopdracht waarbij de student leert een FinTech onderneming te begrijpen en het verband te leggen tussen wat de FinTech onderneming doet enerzijds en de risico's en regulatoire verplichtingen anderzijds. Met deze groepsopdracht wordt de opgedane theoretische kennis toegepast op de praktijk.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
• De student kan de ontwikkelingen van de regulering van, het toezicht op en de actoren binnen de FinTechsector overzien.
• De student kan verschillende technieken en toepassingen van FinTech uitleggen en de risico’s en gevolgen voor de markt benoemen.
• De student kan Europese en nationale regulering ten aanzien van FinTech analyseren en de verschillende FinTech toepassingen classificeren binnen dit kader.

• De student kan de maatschappelijke consequenties van technologische ontwikkelingen voor de financiële onderneming en de klant prioriteren en met deze inzichten het huidige reguleringskader beoordelen.
• De student kan zowel schriftelijk als mondeling een juridisch advies geven met betrekking tot een maatschappelijk en/of duurzaam thema ten aanzien van een FinTech toepassing.

• De student is in staat feedback te geven aan medestudenten en te ontvangen van medestudenten en docenten, en is in staat om deze feedback te verwerken in de onderhanden zijnde juridische documenten of presentaties.
• De student is in staat om op de samenwerking in teamverband en het eigen leerproces te reflecteren.

column1: Bij het vak Fiscaal Concernrecht ligt het accent vooral op de gevolgen van belastingheffing voor ondernemers/rechtspersonen. De onderwerpen die in dit vak met name aan de orde zullen worden gesteld zijn onder andere: subjectieve en objectieve belastingplicht in de vennootschapsbelasting, leningen en rente-aftrek (winstdrainage), deelnemingsvrijstelling, fiscale eenheid, fiscale aspecten van fusies en reorganisaties, en enkele beginselen van internationaal belastingrecht.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
• Weten wie voor de heffing van de vennootschapsbelasting als belastingplichtige wordt aangemerkt en op welke wijze een belastingplichtige in de heffing van de vennootschapsbelasting wordt betrokken.
• Weten welke fiscale spelregels de belastingplichtige bij de vaststelling van zijn winst in acht moet nemen.

• Het verkrijgen van globaal inzicht in de grensoverschrijdende effecten van belastingheffing en de beginselen van internationaal belastingrecht, met name voor zover deze betrekking hebben op ondernemingen en hun participanten.
• Beoordelen welke invloed vennootschapsbelastingheffing kan hebben op vennootschappen en hun participanten en wat daarvan de economische implicaties zijn.

column1: Naast de hoorcolleges zal om de week een werkgroep worden gegeven. Over al deze onderwijsbijeenkomsten kunnen in het (her)tentamen vragen worden gesteld.
Voor de hoorcolleges en de werkgroepen geldt een verplichte aanwezigheid!

De werkgroepen staan in het teken van de probleemstelling, opzet, inleiding en twee inhoudelijke hoofdstukken van uw eigen masterscriptie. Iedere student moet op vaste momenten in de cyclus deze stukken inleveren. Daarnaast moet u ook het werk van andere studenten becommentariëren. Het becommentariëren van elkaars werk gebeurt aan de hand van “peer review”, dit heeft als doel het leren geven en ontvangen van opbouwende kritiek. Bovendien moet u in de laatste werkgroep een poster van uw eigen scriptie-onderzoek presenteren.
De reader voor FCV voor het collegejaar 2020 -2021 zal begin 2021 op Canvas worden geplaatst.

Met dit vak wordt beoogd het fiscale recht te confronteren met een aantal andere rechtsgebieden en om studenten een goede start te laten maken met hun scriptie. Deze dubbele doelstelling komt tot uitdrukking in de opzet van het onderwijs. Iedere week is er een hoorcollege van twee uur. Dit kan een gezamenlijk college van twee docenten uit verschillende disciplines zijn, een theoretisch college of college door fiscaalrechtelijke onderzoekers die aan de hand van de eigen onderzoekservaring concreet laten zien hoe fiscaalrechtelijk onderzoek plaats kan vinden en hoe daarbij een beroep is gedaan op verschillende hulpdisciplines. Aan de hand van hun eigen onderzoek laten zij de methodologische problemen en mogelijkheden zien. Op deze manier worden in de hoorcolleges theorie en wetenschappelijke praktijk op elkaar betrokken. In de colleges over normatieve grondslagen wordt deze opzet enkele malen vervangen door een opzet met slechts één docent, waarbij de theoretische analyses worden gecombineerd met casuïstiek. Tijdens de collegecyclus kan nog literatuur worden toegevoegd.
Voor de hoorcolleges geldt een verplichte aanwezigheid. Laatkomers worden geacht niet aanwezig te zijn: kom dus op tijd!

Er zijn parallelle werkgroepen, elk onder leiding van een docent of twee docenten van de sectie Fiscaal recht. Het uiteindelijke doel van de werkgroep is dat de studenten elkaar helpen bij het onderzoek voor de scriptie, leren kritisch op werk van anderen te reflecteren en kritiek van anderen te ontvangen en hetgeen in de hoorcolleges is behandeld direct kunnen toepassen op hun eigen scriptie. Dat gebeurt in de eerste plaats door elkaars opzet te bekritiseren en van constructieve suggesties te voorzien. In tweede instantie wordt ook een hoofdstuk van de scriptie besproken en van kritisch-constructief commentaar voorzien. De ervaring leert dat studenten door het werk van anderen kritisch te lezen en te bediscussiëren, ook waardevolle inzichten opdoen over hoe hun eigen onderzoek kritisch te bekijken en te verbeteren. De beoordeling van elkaars werk, vindt plaats door middel van peer review en de daarbij behorende invulformulieren. De docenten beoordelen het werk eveneens.

column1: Met het Fiscaal Confrontatievak willen we studenten in de laatste fase van hun studie kennis laten maken met wat (fiscale) wetenschapsbeoefening eigenlijk betekent. Dit doen we niet alleen door wetenschappers te laten vertellen over hun onderzoek, maar ook door studenten zelf wetenschappelijke activiteiten te laten verrichten rondom hun eigen masterscriptie.

Het doel van FCV, kennismaken met wetenschapsbeoefening, is op drieledige wijze vormgegeven. Het eerste doel is om studenten over de grenzen van het positieve recht te laten kijken en inzicht te laten krijgen in hoe rechtsvergelijking en verschillende niet-juridische disciplines ondersteunend (en vaak zelfs onmisbaar) kunnen zijn bij fiscaalrechtelijk onderzoek. Het tweede doel is het verwerven van inzicht en kennis in de normatieve grondslagen van het belastingrecht. Het derde doel is om de studenten te ondersteunen bij het schrijven van de masterscriptie en ze daarvoor de benodigde methodologische inzichten en vaardigheden bij te brengen.

column1: In het vak Fiscaal Ondernemerschap wordt behandeld hoe natuurlijke personen/ondernemers, alsmede ondernemers die door middel van een kapitaalvennootschap ondernemen in de belastingheffing worden betrokken. Verder wordt bekeken welke fiscale spelregels de ondernemer bij de vaststelling van zijn winst in acht moet nemen. Ook wordt behandeld welke ondernemershandelingen leiden tot een afrekening over de in de onderneming of de kapitaalvennootschap aanwezige meerwaarden en onder welke condities hij een dergelijke afrekening kan voorkomen. Van de omzetbelasting en de loonbelasting komen de hoofdlijnen aan bod.

column1: Voor studenten die op een of andere wijze werkzaam zullen zijn in het bedrijfsleven of ten behoeve van het bedrijfsleven is enige kennis van het belastingrecht zeer wenselijk of zelfs noodzakelijk. Vele ondernemingsbeslissingen worden mede bepaald door de fiscale regelgeving.

Het fiscale recht is van grote betekenis binnen onze maatschappij. Belastingen worden door de overheid aangewend voor de financiering van collectieve voorzieningen en het beïnvloeden van gedrag. Aan nagenoeg alle handelingen, gebeurtenissen of transacties in het maatschappelijke verkeer zit een fiscaal aspect. Het belastingrecht bepaalt wie belasting moet betalen en hoeveel; concepten zoals het draagkracht- en profijtbeginsel spelen daarbij vaak een belangrijke rol. Elke persoon en elke onderneming in Nederland moet zijn of haar steentje bijdragen aan de jaarlijks benodigde premie- en belastingopbrengst van meer dan 300 miljard euro.

Ondernemingen hebben dagelijks te maken met de heffing van verschillende soorten belastingen. Veel ondernemingsbeslissingen – zoals de rechtsvormkeuze, financieringswijze en de vestigingsplaats – kunnen worden beïnvloed door fiscale gevolgen. Voor een ieder die op een of andere wijze werkzaam zal zijn in het bedrijfsleven of ten behoeve van het bedrijfsleven, is enige basiskennis van het belastingrecht daarom zeer nuttig.

De minor Fiscaal ondernemingsrecht geeft inzicht in het Nederlandse belastingrecht zoals relevant voor ondernemingen. De minor beoogt zodanige fiscale kennis bij te brengen dat ondernemingsbeslissingen in een (toekomstige) functie in het bedrijfsleven of een adviesfunctie ten behoeve van het bedrijfsleven vanuit een breed perspectief genomen kunnen worden.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
• Heb je kennis verkregen over de werking van het Nederlandse belastingsysteem.
• Begrijp je de basisconcepten van het belastingrecht.
• Kun je verbanden leggen tussen verschillende fiscale concepten en kun je het positieve belastingrecht (kritisch) toetsen aan die beginselen.
• Ben je in staat om bij een onderneming (eenvoudige) fiscale aspecten van handelingen, gebeurtenissen of transacties te herkennen en analyseren.
• Ben je in staat om (eenvoudige) fiscale vraagstukken omtrent ondernemingen en ondernemingsbeslissingen op te lossen.
• Ben je in staat om bij een onderneming vooraf (eenvoudige) fiscale gevolgen van voorgenomen handelingen en transacties en van toekomstige gebeurtenissen te voorzien en daarop te anticiperen.
• Heb je inzicht verkregen in de maatschappelijke context van belastingheffing.

column1: Investment portfolios invariably contain a substantial value in fixed income securities alongside other primary asset classes. Institutional investors such as pension funds and insurance companies are interested in fixed income instruments due to the fit with the nature of their liability structure. Though traditionally the term 'fixed income' is associated with bonds, the innovation of the recent two decades in fixed income markets has brought extensive product diversification. Even just for bonds there are different sub-markets for government bonds, eurobonds, covered bonds, subordinated debt, inflation-linked bonds and asset backed securities to name but a few.

Many of these markets interact with markets for derivatives on the main components of risk for fixed income instruments (interest rate, currency and credit risk) and derivatives of the actual instruments themselves (e.g. futures and options on generic bonds). As a result, 'fixed income' nowadays is a collected term for a whole range of different instruments and their markets. As such, fixed income appeals to a wide range of investors, from very risk-averse central bank reserve managers to risk-loving hedge funds.

In order to understand fixed income securities, the course offers an advanced analytical framework to assess their risk characteristics and dynamic valuation. The course also elaborates on the nature of fixed income markets and its main operators. With this knowledge to hand, an insight is provided in the latest techniques in bond portfolio management.
This course consists of two modules. The first module focuses on analytical valuation techniques of fixed income instruments and includes:

column2: • Nature of fixed income markets and its main operators;
• Measuring interest-rate risk through duration and convexity;
• Valuation of credit risk in fixed income securities.

column1: The second module builds on this analytical framework to study the latest thinking in modeling and strategies of bond portfolio management and includes:

column2: • Passive management theories and strategies, including indexing
• Active portfolio strategies for choosing and outperforming a benchmark;
• Liquidity, trading costs and use of leverage;
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
• Students have knowledge of and insight of techniques for valuing standard and more complex fixed income securities at an advanced level.
• Students have knowledge of theories of term structure of interest rates.
• Students are able to evaluate theoretical models and practical management strategies of portfolios of fixed income securities.

column1: Following (or shadowing) a doctor is an excellent way to have a first-hand experience into the daily activities of a physician. It is helpful to find out if a career in medicine is the right choice for you. It gives a better and real understanding of the practice of medicine. You will be required to organise a total of 4 shadowing sessions with 4 different physicians or health care workers (such as hospital specialists, general practitioners, physiotherapists, etc.) in a hospital or general practice. The sessions may be distributed throughout the academic year.  You will have to write a report of each session, in which you should focus on the specific nature of the interaction between patient and health care worker. At the end of the academic year, there will be a concluding plenary session, in which you will share your experiences with fellow students as well as a teacher (medical doctor).

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

<body>This module is based on an Erasmus MC course, called ‘Kennismaking met de beroepspraktijk’ (KBP), which is translated as 'Understanding the professional practice'. The learning goals of this programme are:

column2: • To give you an insight into the professional field of physicians and other health care workers,
• To make you reflect on your own experiences so that you strengthen your professional attitude towards patients, and
• To learn to organise your own shadowing sessions, by making choices and taking initiative
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Food is identity, and it is elementary that food is more than something alimentary. Although most consumers seem to be sufficiently informed/spammed about healthier diets, better tasting affordable foods, higher quality of ingredients and increased food safety, only few of them really know exactly what food is, how it is produced and processed, and how it can affect our health. With a comprehensive and coherent structure, this course aims to apply a blend of basic sciences, such as biology, chemistry and physics with microbiology, biochemistry, and engineering, to answer those questions. The ultimate goal of this course is to help the students in discovering the origin, taste and nutritional value of our food supply, and to understand the paradigm ""from local to global"", focusing on the differences between food from the local market/producers and from the big food corporations and supermarket chains. Major themes include the nutritional and functional properties of food, digestion and absorption processes, food preservation and safety, food additives and regulations, and the interactions between food processing, diets and health. Particular attention throughout the course will be dedicated to the pivotal concept of 'food quality' and 'sustainable food'. The sustainability of food will be tackled from different perspectives, such as healthy dietary patterns, environmental impact of food production (organic food and plant-based diets) and societal drawbacks (food security and the fight against malnutrition). Finally, the course will take advantage of hands-on experiences that will support lectures and PBL sessions with practical applications and creative opportunities.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
At the end of the course, the student will:

column2: • Acquire a detailed knowledge of the chemical and nutritional aspects of food (Lecture 1, Lecture 2 and Lecture 5);
• Have an overview of the physical and chemical processes behind digestion of food and absorption of nutrients (PBL 1);
• Have a clear picture of the basic aspects related to food production, spoilage, fermentation, processing, preservation, and storage (Lecture 3, Lecture 4, PBL 5);
• Exhibit knowledge about the standard nutritional guidelines to select foods that help maximize people’s health and fitness (PBL 2);

• Understand the role of nutrition and diets in preventing chronic diseases and know how to critically interpret the scientific evidence on the association of nutrition with health (Lecture 6, PBL 3);
• Be able to read and understand food labels (PBL 5);
• Critically assess the impact of food production methods and diet regimes on sustainability (PBL 4), as well as food security around the world (PBL 6).

Students will also learn about the most frequently used measures in symptom assessment, as well as about different psychological therapies that have received empirical support in treating forensic populations. At the end of this course, students will have good understanding of this field and they will be able to critically examine current symptom assessment methods as well as treatment options.</body>

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: <body>As an introduction to this field students will start this practical course with getting acquainted with the DSM disorders most frequently found in forensic patients. They will do so by watching films/video clips on this topic and sharing their thoughts on (psychological) problem behavior. After this, students will have an opportunity to learn directly from experienced behavioral experts, trainers and researchers about expert advice during court proceedings and different assessment tools regularly used in forensic practice, such as the Historical Clinical Risk Management-20 (HCR-20) and the Structured Assessment of Protective Factors for violence risk (SAPROF). In addition, students will learn to use the information from the assessment tools to write a report for the court as expert witness.</body>

column1: Recognizing DSM disorders frequently found in forensic populations.
Learn the basics of a forensic report.
Learn to administer two common assessment tools used in forensic reports for risk of recidivism.</body>

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Forensic psychology is narrowly defined as the application of clinical psychology to criminal cases. Specifically, forensic psychologists focus on questions relating to criminal responsibility, risk assessments for various forms of criminal behaviour, and interventions that specifically target those risk factors to reduce the likelihood of recidivism. Further, forensic psychology studies the aetiology of criminal behaviour.

In this course, you will learn various theoretical explanations for criminal behaviour, particularly violent behaviour. You will study biological and sociopsychological theories, with a specific focus on Andrews and Bonta’s theory of criminal conduct, which incorporates a broad range of theoretical perspectives.

This will lead into the second part of the course, where you will be introduced to the Risk-Needs-Responsivity model. You will learn about the history of risk assessments and how criminogenic needs are incorporated. Following from this, you will learn about evidence-based interventions that target those needs, and review the effectiveness of these interventions. Finally, you will learn about the relation between mental health and criminal behaviour.</body>

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
• Understand the aetiology of criminal behaviour from a psychological and biological perspective
• Be able to apply knowledge about risk, needs and responsivity to individual cases to formulate intervention plans
• Understand recent developments in the assessment and treatment of violent and sex offenders
• Be able to critically evaluate the link between mental health and criminal behaviour, using strong arguments based on scientific insights
• Be able to apply in-depth knowledge about two specific types of offences
• Analyze two specific types of offences in-depth in terms of their aetiology, risk factors and treatment

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: In dit blok worden, na een kennismaking met theoretische modellen binnen het forensisch werkveld, twee thema’s behandeld: jeugddelinquentie en kindermishandeling. Ook thema’s als problematische opvoedingssituaties, veelplegers en verslavingsproblematiek komen daarbij aan bod. De centrale vragen daarbij zijn steeds: “Hoe komt deze persoon in deze situatie tot dit gedrag?” en “Hoe kan je verandering aanbrengen in problematisch gedrag en/of situaties?” De studenten maken daarbij gebruik van een bio-psychosociaal model: welke rol spelen genetische aanleg, cognities/affect en sociale context. Daarbij wordt uitgegaan van een interactioneel en transactioneel model. Nadruk ligt ook steeds op systemische context van problematische ontwikkeling en systemische interventie. De studenten zijn na afloop van het blok in staat forensische diagnostiek en behandeling te evalueren en te bediscussiëren.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
• heb je kennis van de meest gebruikte theoretische modellen in het forensische werkveld over ontstaan en instandhouding van grensoverschrijdend en strafbaar gedrag;

• weet je wat er wordt verstaan onder kindermishandeling en heb je kennis van de prevalentie van mishandeling, de risicofactoren voor plegers, de gevolgen voor slachtoffers en effectieve behandeling (voor daders en slachtoffers);

• heb je kennis van de ontwikkeling van delinquent gedrag en ken je risicofactoren voor delinquentie, heb je zicht op de gevolgen voor persoonlijkheidsontwikkeling en psychopathologie en ken je effectieve behandelmethoden voor antisociaal gedrag;
• heb je (waar van toepassing) kennis van diversiteit in prevalentie en behandeling van forensische klachten.
